%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Standard cartridge with 230gr FMJ bullet 
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Effective vs unarmored enemies and mutants. Not recommended vs enemies in body armor 
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Noticeable bullet drop on range 
 
The .45 ACP (11.43x23mm) is a handgun cartridge designed by genius firearms designer John Browning in early XX century for his famous M1911 pistol. Together with that pistol, .45 ACP served in US military for almost 100 years before being replaced by 9x19mm Parabellum. .45 ACP is an effective handgun cartridge that is accurate, has good terminal ballistics and produces moderate recoil in handguns. Thanks to it's subsonic velocity it is a great round for use in suppressed weapons (since it doesn't produce sonic boom). However, it's also a drawback, as because of it's weight and low muzzle velocity, the .45 ACP exhibits noticeable bullet drop on range. While it's not an issue with pistols, which are usually meant to be used on ranges shorter than 30 meters, it's becoming a problem when using submachine guns or pistol-caliber carbines. When shooting targets beyond 50 meters, one should remember that the bullets will start to drop, and adjusting sights or aiming above the target might be needed. It's disadvantages in comparison to 9x19mm Parabellum are higher recoil, much heavier weight and bigger size, which reduces the amount of ammunition that can be fit into pistol's magazine (for example USP magazine fits 16 rounds of 9x19mm and 12 rounds of .45 ACP). It also has worse penetration capabilities than 9x19mm Para. Nonetheless, it's still a good and capable cartridge and the choice between 9x19mm Para and .45 ACP mostly comes down to personal preferences. This round never became as popular in Europe as in USA, and is relatively rare and expensive, further reducing it's popularity among civilians and stalkers.

 The 12.7x108mm cartridge is a heavy machine gun and anti-materiel rifle cartridge developed in Soviet Union and used in almost a hundred countries. It's used in the same role as 12.7x99mm NATO cartridge and has very similar ballistics. The most famous weapon using this cartridge was the venerable DShK machine gun, but it is also used as anti-materiel and sniper round, most notably in KSVK sniper rifle which is valued among mutant hunters in The Zone as a powerful and reliable weapon. This round has very high power and penetration capabilities - it will penetrate walls, sheet metal and heavy body armor. It's very sought after by hunters and various factions fighting each other, so it's price is pretty inflated, but it's very well worth it.

 Incendiary charge in bullets explodes with low power but high temperature upon impact, giving an effect of bright flash and smoke; the explosion can set dry materiel and fuel on fire, but it's not effective on humans - it penetrates very quickly, so explosion occurs after the bullet explodes. It is however different with mutants - their thick bodies aren't as easily shot-through as humans', so it will often explode inside, causing bigger wounds than normal FMJ bullet. Because of possible wound cauterisation, it might not always translate to higher damage, but nevertheless it's very liked by hunters and soldiers defending outposts deep in the Zone. The 14.5x114mm is a heavy machine gun and anti-tank/anti-materiel rifle cartridge used by Soviet Union and Soviet sattelite staties. It was developed for PTRS and PTRD anti-tank rifles in order to provide infantry with (relatively) light anti-tank assets. Before these anti-tank rifles were developed, Soviet infantry had to rely on anti tank guns or use anti tank grenades to destroy enemy armored vehicles, which was often a suicide, especially in open areas of Russian never-ending steppes. 14.5x114mm cartridge could penetrate up to 40mm of rolled homogenous armor on 100 meters distance - an incredible value in these times, as comparable AT rifles of the time had penetration values of about 25mm. Such power came at cost, as the recoil generated by this cartridge is immense, and can even dislocate the shoulder if not handled properly. Later it was used in KPV machine guns in anti-aircraft role thanks to it's very good range and is used as main armament of BTR-80 infantry vehicle. Today it still remains useful, as it has been used in Syria and Ukrainian Civil War as a weapon against light vehicles and as anti-materiel rifle as it could kill enemies, especially snipers, who hid behind walls. In The Zone it is often used, rarer for above reasons and more as a weapon against big mutants like Pseudogiants, especially on outposts of Duty or other factions who keep their presence in deep parts of The Zone, since it's powerful incendiary bullet tears their internal organs to shreds and causes heavy bleeding, killing the beasts in just few shots.

 The .50 BMG cartridge (also called 12.7x99mm) is a heavy machine gun and anti-materiel rifle cartridge developed by famous firearms genius John Browning in United States back during World War I. It was at first meant to be a cartridge for anti-aircraft machine gun, having more power than contemporary service cartridge, the .30-06 Springfield. The first weapon chambered in that cartridge was M2 Browning heavy machine gun, which proved itself as one of the best firearm constructions of all times, still being used by numerous militaries around the world. In Vietnam it was used by snipers, who mounted high-powered scopes on these machine guns, to shoot enemies and targets on extremely high ranges. Most notable example was Carlos Hatchcock, who set the world record for longest range sniper kill in 1967 in Vietnam by killing a Vietcong guerilla on range of 2 500 yd (2 286m). Current record still belongs to .50BMG as a Canadian sniper killed an ISIS terrorist on immense range of 3 450m. This cartridge is also very respected in The Zone, where it found it's place as an effective ammunition for snipers and big game hunters - only the biggest mutants will survive a direct hit from this caliber.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140]Good terminal ballistics despite very low muzzle velocity 
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Recommended for enemies in medium-heavy body armor or mutants 
 
 12.7x54mm is a subsonic cartridge used in VSK/VSSK Vykhlop suppressed sniper rifle developed in similar way as more common 9x39mm ammunition. It uses a shortened .338LM case and a heavy bullet capable of penetrating heavy armor, which allows it to eliminate well protected targets while remaining very silent. Non-official data say VSSK rifles using this ammunition are capable of 1 MOA accuracy on 100m range with maximum effective range of 600 meters. It's low muzzle velocity makes it way less powerful than other 12.7mm rounds, like .50BMG, so don't confuse it with those cartridges - it must be noted that it's muzzle energy is around 2 500 Joules, slightly less than 7.62x51 NATO round. Still, bigger bullet gives it favorable terminal ballistics - on close range it's wounding profile is even higher than .338 Lapua Magnum bullet. Bronze bullet of sniper load tumbles violently in the tissue, which further increases the tissue damage and provides maximum knock-down potential. Armor piercing bullet has a hardened core which can penetrate up to whopping 16mm of steel on 200 meters distance, which is the value close to this achieved by full-power 12.7x108mm bullet and incredible amount for a subsonic bullet. 12.7x54mm STs-130 cartridge has similar case dimensions to 12.7x55mm TP and LP rounds for ASh-12 big-bore assault rifle, but the bullets used in these cartridges are more than two times longer and bigger. They also have different shape, which gives them better ballistics and allows them to tumble in the tissue more effectively, which results in devastating damage. These cartridges are not interchangeable.

 12.7x54mm is a subsonic cartridge used in VSK/VSSK Vykhlop suppressed sniper rifle developed in similar way as more common 9x39mm ammunition. It uses a shortened .338LM case and a heavy bullet capable of penetrating heavy armor, which allows it to eliminate well protected targets while remaining very silent. Non-official data say VSSK rifles using this ammunition are capable of 1 MOA accuracy on 100m range with maximum effective range of 600 meters. It's low muzzle velocity makes it way less powerful than other 12.7mm rounds, like .50BMG, so don't confuse it with those cartridges - it must be noted that it's muzzle energy is around 2 500 Joules, slightly less than 7.62x51 NATO round. Still, bigger bullet gives it favorable terminal ballistics - on close range it's wounding profile is even higher than .338 Lapua Magnum bullet. Bronze bullet of sniper load tumbles violently in the tissue, which further increases the tissue damage and provides maximum knock-down potential. Armor piercing bullet has a hardened core which can penetrate up to whopping 16mm of steel on 200 meters distance, which is the value close to this achieved by full-power 12.7x108mm AP bullet and incredible amount for a subsonic bullet. 12.7x54mm STs-130 cartridge has similar case dimensions to 12.7x55mm rounds for ASh-12 big-bore assault rifle, but the bullets used in these cartridges are more than two times longer and bigger. They also have different shape, which gives them better ballistics and allows them to tumble in the tissue more effectively, which results in devastating damage. These cartridges are not interchangeable.

 12.7x55mm is a subsonic cartridge used in ASh-12/ShAK-12 assault rifles developed in similar way as more common 9x39mm ammunition. Because the dimensions are slightly different, it cannot be used in Vykhlop sniper rifle which uses similar 12.7x54mm ammunition. It uses a shortened .338LM case and a heavy bullet capable of penetrating heavy armor, which allows it to eliminate well protected targets on close range. It's low muzzle velocity makes it way less powerful than other 12.7mm rounds, like .50BMG, so don't confuse it with those cartridges - it must be noted that it's muzzle energy is around 2 500 Joules, slightly less than 7.62x51 NATO round. Still, bigger bullet gives it favorable terminal ballistics - it's wounding profile is close to .338 Lapua Magnum bullet. 12.7x55mm TP cartridge has similar case dimensions to 12.7x54mm STs-130 rounds for VSSK sniper rifle, but the bullet used in these cartridges is smaller and it's shape is closer to conical pistol bullet (like 9x19mm) than a long, pointy spitzer bullet used in sniper cartridges. Due to it's shape and muzzle energy they're very similar to .50 Beowulf ammunition, but the Russian bullets are 2x or even 3x (depending on load) as heavy as American ones. These cartridges are not interchangeable.

The 9.3x64mm 9SN cartridge is a Russian produced special ammunition for SVDK rifle. It is based on 9.3x64mm Brenekke round, a civilian cartridge developed for big game hunting. It's bullet, bigger than typical 7.62 caliber bullet, has a hardened steel core, which is said to be able to penetrate body armor on up to 600 meters. Small amount of these rifles came to The Zone for military evaluation, and this ammunition is used when it's needed to take down targets in armor or behind cover on high range, where 7.62x54mmR cartridges are less effective. It was also found to be more effective on mutants, but since there are other weapons useful for hunting them this caliber never caught on among Stalkers.

 The 7.62x51 NATO round is a full-size rifle cartridge developed in the 1950s as a standard for rifles and machine guns among NATO countries, it also replaced .30-06 Springfield as service rifle and machine gun ammunition in USA. It was based on civilian .308 Winchester cartridge with which it's interchangeable (.308 Win ammo can be loaded and fired from rifles chambered in 7.62x51 NATO and vice versa) - differences are negligible; 7.62x51 NATO has marginally thicker case and produces slightly lower pressure. Bigger dimensions allow for more propellant than in 5.56x45 rounds, giving it way longer range and better terminal ballistics. Like all full-size rifle round it is powerful, provides high accuracy, good terminal ballistics and has high penetration potential, it is also very universal and can shoot a lot of types of bullets - FMJ, SP, AP, OTM and others. On the other hand, it produces strong recoil and is way heavier than smaller intermediate rounds. One of it's advantages over other rounds are it's well designed dimensions, which allow for very reliable feeding. In tests, weapons chambered in 7.62x54mmR had 17% higher chance of malfunction compared to weapons chambered in 7.62x51mm NATO. German DM111 rounds are famous for their good terminal ballistics thanks to special bullet construction. This round is used by various rifles and machine guns of western production, lots of which made it's way from Germany to The Zone through black market affiliations. It's not as cheap as similar 7.62x54mmR used by former Warsaw Pact countries, but nonetheless it's a popular and easily available round.

 .357 Magnum is a revolver cartridge with a .357-inch (around 9 mm) bullet diameter. It was created by Smith and Wesson and Winchester constructors for use in revolvers as a more powerful alternative to .38 Special, starting the "Magnum era" of handgun ammunition. Thanks to its high propellant power and soft-point bullet it expands very well in tissue, resulting in higher tissue damage upon impact than other handgun cartridges like .38 Special or 9x19mm Para. This makes it much more effective upon hit compared to typical handgun cartridges, like 9x19 Para and .45ACP. On the other hand, revolvers have lower capacity than modern handguns, and the .357 itself produces stronger recoil than these rounds, which requires more training to use it efficiently. Before choosing it as your primary cartridge be sure you can control the recoil and achieve high accuracy, as this round can be pretty unforgiving. Nonetheless, .357 Magnum is popular and effective load for personal protection and is probably the only Magnum load that is not "overkill" when it comes to concealed carry weapon choice.

 Premium personal defense cartridge with high-pressure load and higher quality Jacketed Hollow Point bullet for both higher velocity, expansion in tissue and penetration. .357 Magnum is a revolver cartridge with a .357-inch (around 9 mm) bullet diameter. It was created by Smith and Wesson and Winchester constructors for use in revolvers as a more powerful alternative to .38 Special, starting the "Magnum era" of handgun ammunition. Thanks to its high propellant power and soft-point bullet it expands very well in tissue, resulting in higher tissue damage upon impact than other handgun cartridges like .38 Special or 9x19mm Para. This makes it much more effective upon hit compared to typical handgun cartridges, like 9x19 Para and .45ACP. On the other hand, revolvers have lower capacity than modern handguns, and the .357 itself produces stronger recoil than these rounds, which requires more training to use it efficiently. Before choosing it as your primary cartridge be sure you can control the recoil and achieve high accuracy, as this round can be pretty unforgiving. Nonetheless, .357 Magnum is popular and effective load for personal protection and is probably the only Magnum load that is not "overkill" when it comes to concealed carry weapon choice.

 .44 Remington Magnum, also called .44 Mag, is a high-caliber cartridge designed for revolvers. It is based on a lenghtened .44 Special case, loaded to higher pressure. For the long time it was the most powerful handgun cartridge in existence, but was later eclipsed by newer, even bigger cartridges. However, it still remains a very popular cartridge and is viable as a hunting round. It has too high recoil to be used as reliable personal defence round in typical defence scenarios, but because of it's great terminal ballistics it is very useful in shooting bigger animals - in places like Alaska people are more likely to be attacked by bears than criminals, and because of that it is a good choice to carry a .44 Magnum handgun there. The Zone also is one of these places, since mutant activity is high and they are often way more resistant than humans. Because of that, a lot of Stalkers carry a Magnum revolver as their sidearm. .44 Magnum ammunition is pricy, but availability is relatively high.

 .50 Action Express is a high-caliber pistol cartridge and one of the most powerful handgun cartridges in existence. It has bigger dimensions than comparable .44 Magnum cartridge, most notably wider bullet, which causes higher tissue damage upon hitting. While it wasn't adopted by any military and is very rarely used by hunters, remaining rather a curiosity among shooters, it surprisingly made a place for it in The Zone. It has too high recoil to be used as reliable personal defence round in typical defence scenarios, but because of it's great terminal ballistics it is very useful in shooting bigger animals - in places like Alaska people are more likely to be attacked by bears than criminals, and because of that it is a good choice to carry a Magnum handgun there. The Zone also is one of these places, since mutant activity is high and they are often way more resistant than humans. Because of that, a lot of Stalkers carry a Magnum revolver as their sidearm, and some also use Desert Eagle pistols - including the ones chambered in .50 Action Express. This cartridge provides very high wounding potential and longer range than typical pistol bullet, but requires careful aiming and strong hands, even though Desert Eagle's semiautomatic action efficiently absorbs part of recoil. Overally, if you plan an expedition to place where mutants are plentiful, .50AE Desert Eagle on your hip will make you feel safer.

 Extremely powerful. The .500 SW Magnum is a semi-rimmed handgun cartridge developed in early 2000s. It was designed as a cartridge for hunting all kinds of animals in North America and is currently the most powerful mass-produced handgun cartridge in existence. Some loads can produce as much as 4000 Joules of muzzle energy, two times that of 7.62x39mm cartridge of AKM rifle. It is not without a cost - the recoil is absolutely immense, and untrained shooters might not be able to withstand it. It is almost impossible to effectively fire it rapidly. It's power however allows to bring down most mutants in The Zone reliably, without need to hit them multiple times. It's huge size and heavy weight however makes it less popular as a hunting tool, with mutant hunters preferring battle rifles loaded with Soft Point bullets, and smaller Magnum handguns as sidearms.

 .30 Carbine (7.62x33mm) is a carbine cartridge used in the M1 Carbine introduced early in World War II. It is meant to be an intermediate cartridge, between .45 ACP and .30-06 Springfield rounds. It's shape (it's not bottlenecked, like other intermediate cartridges), dimensions and ballistics are similar to those of .357 Magnum cartridge. After World War II ended, multiple countries' militaries used M1 and M2 Carbines and had this cartridge in their warehouses, and meanwhile M1 Carbine itself became quite popular choice among non-military gun owners as a "patrol rifle", weapon for personal defence or hunting. Because of that, .30 Carbine is still produced for civilian market and it was brought over to The Zone together with surplus Carbines.

 The .338 Lapua Magnum (8.6x70mm) is a full-size rifle cartridge, developed jointly by Finnish companies SAKO and Lapua and British Accuracy International during the 1980s as a high-powered, long-range cartridge for military snipers. It became combat proven in the Afghanistan and Iraq War, giving it international fame and making it more popular among hunters and recreational shooters. At least two longest-range record kills were achieved with this round. It is used by militaries all around the world, eg. USA, UK, Germany, but also Finland, Poland, Ukraine and Russia, among others. .338 Lapua Magnum is a round that fills the gap between 7.62x51mm NATO round, which loses too much energy on ranges above 800 meters, and .50 BMG, which was designed as a heavy machine gun round and is not a perfect for precision shooting. Sporting a specially designed match bullet this round has extremely high accuracy and provides good balance between penetration and damage, allowing it to engage all types of targets. In The Zone it is a rather rare and pricy cartridge, only rarely used by snipers and hunters of all factions.

 A shotgun shell is a self-contained cartridge typically loaded with multiple metallic shots, which are small, generally spherical projectiles. Buckshot cartridges usually contain 6 to 8 of such projectiles, which are extremely lethal at close range. Cheap and reliable, they are primary tool for hunters in The Zone, but can also prove effective in close quarters combat. Gauge is a unit of measurement when it comes to smoothbore firearms. 12 Gauge equals to 18.53mm caliber, while 28 Gauge equals to 13.97mm.

It doesn't have enough force to penetrate skin of bigger animals, icluding humans. Since almost every Stalker in The Zone wears at least heavy clothing (not to mention body armor), birdshot it absolutely useless in combat.  Shotgun slug (also called "Brenekke" after it's designer, Wilhelm Brenekke) is a heavy projectile made of lead, copper, or other material and fired from a shotgun, designed for hunting large game, self-defense, and many other uses. Slugs provide higher accuracy and range than buckshot. Being an 18mm projectile, it also causes extremely high tissue damage, which is further increased due to it's potential expansion. Slugs can be also effective against enemies in body armor, since its sheer power causes blunt-trauma damage upon hit, which can result in internal organs damage and heavy internal bleeding, leading to death. Shotgun slugs are popular in The Zone due to it's sheer power and extended range, which allows to reliably put down even most fierce mutants and enemies wearing heaviest body armor. Gauge is a unit of measurement when it comes to smoothbore firearms. 12 Gauge equals to 18.53mm caliber, while 28 Gauge equals to 13.97mm.

 Sabot is a structural device which holds a bullet of lower caliber than the barrel it is fired from. This is the case here - a 7.62mm bullet was inserted into sabot and placed in a shotgun shell. That gives it higher accuracy and penetration than 12ga slug for the cost of less power. It is a niche round but can have it's uses if your main weapon is a shotgun and you're caught in a battle on distance. Works best fired from long barrels. Gauge is a unit of measurement when it comes to smoothbore firearms. 12 Gauge equals to 18.53mm caliber, while 28 Gauge equals to 13.97mm.

 Flechettes loaded into shotgun shell were used since the war in Vietnam. Because of their disappointing wounding capabilities and lower than expected accuracy they are no longer used in military applications, but their high penetration can make them useful in some very rare cases. Their niche usefulness, high price and overall rarity make them extremely unpopular among Stalkers, who prefer using low-caliber intermediate cartridges like 5.45 or 5.56 instead.

 A shotgun shell is a self-contained cartridge typically loaded with multiple metallic shots, which are small, generally spherical projectiles. Buckshot cartridges usually contain 6 to 8 of such projectiles, which are extremely lethal at close range. Cheap and reliable, they are primary tool for hunters in The Zone, but can also prove effective in close quarters combat. Gauge is a unit of measurement when it comes to smoothbore firearms. 12 Gauge equals to 18.53mm caliber, while 28 Gauge equals to 13.97mm.

Shotgun slug (also called "Brenekke" after it's designer, Wilhelm Brenekke) is a heavy projectile made of lead, copper, or other material and fired from a shotgun, designed for hunting large game, self-defense, and many other uses. Slugs provide higher accuracy and range than buckshot. Being an 18mm projectile, it also causes extremely high tissue damage, which is further increased due to it's potential expansion. Slugs can be also effective against enemies in body armor, since its sheer power causes blunt-trauma damage upon hit, which can result in internal organs damage and heavy internal bleeding, leading to death. Gauge is a unit of measurement when it comes to smoothbore firearms. 12 Gauge equals to 18.53mm caliber, while 28 Gauge equals to 13.97mm.

28 Gauge bird hunting shell. Upon discharge it send a thick cloud of about 100 very small metallic pellets in general area of target, increasing chance of hit. It doesn't have enough force to penetrate skin of bigger animals, icluding humans. Since almost every Stalker in The Zone wears at least heavy clothing (not to mention body armor), birdshot it absolutely useless in combat. Gauge is a unit of measurement when it comes to smoothbore firearms. 12 Gauge equals to 18.53mm caliber, while 28 Gauge equals to 13.97mm.

 23mm round designed for KS-23 shotgun, equivalent of 6 gauge shotgun shell. Because 23mm shotguns barrels are rifled, they're not very effective for shooting buckshot, but still have considerate power - the Shrapnel-25 round is similar in power to 3.5" Magnum shotgun shell with No.4 buckshot. These rounds are only produced in Russia for MVD, but are sometimes locally manufactured and handloaded by big game hunters in The Zone, who like the extreme power of 23mm shotguns.

 23mm round designed for KS-23 shotgun, equivalent of 6 gauge shotgun shell. 23mm shotgun barrels are rifled, which make them extremely effective for shooting slugs. Shotgun slug (also called "Brenekke" after it's designer, Wilhelm Brenekke) is a heavy projectile made of lead, copper, or other material and fired from a shotgun, designed for hunting large game, self-defense, and many other uses. Slugs provide higher accuracy and range than buckshot. Being a 23mm projectile, it also causes extremely high tissue damage, which is further increased due to it's potential expansion. Slugs can be also effective against enemies in body armor, since its sheer power causes extreme blunt-trauma damage upon hit, which can result in internal organs damage and heavy internal bleeding, leading to death. Shotgun slugs are popular in The Zone due to it's sheer power and extended range, which allows to reliably put down even most fierce mutants and enemies wearing heaviest body armor. 23mm slug is even more powerful than 12 gauge slug and is extremely effective vs mutants. These rounds are only produced in Russia for MVD, but are sometimes locally manufactured and handloaded by big game hunters in The Zone, who like the extreme power of 23mm shotguns.

 The 5.45x39mm is an intermediate cartridge developed in Soviet Union after western 5.56x45mm ammunition and M16 rifles were captured and evaluated. 5.45x39mm was made for use in new AK-74 rifle which was intended to replace the venerable 7.62x39mm cartridge and AKM rifles in service. It's dimensions provide very reliable feeding from magazine (which made it's part in making AKs one of the most reliable firearms ever) but it still keeps it's corrosive load just like 7.62x39mm cartridge, that is rather harsh on weapon's internals, which makes it susceptible for rusting. Because of that, despite their reliability, weapons chambered in that ammo should be cleaned often. It's advantages over 7.62x39mm are it's lighter weight, high muzzle velocity, flat trajectory and way lower recoil, which allows for effective rapid fire on the target, all that for the cost of slightly less power, but it still retains good terminal ballistics due to it's susceptibility to tumbling in the tissue. All that made 5.45x39mm a preferable alternative to older type of ammunition and it continues to stay as the main service cartridge of Russia and some of the former Warsaw Pact countries. Ukrainian military also uses this ammunition as standard and huge amounts were stolen from military warehouses or bought from corrupt officers to finally appear on the black market in The Zone. It is widely available and its low price makes it a great choice for many Stalkers.

 The 5.45x39mm is an intermediate cartridge developed in Soviet Union after western 5.56x45mm ammunition and M16 rifles were captured and evaluated. 5.45x39mm was made for use in new AK-74 rifle which was intended to replace the venerable 7.62x39mm cartridge and AKM rifles in service. It's dimensions provide very reliable feeding from magazine (which made it's part in making AKs one of the most reliable firearms ever) but it still keeps it's corrosive load just like 7.62x39mm cartridge, that is rather harsh on weapon's internals, which makes it susceptible for rusting. Because of that, despite their reliability, weapons chambered in that ammo should be cleaned often. It's advantages over 7.62x39mm are it's lighter weight, high muzzle velocity, flat trajectory and way lower recoil, which allows for effective rapid fire on the target, all that for the cost of slightly less power, but it still retains good terminal ballistics due to it's susceptibility to tumbling in the tissue. All that made 5.45x39mm a preferable alternative to older type of ammunition and it continues to stay as the main service cartridge of Russia and some of the former Warsaw Pact countries. Ukrainian military also uses this ammunition as standard and huge amounts were stolen from military warehouses or bought from corrupt officers to finally appear on the black market in The Zone. It is widely available and its low price makes it a great choice for many Stalkers. 7N24 cartridge is called a "super-armor piercing cartridge" as it has heavy bullet (64gr compared to 27gr of 7N22) with tungsten-carbide core, which gives it very high penetration capabilities.

 The 5.56x45mm NATO (official NATO nomenclature 5.56 NATO) is an intermediate cartridge family developed in Belgium by FN Herstal, based on .223 Remington cartridge. It was developed in 1960s when first AR-15 rifle (later standarised as M16) came out and quickly shown it's huge potential, despite conservative decision makers' opposition. It became the standard cartridge for NATO forces as well as many non-NATO countries. It is less powerful than full-size 7.62x51mm cartridge, but also weights less, has flatter trajectory and has way lower recoil, improving rapid-firing accuracy. Despite it's small dimensions it has pretty good terminal ballistics as it's prone to yaw and fragment in soft tissue, causing way higher damage than its' caliber would suggest. However, it's yawing potential is dependant on velocity (and therefore the lenght of the barrel, since the longer the barrel the higher the velocity) and it loses a lot of power when shot from short-barreled platform. Despite this issue, 5.56x45mm is an all-around effective cartridge that is available in multiple types which you can choose depending on your needs. It is well liked by Stalkers and is readily available on the market as one of the few western types of ammunition.

It was developed in 1960s when first AR-15 rifle (later standarised as M16) came out and quickly shown it's huge potential, despite conservative decision makers' opposition. It became the standard cartridge for NATO forces as well as many non-NATO countries. It is less powerful than full-size 7.62x51mm cartridge, but also weights less, has flatter trajectory and has way lower recoil, improving rapid-firing accuracy. Despite it's small dimensions it has pretty good terminal ballistics as it's prone to yaw and fragment in soft tissue, causing way higher damage than its' caliber would suggest. Mk262 is an american Open Tip Match cartridge that was first used as ammunition for marksman rifles, but thanks to it's greatly improved terminal ballistics it started to become used by Special Forces in M4A1 and Mk18 carbines for higher effectiveness. For these reasons it also become favourite ammo for some Mercenaries groups, and some batches can also be bought on black market in The Zone.

 6.8 SPC (6.8x43mm) is a modern intermediate rifle cartridge, being a middle ground between 5.56x45mm and 7.62x39mm cartridges. It was developed by Remington Arms together with members of US Army marksmen and USSOCOM. In early 2000s it was used in special forces and reports considered it superior to 5.56 in CQC due to very good wounding potential, but also found it to be lacking in long range engagements. Nonetheless, terminal ballistics of 6.8SPC FMJ bullets are still superior to 5.56x45mm FMJ bullets on all ranges, actually exceeding those of the famous 7.62x39mm round. The advantages of 6.8SPC over 5.56x45mm NATO are way better terminal ballistics when using FMJ bullet, especially on ranges above 100 meters, longer effective range and slightly improved accuracy. It's drawbacks are slightly heavier weight and bigger dimensions - 6.8x43SPC fits in standard AR-15 magazines, but only 25 round can be loaded (instead of standard 30); if one wants to have 30 rounds capacity in AR-15, he needs to buy a dedicated 6.8SPC magazine. It wasn't adopted by US Army due to financial and logistical issues, but it found it's place in law enforcment and few countries (with Saudi Arabia as main user). It also found it's place in The Zone, where it's regarded as reliable and efficient round in use against enemies in body armor and mutants, thanks to it's ballistics and wounding capability. However, it's arguably high cost and low availability keep some stalkers off of this ammo, who tend to stick to other, more popular loads.

 .300 AAC Blackout (7.62x35mm) is an intermediate cartridge. It was developed for use in AR-15 carbines, with purpose to achieve ballistics similar for soviet 7.62x39mm round. Unlike 5.56x45mm it provides good terminal ballistics even when shot from short barrels and has great performance when used as subsonic cartridge in suppressed carbines (providing ballistics comparable to 9x39mm rounds). Out of longer barrels it has similar accuracy and bullet drop as 5.56x45mm round, but it keeps higher energy on high distance. It can be loaded to standard 5.56 AR-15 magazines without loss in capacity and shot without problems. It's advantage over 5.56x45mm NATO are better terminal ballistics, especially when shooting subsonic loads, while feeding in AR-15 without problems - AR-15s that were adapted for comparable 7.62x39mm rounds were often jamming. Disadvantages are heavier weight and lower muzzle velocity. .300 Blackout is currently sometimes used by special forces and well regarded among hunters as a reliable and effective load for medium game. In Zone it is well liked for the same reasons, providing better wounding capabilities than 5.56 and 5.45 caliber weapons, all that while reliably loading from AR-15 type weapons. It's high price and low availability can be a problem for some Stalkers, who may prefer cheaper rifles in more popular calibers.

 .300 AAC Blackout (7.62x35mm) is an intermediate cartridge. It was developed for use in AR-15 carbines, with purpose to achieve ballistics similar for soviet 7.62x39mm round. Unlike 5.56x45mm it provides good terminal ballistics even when shot from short barrels and has great performance when used as subsonic cartridge in suppressed carbines (providing ballistics comparable to 9x39mm rounds). Out of longer barrels it has similar accuracy and bullet drop as 5.56x45mm round, but it keeps higher energy on high distance. It can be loaded to standard 5.56 AR-15 magazines without loss in capacity and shot without problems. It's advantage over 5.56x45mm NATO are better terminal ballistics, especially when shooting subsonic loads, while feeding in AR-15 without problems - AR-15s that were adapted for comparable 7.62x39mm rounds were often jamming. Disadvantages are heavier weight and lower muzzle velocity. .300 Blackout is currently sometimes used by special forces and well regarded among hunters as a reliable and effective load for medium game. In Zone it is well liked for the same reasons, providing better wounding capabilities than 5.56 and 5.45 caliber weapons, all that while reliably loading from AR-15 type weapons. It's high price and low availability can be a problem for some Stalkers, who may prefer cheaper rifles in more popular calibers.

 6x35 KAC is basically a 5.56x45mm cartridge shortened by 10mm. This provides lower recoil and ammo weight, while keeping almost identical velocity out of short (10", 254mm) barrel. This cartridge didn't gain popularity and was overshadowed by similar ammunition like FN's 5.7x28mm. It is used only by KAC PDW.

 The 7.62x54mmR is a rimmed rifle cartridge developed by the Russian Empire and introduced as a service cartridge in 1891. Originally designed for the bolt-action Mosin–Nagant rifle, it was used during the late Tsarist era and throughout the Soviet period to the present day. Case of big dimension allows to be loaded with more powder than 7.62x51 NATO cartridge, which allows it to have slightly more energy. It can be loaded with lots of different bullet types and it works great with FMJ, SP and AP rounds, which makes it a very universal cartridge. Sniper loads also exist and are used as default ammunition in Soviet SVD and Russian SV-98 sniper rifle. It's rimmed construction however has its' flaws - in comparison with 7.62x51 NATO, it has been proven that weapons using 7.62x54R are about 17% more prone to jams and stoppages than same constructions fed by 7.62x51mm NATO. Military 7.62x54mmR cartridges are also using corrosive primers, so they increase weapons' susceptibility to rust. Despite it's disadvantages, the cartridge remains one of the few standard-issue rimmed cartridges still in military use and has the longest service life of all military-issued cartridges in the world. It is also popular among civilians as a hunting round and is valued in The Zone for it's high power, range and good terminal ballistics.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Bullet contains small incendiary charge which explodes upon impact 
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Recommended for dangerous mutants and enemies in heavy body armor. 
 
 Incendiary charge in bullets explodes with low power upon impact, giving an effect of bright flash and smoke; the explosion can set dry materiel and fuel on fire, but it's not effective on humans - it penetrates very quickly, so explosion occurs after the bullet explodes. It is however different with mutants - their thick bodies aren't as easily shot-through as humans', so it will often explode inside, causing slightly higher wounds than normal FMJ bullet. Because of possible wound cauterisation, it might not always translate to higher damage, but nevertheless it's very liked by hunters and soldiers defending outposts deep in the Zone. Especially Duty hunter squads often carry at least one machinegun loaded with these rounds to maximise their firepower.

 The 7.62x39mm M43 round is an intermediate cartridge of Soviet origin that was designed during World War II. It was first used in SKS rifle, but it became most famous as standard AK rifle ammunition - it's to some part also the ammunition's characteristics that made the AK one of the most reliable firearms in the world. It's dimensions provide very reliable feeding from magazine but because of it's corrosive load it's rather harsh on weapon's internals, which makes it susceptible for rusting. Because of that, despite their reliability, weapons chambered in that ammo should be cleaned often. Due to the worldwide proliferation of AK pattern rifles, the cartridge is used by both militaries and civilians alike. Among it's advantages are reliable feeding, relatively good ballistics, good penetration capabilities on hard cover and easy manufacturing process, but it also has it's flaws - namely it's heavier than modern ammunition types, it produces recoil that is hard to control when shooting in bursts and it's terminal ballistics are rather unfavorable when compared to it's raw energy factor - M43 FMJ bullet yaws only after it passed long distance, which means that most of the time it just overpenetrates and leaves the body without causing much damage to vital organs. It was largely replaced in Russian military service by the 5.45x39mm cartridge, which provides better ballistics and produces half the recoil, used in the AK-74 assault rifle and its variants. However, in the 21st century the 7.62x39mm still remains a common service rifle chambering, including for newly developed rifles.

 The 7.62x39mm M43 round is an intermediate cartridge of Soviet origin that was designed during World War II. It was first used in SKS rifle, but it became most famous as standard AK rifle ammunition - it's to some part also the ammunition's characteristics that made the AK one of the most reliable firearms in the world. It's dimensions provide very reliable feeding from magazine but because of it's corrosive load it's rather harsh on weapon's internals, which makes it susceptible for rusting. Because of that, despite their reliability, weapons chambered in that ammo should be cleaned often. Due to the worldwide proliferation of AK pattern rifles, the cartridge is used by both militaries and civilians alike. Among it's advantages are reliable feeding, relatively good ballistics, good penetration capabilities on hard cover and easy manufacturing process, but it also has it's flaws - namely it's heavier than modern ammunition types, it produces recoil that is hard to control when shooting in bursts and it's terminal ballistics are rather unfavorable when compared to it's raw energy factor - M43 FMJ bullet yaws only after it passed long distance, which means that most of the time it just overpenetrates and leaves the body without causing much damage to vital organs. It was largely replaced in Russian military service by the 5.45x39mm cartridge, which provides better ballistics and produces half the recoil, used in the AK-74 assault rifle and its variants. However, in the 21st century the 7.62x39mm still remains a common service rifle chambering, including for newly developed rifles.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Bullet contains small incendiary charge which explodes upon impact 
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Recommended for dangerous mutants and enemies in heavy body armor. 
 
 Incendiary charge in bullets explodes with low power upon impact, giving an effect of bright flash and smoke; the explosion can set dry materiel and fuel on fire, but it's not effective on humans - it penetrates very quickly, so explosion occurs after the bullet explodes. It is however different with mutants - their thick bodies aren't as easily shot-through as humans', so it will often explode inside, causing slightly higher wounds than normal FMJ bullet. Because of possible wound cauterisation, it might not always translate to higher damage, but nevertheless it's very liked by hunters and soldiers defending outposts deep in the Zone. Especially Duty hunter squads often carry at least one machinegun loaded with these rounds to maximise their firepower. The 7.62x39mm round is an intermediate cartridge of Soviet origin that was designed during World War II. It was first used in SKS rifle, but it became most famous as standard AK rifle ammunition - it's to some part also the ammunition's characteristics that made the AK one of the most reliable firearms in the world. It's dimensions provide very reliable feeding from magazine but because of it's corrosive load it's rather harsh on weapon's internals, which makes it susceptible for rusting. Because of that, despite their reliability, weapons chambered in that ammo should be cleaned often. Due to the worldwide proliferation of AK pattern rifles, the cartridge is used by both militaries and civilians alike. Among it's advantages are reliable feeding, relatively good ballistics, good penetration capabilities on hard cover and easy manufacturing process, but it also has it's flaws - namely it's heavier than modern ammunition types, it produces recoil that is hard to control when shooting in bursts and it's terminal ballistics are rather unfavorable when compared to it's raw energy factor - M43 FMJ bullet yaws only after it passed long distance, which means that most of the time it just overpenetrates and leaves the body without causing much damage to vital organs. It was largely replaced in Russian military service by the 5.45x39mm cartridge, which provides better ballistics and produces half the recoil, used in the AK-74 assault rifle and its variants. However, in the 21st century the 7.62x39mm still remains a common service rifle chambering, including for newly developed rifles. This variant has standard FMJ M43 bullet, which which offers good balance between penetration and tissue damage, allowing to effectively engage all types of targets.

 The 9x18mm Makarov is a Russian handgun cartridge designed in 1946, and in 1951 it became a standard military pistol cartridge of the Soviet Union and the Eastern Bloc, analogous to the 9x19mm Parabellum in NATO and Western military use. It has slightly lower power than 9mm Parabellum, but is still an effective pistol cartridge. The reason for it's low power is because the Soviets wanted a compact, simple blowback action pistol - this type of construction can't handle more powerful ammunition, and 9x18mm is the most powerful round that can be used in such design without problems. Overally, 9x18mm is about 30% weaker than 9x19mm Parabellum. It's very good in small, compact pistols like PM, but loses out to 9x19mm when it comes to full-size military pistols, and in the end was replaced by 9x19mm Parabellum in Russian army. 9x18mm remains in service with Ukrainian military. It is widely available in The Zone, large amounts were stolen from the military warehouses or bought off from corrupt military officers. It's high availability and low price make it a great choice for many Stalkers.

 The 9x19mm Parabellum is a pistol cartridge designed by Georg Luger and introduced in 1902 for his Luger semi-automatic pistol. It is also known under the names 9mm Luger, 9mm Para, 9x19. It is a standard pistol cartridge for NATO forces as well as many non-NATO countries. 9x19mm Parabellum is the worlds most popular and widely used military handgun and submachine gun cartridge. 9x19mm Parabellum offers the best balance between power and penetration, and low weight with controllable recoil. It is very popular all around the world as it is effective in police, military and self-defense use. Its extreme popularity makes it highly common in Europe, so it is also readily available in The Zone. Most 9x19mm ammunition comes from military and black market, but some stalkers also bring their own pistols they own for self-defense, so many 9x19mm ammo variants can be found in The Zone. This is a variant with a standard FMJ bullet, which offers good balance between penetration and tissue damage, allowing to effectively engage all types of targets. Military NATO 9x19mm is loaded to higher pressures than civilian loads, which makes it slightly more effective in combat.

 10mm Auto (10x25mm) is a powerful handgun cartridge dedicated primarily for semi-automatic pistols. It was developed by famous firearms and tactics expert, Jeff Cooper, and introduced in '80s together with Bren Ten pistol. After the catastrophic 1986 FBI Miami shootout it was chosen as service caliber for FBI, but was hard to control by agents with weaker hands and was replaced by shorter version, the .40SW. It however remained popular as a sporting, hunting and personal defence round. Due to it's ballistics it's basically called a .357 Magnum for semi-automatics, however some loads can even surpass famed .357 Mag's terminal performance. In The Zone it's a well regarded and respected round, as for Loners main enemies are mutants - and to bring them down, high firepower is mandatory. 10mm pistols are well liked and preferred over Magnum revolvers, but ammo itself is relatively expensive and harder to find - it is however regarded to be worth the hassle.

 10mm Auto (10x25mm) is a powerful handgun cartridge dedicated primarily for semi-automatic pistols. It was developed by famous firearms and tactics expert, Jeff Cooper, and introduced in '80s together with Bren Ten pistol. After the catastrophic 1986 FBI Miami shootout it was chosen as service caliber for FBI, but was hard to control by agents with weaker hands and was replaced by shorter version, the .40SW. It however remained popular as a sporting, hunting and personal defence round. Due to it's ballistics it's basically called a .357 Magnum for semi-automatics, however some loads can even surpass famed .357 Mag's terminal performance. In The Zone it's a well regarded and respected round, as for Loners main enemies are mutants - and to bring them down, high firepower is mandatory. 10mm pistols are well liked and preferred over Magnum revolvers, but ammo itself is relatively expensive and harder to find - it is however regarded to be worth the hassle.

 .40 SW (10x22mm) is a pistol cartridge developed as reduced-power 10mm Auto cartridge for FBI, as 10mm was too powerful for weaker agents, like older people or women. The new cartridge was successful and was adopted by several law enforcment agencies, including FBI. It also became popular with civilian firearms owners as a personal defence round, being something in between 9x19mm Para and .45 ACP. Today's improved cartridges of 9x19mm and .45 ACP overshadow .40SW, but it still remains a viable platform and will definitely do it's job when needed. The only problem with this round is that since it never became as popular in Europe as in USA, availability of that cartridge and firearms chambered in it is pretty low, and finding ammo for it might be relatively hard.

 7.62x25mm TT is a Soviet bottlenecked pistol cartridge, which is basically a hot-loaded version of 7.63x25 Mauser cartridge used in C96 pistol - the dimensions are the same, but since 7.62 TT is more powerful, it is advised against using it in C96 pistol. 7.62 TT was accepted for military in 1930s and since then widely used in Eastern block and Soviet sattelite countries. It was most notably used in TT pistol and PPSh-41 submachine gun, but numerous other designs used this caliber, including weapons of Czech, Yugoslavian and Chinese design. It has considerably high muzzle velocity compared to other handgun cartridges, which, in combination with it's small dimensions give it high penetration capabilities, allowing it to penetrate light body armor. In Russia in rough '90s, mafia bosses wore light bulletproof vests in order to protect themselves, so contract killers often chose TT pistols as their weapons of choice since they could penetrate these vests, and their low price and abundance on black market meant they could simply dump them after the killing to get rid of evidence.

 7.63x25mm Mauser is a bottlenecked pistol cartridge developed in 1890s, one of the first successful semiautomatic pistol cartridges in the world. It was most notably used in famous Mauser C96 pistol, which made astounding career all over the world during and after World War I. In 1920s it was a base for even more famous 7.62x25 TT cartridge, which is basically just a hotter loaded 7.63 Mauser. Back in it's day, 7.63 Mauser was the most powerful semiautomatic pistol cartridge available, but these days are long gone - cartridges like 9x19 Parabellum and .45 ACP made it obsolete in 1930s already, and after WWII almost every military used them instead. Today it remains in production but just as a curiosity and relic firearm load, however, some people kept their old Mausers at home together with ammo, and since some of them surfaced in The Zone, handloads of this ammo are available from some traders. Still, it isn't very popular among Stalkers for it's low power, and newer firearms firing more effective bullets like TT or Makarov are available for cheap too.

 .32 ACP, also known as 7.65 Browning (7.62x17mmSR) is a semi-rimmed handgun cartridge developed by firearms genius John Browning as his first pistol cartridge. It was first used in FN M1900 pistol and immediately became popular. It is small and light, and compact pistols for concealed carry were designed for that caliber even long after more powerful loads like .45ACP and 9x19mm Parabellum appeared, most famous of them being the Walther PPK. Due to it's low energy it has low recoil even when shot from smallest pistols, however, the downside to it is it's lack of reliable wounding potential. Still, as an ammunition for pocket pistol it remains a viable choice. It also found use as ammunition for famous Czech Skorpion SMG, which became very popular thanks to it's compact size, very low price and of course little to no recoil thanks to 7.65 ammunition it uses. Since all these weapons found it's way to The Zone, this ammunition is readily available and popular.

 .25 ACP (6.35x16mmSR) is a semi-rimmed centerfire pistol cartridge designed by firearms genius John Browning in 1905 for FN M1905 pocket pistol. It was designed to duplicate the performance of .22LR cartridge, but with centerfire mechanism for improved reliability. .25 ACP pocket pistols were very popular in years before Second World War and hundreds of thousands were produced. Some of them are still kept by people in Easter Europe, and they found their way into The Zone where they are used concealed as a last ditch weapon.

 .22 Long Rifle (5.6x15mmR) is a .22 caliber rimfire cartridge and is the most prolific sporting cartridge in the world. It was introduced in 1887 and is still very popular to this day. It's low cost, minimal recoil and good accuracy make it a perfect cartridge for amateur and young shooters. Wide variety of .22LR ammo is available, with most popular being Soft Point High Velocity round, which is used as sporting and vermin-hunting cartridge. It has been brought to The Zone as a tool to kill rats and Tushkanos with greater efficiency, and is quite popular among those who want to hunt them, some Stalkers also like to hunt crows, and shooting them with .22LR is a big challenge - those who can reliably bring down a bird with one of .22LR pistols are respected as great marksmen. .22LR Soft Point bullet can penetrate human body and deforms efficiently in tissue, but it can have trouble penetrating thick clothes. Since almost everybody in The Zone wear light body armor or at least heavy jackets, .22LR has no place in combat.

 HK 4.6x30mm is a PDW-type cartridge, developed as a direct competitor to FN's 5.7x28mm. It was designed to have high velocity and penetration potential, similar to that of assault rifle's ammunition, while producing lower possible recoil. While experts on NATO CRISAT tests claimed 5.7x28mm cartridge to be more effective, Germans opposed the outcome, and in effect both of these cartridges began to be used independently, according to preference of militaries or agencies who choose them. 4.6x30mm is said to produce little to no recoil when shot in fully automatic mode from MP7 submachine gun, but, despite it often tumbling in tissue, has low tissue damage potential, the result being that it sometimes requires multiple hits on target to bring it down. All this makes 4.6x30mm and MP7 itself a niche platform, with narrow area of usefulness in regular combat. Either way, MP7 and 4.6mm ammunition are both very light, which allows user to take huge amount of it with him, and low recoil makes it a very easy weapon to use. It made a career in The Zone since it first arrived with Mercenary squad (allegedly associated with French Foreign Legion), as it's low weight and extremely good handling made it popular choice as a sidearm instead of a pistol for those Stalkers who have enough money to spare it for one.

 FN 5.7x28mm is a PDW-type cartridge, developed as a high velocity ammunition for FN P90 and FN Five-seveN pistol. It was designed to have high velocity and penetration potential, similar to that of assault rifle's ammunition, while producing lower possible recoil. It was developed in response to NATO requests for a replacement of 9x19 Parabellum cartridge to one with higher range, velocity and ability to defeat light body armor. In 2003 NATO conducted a series of tests, where 5.7x28mm was deemed superior to comparable 4.6x30mm HK ammunition, however, the German delegation rejected NATO recommendations, which halted the process of adopting the 5.7x28mm round as a standard pistol cartridge for NATO. 5.7x28mm is said to produce little to no recoil when shot in fully automatic mode from FN P90 submachine gun, but, despite it often tumbling in tissue, has low tissue damage potential, the result being that it sometimes requires multiple hits on target to bring it down. All this makes 5.7x28mm a niche platform, with narrow area of usefulness in regular combat. Either way, and 5.7mm ammunition and weapons chambered in it are very light, which allows user to take huge amount of ammunition with him, and low recoil makes it a very easy weapon to use. In The Zone it became valued as it's low weight allows to take a lot of it for long trips deep into the wild while not being a burden to the user.

 The 9x39mm is a cartridge based on the russian 7.62x39 mm round, but with an expanded neck to accommodate a bigger bullet. The intent was to create a subsonic cartridge for suppressed firearms for special forces units that had more power, range and penetration than handgun cartridges. Other russian bullets like 5.45mm or 7.62mm are too light to be effective at subsonic velocities. The round has an effective lethal range of 300 to 400 meters and is not suitable for long-range sniping. The SP-5 is an accurised cartridge contains an FMJ bullet with a steel core, which provides both good penetration and wounding capabilities, being in effect suitable for all types of targets. It's a rare ammunition in The Zone and definitely sought after.

 Civilian-legal 9x39mm cartridge. Since civilian-legal hunting variants of modified (silencer-less) VSS and 9A91 rifles are being sold on Russian market, the civilian-legal 9x39mm ammo also followed. This type of ammunition has 158gr lead-core bullet that can't penetrate armor any better than similar rifle cartridges, but deforms easily in the tissue providing good terminal ballistics. The 9x39mm is a cartridge based on the russian 7.62x39 mm round, but with an expanded neck to accommodate a bigger bullet. The intent was to create a subsonic cartridge for suppressed firearms for special forces units that had more power, range and penetration than handgun cartridges. Other russian bullets like 5.45mm or 7.62mm are too light to be effective at subsonic velocities. The round has an effective lethal range of 300 to 400 meters and is not suitable for long-range sniping. The PAB-9 is a version of 9x39mm cartridge which contains an FMJ bullet with a steel core, which provides good penetration but worse wounding capabilities and accuracy - it has been produced as a cheaper alternative to SP-5 and SP-6 cartridges. However, it's still a rare ammunition in The Zone and definitely sought after.

HEAT warhead for anti-tank warfare used with the RPG-7 grenade launcher. The main purpose of the warhead is to destroy armored vehicles and kill enemies behind cover - HEAT warhead's blast radius is rather weak for such big and heavy round, so it's less useful to fight infantry. In The Zone it is also sometimes used to kill big, dangerous mutants or destroy mutant lairs.

 The 7.62x39mm round is an intermediate cartridge of Soviet origin that was designed during World War II. It was first used in SKS rifle, but it became most famous as standard AK rifle ammunition - it's to some part also the ammunition's characteristics that made the AK one of the most reliable firearms in the world. It's dimensions provide very reliable feeding from magazine but because of it's corrosive load it's rather harsh on weapon's internals, which makes it susceptible for rusting. Because of that, despite their reliability, weapons chambered in that ammo should be cleaned often. Due to the worldwide proliferation of AK pattern rifles, the cartridge is used by both militaries and civilians alike. Among it's advantages are reliable feeding, relatively good ballistics, good penetration capabilities on hard cover and easy manufacturing process, but it also has it's flaws - namely it's heavier than modern ammunition types, it produces recoil that is hard to control when shooting in bursts and it's terminal ballistics are rather unfavorable when compared to it's raw energy factor - M43 FMJ bullet yaws only after it passed long distance, which means that most of the time it just overpenetrates and leaves the body without causing much damage to vital organs. It was largely replaced in Russian military service by the 5.45x39mm cartridge, which provides better ballistics and produces half the recoil, used in the AK-74 assault rifle and its variants. However, in the 21st century the 7.62x39mm still remains a common service rifle chambering, including for newly developed rifles. This ammunition variant is AP round with bullet cotaining hardened steel core, giving it improved penetration for the cost of less wounding capabilities. It was developed during '90s for Russian special forces, so it's rather rare and expensive compared to other AP rounds. Not recommended agains mutants.

It was first used in SKS rifle, but it became most famous as standard AK rifle ammunition - it's to some part also the ammunition's characteristics that made the AK one of the most reliable firearms in the world. It's dimensions provide very reliable feeding from magazine but because of it's corrosive load it's rather harsh on weapon's internals, which makes it susceptible for rusting. Due to the worldwide proliferation of AK pattern rifles, the cartridge is used by both militaries and civilians alike. Among it's advantages are reliable feeding, relatively good ballistics, good penetration capabilities on hard cover and easy manufacturing process, but it also has it's flaws - namely it's heavier than modern ammunition types, it produces recoil that is hard to control when shooting in bursts and it's terminal ballistics are rather unfavorable when compared to it's raw energy factor - M43 FMJ bullet yaws only after it passed long distance, which means that most of the time it just overpenetrates and leaves the body without causing much damage to vital organs. It was largely replaced in Russian military service by the 5.45x39mm cartridge, which provides better ballistics and produces half the recoil, used in the AK-74 assault rifle and its variants. However, in the 21st century the 7.62x39mm still remains a common service rifle chambering, including for newly developed rifles. This variant has standard FMJ M43 bullet, which which offers good balance between penetration and tissue damage, allowing to effectively engage all types of targets.

 The 7.62x39mm round is an intermediate cartridge of Soviet origin that was designed during World War II. It was first used in SKS rifle, but it became most famous as standard AK rifle ammunition - it's to some part also the ammunition's characteristics that made the AK one of the most reliable firearms in the world. It's dimensions provide very reliable feeding from magazine but because of it's corrosive load it's rather harsh on weapon's internals, which makes it susceptible for rusting. Because of that, despite their reliability, weapons chambered in that ammo should be cleaned often. Due to the worldwide proliferation of AK pattern rifles, the cartridge is used by both militaries and civilians alike. Among it's advantages are reliable feeding, relatively good ballistics, good penetration capabilities on hard cover and easy manufacturing process, but it also has it's flaws - namely it's heavier than modern ammunition types, it produces recoil that is hard to control when shooting in bursts and it's terminal ballistics are rather unfavorable when compared to it's raw energy factor - M43 FMJ bullet yaws only after it passed long distance, which means that most of the time it just overpenetrates and leaves the body without causing much damage to vital organs. It was largely replaced in Russian military service by the 5.45x39mm cartridge, which provides better ballistics and produces half the recoil, used in the AK-74 assault rifle and its variants. However, in the 21st century the 7.62x39mm still remains a common service rifle chambering, including for newly developed rifles.

 Incendiary charge in bullets explodes with low power upon impact, giving an effect of bright flash and smoke; the explosion can set dry materiel and fuel on fire, but it's not effective on humans - it penetrates very quickly, so explosion occurs after the bullet explodes. It is however different with mutants - their thick bodies aren't as easily shot-through as humans', so it will often explode inside, causing slightly higher wounds than normal FMJ bullet. Because of possible wound cauterisation, it might not always translate to higher damage, but nevertheless it's very liked by hunters and soldiers defending outposts deep in the Zone.  The 7.92x57 Mauser (also known as 8mm Mauser) round is a full-size rifle cartridge. It was adopted by the German Empire before WWI and stayed the German service cartridge to the fall of the Third Reich. In its day, thanks to it's excellent ballistics the 7.92x57mm Mauser cartridge was one of the worlds most popular military cartridges. In the 21st century it is still a popular sport and hunting cartridge that is factory-produced in Europe and the United States. In Central and Eastern Europe it is currently one of the most common hunting cartridges, together with .308 Winchester and 7.62x54mmR. Quite a number of weapons chambered in this cartridge made it's way to The Zone, mostly various Mauser hunting rifles and surplus Kar98k rifles, and since this ammunition is readily available in gun shops across Europe it's not a surprise it came here with them. A big number of surplus military 7.92x57mm rounds from Balkans also reached The Zone, being readily available to buy. Former Yugoslavia used 7.92x57mm as service cartridge and huge stockpiles of this ammunition reached the black market after it's downfall. Stalkers like 7.92x57 ammunition for it's power and reliability, with the only drawback being lower availability of specialized types of ammo, which can usually be quite expensive.

 The 7.92x33mm Kurz is an intermediate cartridge developed in Nazi Germany prior to and during World War II. It was specifically intended for development of an assault rifle, later known as Sturmgewehr 44. The round was developed as a compromise between the longer 7.92x57mm rifle and the 9x19mm Parabellum pistol rounds, and is known as an intermediate cartridge. Only a few weapons used this cartridge and only one - the beforementioned StG 44 - gained popularity. Former Yugoslavia used StG44 rifles and the 7.92x33mm was used as service cartridge, and huge stockpiles of this ammunition reached the black market after it's downfall. As the StG 44 rifles appeared in The Zone through black market connections, so did it's ammunition, and since it's effective and easy to manufacture it became relatively easy to find around.

 The 7.92x33mm Kurz is an intermediate cartridge developed in Nazi Germany prior to and during World War II. It was specifically intended for development of an assault rifle, later known as Sturmgewehr 44. The round was developed as a compromise between the longer 7.92x57mm rifle and the 9x19mm Parabellum pistol rounds, and is known as an intermediate cartridge. Only a few weapons used this cartridge and only one - the beforementioned StG 44 - gained popularity. Former Yugoslavia used StG44 rifles and the 7.92x33mm was used as service cartridge, and huge stockpiles of this ammunition reached the black market after it's downfall. As the StG 44 rifles appeared in The Zone through black market connections, so did it's ammunition, and since it's effective and easy to manufacture it became relatively easy to find around. This variant has a commercial hollow-point bullet, which increases wounding capabilities through expanding for the cost of penetration.

%c[0,170,170,170]PSO (for Pritsel Snaipersky Optichesky, "Optical Sniper Sight") is a series of Soviet-made optical scopes produced by Novosibirsk Instrument-Making Plant (NPZ Optics State Plant). In common use since 1964 when it was introduced as a standard issue telescopic sight for SVD sniper rifle. Recognized for its durability, versatility and very well-designed reticle pattern featuring convenient range-finder scale. This particular type has 4x magnification rate, making it usable mainly for combat at long ranges. It is attached to weapons by means of a dovetail mount, which is standard in Warsaw Pact countries.

%c[0,170,170,170]PSO (for Pritsel Snaipersky Optichesky, "Optical Sniper Sight") is a series of Soviet-made optical scopes produced by Novosibirsk Instrument-Making Plant (NPZ Optics State Plant). In wide use since 1964 where it was introduced as a standard issue telescopic sight for SVD sniper rifle. Recognized for its durability, versatility and very well-designed reticle pattern featuring convenient range-finder scale. This particular type has been equipped with medium-range heat sensor and 4x magnification rate, and was mainly designed for use by Spetsnaz units. It is attached to weapons by means of a dovetail mount.

%c[0,170,170,170]PSO (for Pritsel Snaipersky Optichesky, "Optical Sniper Sight") is a series of Soviet-made optical scopes produced by Novosibirsk Instrument-Making Plant (NPZ Optics State Plant). In wide use since 1964 where it was introduced as a standard issue telescopic sight for SVD sniper rifle. The scope has been later adapted to assault rifles such as AK-74 or AN-94. Recognized for its durability, versatility and very well-designed reticle pattern featuring convenient range-finder scale. This particular type has been equipped with self-sustaining third generation night vision device and 2.6x magnification rate, making it ideal for close to medium range combat in low-light conditions. This variant was mainly designed for use by Spetsnaz units. It is attached to weapons by means of a dovetail mount. The scope's body is very durable, so it might be difficult to salvage batteries without damaging them.

It features an atypical, pylon-shaped reticle which makes the sight usable mostly at short-medium distances due to the fact it can obscure targets at long range. %c[0,170,170,170]Suppressor, silencer (contrary to popular belief, silencer is a technically correct term), sound moderator - all these words mean one thing. It's a long, metal cylinder with internal sound baffles, typically made of rubber, that slow down and cool the escaping propellant gas, which decreases both sound volume and muzzle blast. First device of that type was produced as early as of 1909 by son of famous designer Hiram Maxim, who gave it the trademark name of Maxim Silencer. The silencers took a long time to finally become adapted for military use, but nonetheless after few decades it became slowly adopted in special forces. In recent years silencers also began to be used by armies as a standard issue.
 
%c This device is an advanced suppressor of US design and manufacture, used by military, law enforcement agencies and civilian gun enthusiasts. It consists of steel body filled with four extension chambers, followed by a series of Z-type titanium baffles. The unit almost completely reduces muzzle flash and considerably suppresses sound emitted when firing. It also requires minimum maintenance. Silencers of this and similar types are commonly used on all smallbore Western-made rifles and remain in active service in Western armed forces. It can be used on all weapons of caliber lower than 5.6mm.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Sound suppression: %c[0,170,170,170]medium

%c[0,140,140,140]COMPATIBILITY:

%c An effective sound suppressor for 9x18mm caliber weapons. Straight blowback pistols (.32, .380, 9x18) do not suppress well since the increased rearward pressure speeds up the slide and dumps a bunch of gas out the chamber end of the barrel, so a specially modified PB pistol was made for quiet shooting - however, the sound reduction is still achieved with removable silencer, it's just as quiet as to be useful for assasinations. It is made of steel body containing fine brass mesh. The front of the unit comprises a set of rubber wipes with caliber-sized holes for the bullet to pass through. Normally used for close-combat engagements against lightly-armored enemies.

%c[0,170,170,170]The Recce 5 (MOD 4) is the compact 5.56mm little brother to the Recce 7. It is one of the lightest most durable, accurate, and high performance 5.56mm suppressors on the market. The Recce 5, weighs only 14.5 ounces on it's own and a mere 16.3 ounces as a suppressor system with the included Taper Mount Minimalist Brake. The included Taper Mount ensures minimal and repeatable point of impact shift with only minor weight gain. The Recce 5 achieves out of this world sound performance vs its size. Utilizing our Patented Efficiency baffle technology this compact suppressor drops SPL by 35db on a 14.5" M4 while keeping gas blow-back to normal levels. To increase performance for military users a high efficiency low profile flash suppressor was integrated into the front of the suppressor. This feature reduces flash, providing minimal signature for the user in low light environments.

%c[0,170,170,170]The primary reason for the original M10 finding recognition was its revolutionary sound suppressor designed by Mitchell WerBell III of Sionics. This suppressor had a two-stage design, with the first stage being larger than the second. This uniquely shaped suppressor gave the MAC-10 a very distinctive look. It was also very quiet, to the point that the bolt could be heard cycling, along with the suppressed report of the weapon's discharge; however, only if subsonic rounds were used (standard .45 ACP rounds are subsonic). The suppressor when used with a Nomex cover created a place to hold the firearm with the secondary hand.

Mounted through a miniaturized Nielsen Device, it does not obscure ironsight aiming, remaining perfectly in-line with upper edge of most modern repeatable and automatic pistols. %c Soviet PBS-1 (for Pribor Bezszumnoj Strielby) sound suppressor for caliber 7.62x39 weapons. Although dated, first produced in 1950s, it is extremely effective and is still being produced as a valuable add-on to common AK-47 and AKM rifles. The suppressor is encompassed in alloy-steel cylinder and consists of a gas-exhausting expansion chamber which is followed by eleven compartments divided by ten M-type steel baffles. Originally, the suppressor contained a rubber wipe which has replaced been replaced by a hi-quality polymer counterpart that no longer requires frequent replacement. The only drawback of this silencer is that the sound suppression is not as effective as in more modern designs.

%c This device is a high-bore silencer for use on pistols with caliber of .45 or lower, especially for .45 ACP. This cartridge has subsonic speed by default, so it doesn't require specially designed ammunition for extremely good sound reduction - you can just put on silencer and use it with standard issue ammo, fully suppressing it and retaining it's full power. Because of this, the .45 ACP is often preferred over modern 9x19mm loads when it comes to stealth operations. This suppressor allows to turn every firearm chambered in .45 ACP into a completely silent weapon.

%c[0,170,170,170]This specially designed three-chambered suppressor is not intended to completely silence the SVU rifle since the soldier would not be using subsonic ammunition. Its main purpose is to quiet and diffuse the noise enough to make detection by the enemy difficult. Its special feature is a very effective muzzle break placed on end of silencer, capable of reducing recoil by about 40%. Above capabilities come at the cost of reduced muzzle velocity and thus significantly lower the weapon's damage output.

A modified M203 grenade launcher whose length has been decreased by three inches, and which can be attached to weapons by means of a Picatinny rail. Thanks to a changed mount, this grenade launcher is widely used around the world and can be installed on most currently produced rifles. Although of more modern design, it has almost the same properties as its Soviet counterpart - the GP-25 grenade launcher.

The RGM-40 Kastet (English: Brass knuckles) grenade launcher is a stand-alone version of the Russian GP-30 grenade launcher with a telescoping stock, AK-type pistol-grip and flip-up tangent sights. It is a single-shot muzzle loaded weapon with a self-cocking trigger mechanism and offers a high degree of commonality with the GP-30. It was developed mainly for police use with non-lethal grenades, but it is also popular among soldiers. Standalone grenade launchers are regaining popularity, as those mounted underbarrel are increasing weapon's weight and change balance too much, decreasing practical accuracy and making it uncomfortable to carry them for prolonged time.

%c[0,170,170,170]KSVK is a Russian .50 caliber (12.7x108mm) anti-materiel rifle developed at Degtyarev plant in the late 1990s. It was designed for anti-materiel tasks and counter-sniper duty, as well as for ellimination of enemies in heavy armor or behind thick cover. KSVK is a bullpup configured, manually operated, rotary bolt (or straight-pull, depending on variant) rifle. Ammunition is fed from detachable 5-round box magazines. Heavy barrel is equipped with a massive muzzle brake. KSVK is fitted with standard Russian side-mounted scope rail, and can be fitted with variety of day and night scopes. Folding bipod is attached to a special extender, which runs below the barrel from the receiver, which allows for free floating barrel. Open iron sights on folding bases are installed for backup or emergency purposes. KSVK is said to be a moderately accurate rifle, similar to American Barret M82 rifle. It's advantages are very high power and range, but it is very heavy and unwieldy. KSVK is currently used only by Russian military. Some of these rifles came to The Zone with few of PMC teams, which can hint at least some of the Mercenaries groups in The Zone are linked to Russia's government. It is relatively rare in The Zone, usually used only by mercenaries and Duty groups, who use it to dispatch dangerous mutants from safe distance, as it's powerful rounds can kill any type of mutant.
