%c[0,170,170,170]AN-94 is a Russian rifle designed as a possible successor to AK-74 rifle. It is similar to AK externally but it's action is noticeably different. In 1979 the Soviet military started project Abakan - it was meant to produce a successor to AK-74. One of it's main points was developing a system that would increase practical accuracy by 50-100%. This was achieved in AN-94 by use of recoil delaying mechanism - specially designed gas system instantly moves the bolt back and chambers new cartridge, which allows the weapon to fire two rounds with the rate of fire of 1800 RPM. The next rounds (when firing in longer bursts) are fired in typical cycling rate of about 650 RPM. Because the second round is fired before the force of recoil reaches the shooter or gets to move the weapon's muzzle, those two rounds are fired from exactly same position, which basically guarantees they will hit the exact same spot with high precision. Because of this, the AN-94 was proven to be good at penetrating body armor, since two bullets hit the same spot - the first bullet weakens the armor structure, the second penetrates it. However, all this came with drawbacks such as bad weight balance, complicated action and greatly lowered reliability, which finally killed this project. AN-94 is used only by Russian military and was spotted in conflict zones only few times. Some of AN-94s were withdrawn and they found their place in The Zone - Armament Research Services (ARES) organization report suspects that these rifles were either supplied to Russian-backed PMC groups or found their way to black market after being withdrawn from service.

%c[0,170,170,170]AA-12 (Atchisson Assault) is a modern automatic combat shotgun designed in 1970s for close quarters combat in urban areas and jungles. It shoots in fully automatic mode, but low cyclic rate of 300RPM allows single rounds to be fired by one short trigger pull. It is a very unique weapon mechanically, using gas operated action with locked breech. The system greatly reduces felt recoil - shotguns often have very high recoil, but the AA-12 gas system absorbs great part of the recoil force, so the shooter doesn't feel the violent kick. The shotgun was made from stainless steel and the clearance is kept between the moving parts, which provides improved durability of parts and reliability of mechanism. AA-12 is only used by law enforcement agencies and the US Marines. Only test series were made, since the heavy automatic shotgun is overally quite a niche weapon. Few of these shotguns were carried by guards of UN scientific expedition that perished in deep parts of The Zone some time ago - after they were found, their weapons were sold on black market. Almost all of these examples of AA-12 were bought by Duty and are sometimes effectively used in anti-mutant operations due to their tremendous firepower.

%c[0,170,170,170]AAC Honey Badger is an integrally suppressed personal defense weapon based on the AR-15, chambered in .300 Blackout. It was designed as a weapon that would be a competitor to famous integrally suppressed MP5SD submachine gun. This weapon was designed for military - Honey Badger has exactly same controls as other AR-15 variants, eg. M4A1, so the soldiers trained on these weapons can quickly adapt to it, additionally, it's weight and length is similar to that of MP5. It uses a modern .300 BLK cartridge (7.62x35mm), which has similar ballistics to the famous Soviet 7.62x39mm cartridge used in AKM, but performs much better at subsonic speeds, similarly to 9x39mm rounds - thanks to this, it is way better at stealth operations than typical carbine chambered in 5.56x45mm round or 7.62x39mm AK. Mechanically, it is just like any other AR-15 - is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. It is less reliable than comparable designs when dirty, but the closed system very effectively seals it from the outside, which prevents any dirt and mud from preventing the internals - this means that the AR-15s are less prone to external elements than eg. AKM. It is built on a standard M4 upper and lower receiver, a short barrel with a fast rate of rifling twist, integrated customized suppressor, and a proprietary buffer tube and collapsible stock featuring two prongs. It is an effective stealth weapon, but it is also liked for it's light weight, compact size and the .300BLK chambering which is more powerful than 5.56x45mm round.

%c[0,170,170,170]AEK-919K Kashtan (Russian: "Chestnut") was developed in Russia in 1990s based on Austrian Steyr MPi 69 submachine gun. The design was not perfect from the beggining and required multiple fixes. After it was polished, it was accepted into service with Russian army and law enforcement agencies, where it's considered to be a solid weapon. It's built in a compact SMG layout, with the magazine well being placed in the pistol grip, like Sa vz.26, PM wz.63 or Uzi SMGs. The receiver is made of stamped metal and the frame is made of polymer. Mechanically it's a select fire, blowback operated firearm which fires from the open bolt, which lowers overheating but also usually decreases accuracy, however the AEK-919K is said to be a relatively accurate weapon. It's distinctive features are the retractable stock and barrel with polygonal rifling and muzzle threading, which allows quick attachment of sound silencer. It's a small and handy weapon, similar in it's layout to famous Mini Uzi. It's size and ergonomics make it fit for use as a PDW or a sidearm.

%c[0,170,170,170]Ak 5C is a shortened, carbine variant of Bofors Ak5 - a modernized Swedish variant of Belgian assault rifle chambered in 5.56x45mm, the FN FNC. It was specially modified to work in harsh, subarctic climate and is a service rifle in Swedish Armed Forces, where it replaced Ak4 - the HK G3 variant produced on licence. The FNC is a Belgian assault rifle chambered in 5.56x45mm. It was developed as a successor to the venerable FN FAL which was chambered in more powerful 7.62x51mm round, since the weaker, but more controllable 5.56x45mm ammunition became the primary round of NATO forces. While visually FNC is similar to the FAL rifle, mechanically it works somewhat differently. It uses a gas-operated long-stroke piston system and a rotating bolt locking mechanism, similar to the AK rifle. Upper receiver is made of stamped steel and lower receiver is made of aluminum alloy to save weight. Among it's strong sides are it's reliability, durability, relatively good ergonomics and effective flash hider mounted by default. Good sights layout provides long sight line, increasing the practical accuracy. Swedes made quite a number of changes to FNC design. Ak5 has a larger trigger guard and cocking handle to allow for operation while wearing winter gloves, an enlarged handguard, a new, collapsible shoulder stock, different iron sights and gas block, a modified bolt, removal of the 3-round burst capability, and a corrosion-resistant green (instead of black) finish. Only a few of these rifles reached The Zone via the black market, where they are known as solid weapons that will never let it's user down.

%c[0,170,170,170]AEK-971 is a modern Russian assault rifle chambered in 5.45x39mm. It took part in tests that were intended to unveil successor to AK-74 rifle, where AN-94 was deemed most succesful. However, later AN-94 was ditched and Russia again started to see potential in AEK-971. The biggest advantage AEK-971 has over AK-74 is the "Balanced Automatic Recoil System" (BARS), which uses special set of counterweights that greatly reduce felt recoil and muzzle climb of the weapon, making it extremely efficient when shooting even long bursts. It is considered one of the most advanced assault rifles at the moment, which has a reflection in it's price. The AEK-971 assault rifle was originally designed and tested during "Abakan" trials of late 1980s, where AN-94 won against it, and the AEK was shelved for some time. In 2013 a new version of AEK-971, the A-545, entered Ratnik trials alongside AK-12, where it shown great potential as it outperformed AK-12 on ranges up to 300 meters and in burst accuracy. The AEK-971's greatest advantage is so-called "balanced recoil system", which is a system of buffers which reduce felt recoil greatly by work of counterbalances. The synchronous and opposite movement of the balancing weight eliminates most recoil force except the recoil impulse, so the rifle becomes more stable during fully automatic fire. It's disadvantage however is greatly increased cost and slightly lowered reliability.

%c[0,170,170,170]AK-12 is the latest modern variant of Kalashnikov's rifle, chambered in 5.45x39mm cartridge and designed as a modular rifle that would be as easy to customise and reequip for different missions as service rifles of western countries, most notably the AR-15 variants. It is basically a modern AK-74 but significantly redesigned to fit today's needs, with changes to body shape, used materials, new sights with longer sightline and RIS rails mounted by default on handguards and receiver that allow to mount modern equipment without the need for additional changes. It is currently being tested, and is meant to be introduced to Russian military where it's intended to replace AK-74M rifles. Some of older prototypes were reportedly "stolen" and it was confirmed that they found their way into hands of at least one Mercenary group. Other theory says that at least some detachments of Mercenaries are working closely with Russian government and part of them received these rifles as part of financing in return for their feedback as a less-conventional type of field testing. Mechanically it is based on older AK rifles; it's a gas operated, selective fire assault rifle. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud.

%c[0,170,170,170]The wz.88 Tantal is a Polish 5.45x39mm assault rifle developed in the late 1980s and produced in famous weapons factory in Radom (FB Radom). It's basically an equivalent of Soviet AK-74 rifle with some minor differences, most notably the slightly higher rate of fire, three-round burst fire mode and folding stock mounted by standard. Use of new, smaller cartridge increases accuracy and range and makes it much easier to take follow up shots with it, which increases the chances of hitting - all this while retaining durability and reliability of other AK rifles. Tantal (Tantalum - Polish weapons and military equipment receive names of chemical elements) is widely considered to be an AK-74 variant, however it's base weapon was Polish modification of AKMS called wz.80 that has been rechambered to 5.45x39mm using AK-74 system as an example. Because of that, it has higher degree of parts interchangeability with AKM than AK-74 and is closer to it mechanically. Development of the new rifle chambered in 5.45mm caliber started officially in 1984 and by 1986 first prototypes were produced. The rifle was modernized and some faults were corrected(among the changes made, a series of components were introduced that were meant to be interchangeable with the AK-74, including the bolt carrier, bolt, magazines and the burst fire mode was further refined) and in 1989 the rifle entered mass production. It was well liked by soldiers and is considered by some to be even better than AK-74. Among it's downsides are heavier weight and less durable stock type, but it's a still a very reliable and accurate rifle. Mechanically it is just like AKM; it's a gas operated, selective fire weapon. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud.

%c[0,170,170,170]AK-74 is a Soviet 5.45x39mm assault rifle that was designed in early 1970s as an answer to new US M16 rifle shooting new type of ammunition. Use of new, smaller cartridge increases accuracy and range and makes it much easier to take follow up shots with it, which increases the chances of hitting - all this while retaining durability and reliability of other AK rifles. AK-74 and it's variants still stay as service rifle of Ukrainian military and is one of the most popular weapons in The Zone due to it's reliability, accuracy, low price and readily available ammunition. Mechanically, it's a gas operated, selective fire assault rifle. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud. Overengineered receiver and chrome lined barrel provide exceptional durability, and the well-designed cartridge dimensions and strong action allow for reliable feeding in almost all conditions, even when the weapon is very dirty and/or corroded. Among main features of AK-74 are the chambering in lighter and more accurate 5.45x39mm round and a new muzzle device, which further reduces the recoil, muzzle climb and the flash from firing. Furniture is slightly redesigned from AKM, early AK-74s used plywood furniture like AKM but big amount was also produced with dark-plum coloured polymer stock and handguards, which is more resistant to wear and slightly lighter than plywood. AK-74 and it's variants stay in service in more than 20 countries. AK-74 also still stays as service rifle of Ukrainian military and is one of the most popular weapons in The Zone due to it's reliability, accuracy, low price and readily available ammunition. Lots of these rifles were stolen from military warehouses or bought off from corrupt military officials, in result, the AK-74 is the most common rifle in The Zone.

%c[0,170,170,170]AK-74M is a modernized variant of AK-74, a Soviet 5.45x39mm assault rifle that was designed in early 1970s as an answer to new US M16 rifle shooting new type of ammunition. Use of new, smaller cartridge increases accuracy and range and makes it much easier to take follow up shots with it, which increases the chances of hitting - all this while retaining durability and reliability of other AK rifles. AK-74 and it's variants still stay as service rifle of Ukrainian military and is one of the most popular weapons in The Zone due to it's reliability, accuracy, low price and readily available ammunition. Mechanically, it's a gas operated, selective fire assault rifle. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud. Overengineered receiver and chrome lined barrel provide exceptional durability, and the well-designed cartridge dimensions and strong action allow for reliable feeding in almost all conditions, even when the weapon is very dirty and/or corroded. Among main features of AK-74 are the chambering in lighter and more accurate 5.45x39mm round and a new muzzle device, which further reduces the recoil, muzzle climb and the flash from firing. AK-74M differs from AK-74 with folding stock mounted by default (shaped just like fixed polymer stock), new black-coloured polymer instead of wood or plum polymer and strengthened receiver. The outcome is slightly improved ergonomics, accuracy and reliability, but it comes for the price of heavier weight. Apart from these changes, AK-74M is basically identical to AK-74. AK-74M is a service rifle of Russian army. Some of these rifles came with few of Mercenaries teams, which can hint at least some of the Mercenaries groups in The Zone are linked to Russia's government. They are considered to be better than older AK-74 rifles, but their prices are relatively high and some Stalkers prefer to buy a modern western-type weapon instead, or just stay with older AK.

%c[0,170,170,170]AK-101 is a variant of AK-74M rifle chambered for more popular 5.56x45mm NATO cartridge and intended for export. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud. Overengineered receiver and chrome lined barrel provide exceptional durability, and the well-designed cartridge dimensions and strong action allow for reliable feeding in almost all conditions, even when the weapon is very dirty and/or corroded. AK-101 is chambered for 5.56x45mm NATO cartridge, which is slightly more powerful. Apart from different chambering it is identical to AK-74M, which is a modernized variant of AK-74 rifle. Among differences there is folding stock mounted by default (shaped just like fixed polymer stock), new black-coloured polymer instead of wood or plum polymer and strengthened receiver. The outcome is slightly improved ergonomics, accuracy and reliability, but it comes for the price of heavier weight. Apart from these changes, AK-74M is basically identical to AK-74. Some of these rifles came with few of Mercenaries teams, which can hint at least some of the Mercenaries groups in The Zone are linked to Russia's government. They are considered to be better than older AK-74 rifles, but their prices are relatively high and some Stalkers prefer to buy a modern western-type weapon instead, or just stay with older AK.

%c[0,170,170,170]AK-9 is a compact assault rifle chambered in 9x39mm cartridge and developed as a competitor to SR-3M and 9A91 assault rifles. It is a part of "hundred-series-AKs" and shares it's features with other rifles of this family, such as AK-105, but has roughly same dimensions as AKS-74u. It was first shown in the year 2006 but the project was frozen for long time, only recently, in 2013, Kalashnikov Concern started working on AK-9 again, modernizing existing prototypes. It is yet unknown what changes will new prototype feature. Only few of these weapons reached The Zone through black market and it is not known if they have been actually sold or stolen from the army warehouses. It is intended to be used with a suppressor fitted by default, but it can function reliably without silencer too, just like SR-3M or 9A91 rifles. Mechanically it is just like AKM; it's a gas operated, selective fire assault rifle. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud.

%c[0,170,170,170]AK-102 is a carbine variant of AK-101 rifle, sporting a 314mm (12.4") barrel. It's not as short as older AKS-74u carbine, but it is still lighter and more maneuverable than longer AK rifles, however because of short barrel it still loses some of muzzle velocity, and therefore range. Apart from these changes, it is identical to AK-74M and AK-101, which are very similar to AK-74 - a Soviet 5.45x39mm assault rifle that was designed in early 1970s as an answer to new US M16 rifle shooting new type of ammunition. Use of new, smaller cartridge increases accuracy and range and makes it much easier to take follow up shots with it, which increases the chances of hitting - all this while retaining durability and reliability of other AK rifles. Among main features of AK-74 are the chambering in 5.45x39mm round, which increases accuracy and range and makes it much easier to take follow up shots with it, which increases the chances of hitting and a new muzzle device, which further reduces the recoil, muzzle climb and the flash from firing. Mechanically it is just like AKM; it's a gas operated, selective fire assault rifle. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud. AK-102 is produced for export to countries using AK-101. Some of these rifles came with few of Mercenaries teams, which can hint at least some of the Mercenaries groups in The Zone are linked to Russia's government. They are considered to be better than older AK-74 rifles, but their prices are relatively high and some Stalkers prefer to buy a modern western-type weapon instead, or just stay with older AK.

%c[0,170,170,170]AK-103 is a variant of AK-74M rifle chambered for older, but more powerful 7.62x39mm cartridge and intended mainly for export, but also used in special forces and internal affairs or counter-terrorist groups. Apart from different chambering it is identical to AK-74M, which is a modernized variant of AK-74 rifle - a Soviet rifle that was designed in early 1970s as an answer to new US M16 rifle shooting new type of ammunition. Use of new, smaller cartridge increases accuracy and range and makes it much easier to take follow up shots with it, which increases the chances of hitting - all this while retaining durability and reliability of other AK rifles. Among main features of AK-103 are the chambering in 7.62x39mm round, which provides higher wounding and penetration capabilities and a new muzzle device, which further reduces the recoil, muzzle climb and the flash from firing. Mechanically it is just like AKM; it's a gas operated, selective fire assault rifle. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud. AK-103 is designed for export to countries preferring 7.62x39mm caliber. Some of these rifles came with few of Mercenaries teams, which can hint at least some of the Mercenaries groups in The Zone are linked to Russia's government. They are considered to be better than older AKM rifles, but their prices are relatively high and some Stalkers prefer to buy a modern western-type weapon instead, or just stay with older AK.

%c[0,170,170,170]AK-104 is a carbine variant of AK-103 rifle, sporting a 314mm (12.4") barrel. It is lighter and more maneuverable than longer AK-103 or AKM rifles, and 7.62x39mm cartridge doesn't lose much velocity when shot from even very short barrels, which means it has similar range and wounding potential as longer AK-103, the only downside being shorter sight line, which reduces practical accuracy. Apart from shorter barrel it is identical to AK-103, which is a variant of AK-74M rifle rechambered in 7.62x39mm. Among differences there is folding stock monted by default (shaped just like fixed polymer stock), new black-coloured polymer instead of wood or plum polymer and strenghened receiver. The outcome is slightly improved ergonomics, accuracy and reliability, but it comes for the price of heavier weight. Apart from these changes, AK-74M is basically identical to AK-74. AK-74M is a service rifle of Russian army. Some of these rifles came with few of Mercenaries teams, which can hint at least some of the Mercenaries groups in The Zone are linked to Russia's government. They are considered to be better than older AK-74/AKM rifles, but their prices are relatively high and some Stalkers prefer to buy a modern western-type weapon instead, or just stay with older AK.

%c[0,170,170,170]AK-105 is a carbine variant of AK-74M rifle, sporting a 314mm (12.4") barrel. It's not as short as older AKS-74u carbine, but it is still lighter and more maneuverable than longer AK rifles, however because of short barrel it still loses some of muzzle velocity, and therefore range. Apart from these changes, it is identical to AK-74M, a modernized variant of AK-74, a Soviet 5.45x39mm assault rifle that was designed in early 1970s as an answer to new US M16 rifle shooting new type of ammunition. Use of new, smaller cartridge increases accuracy and range and makes it much easier to take follow up shots with it, which increases the chances of hitting - all this while retaining durability and reliability of other AK rifles. Mechanically, it's a gas operated, selective fire assault rifle. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud. Overengineered receiver and chrome lined barrel provide exceptional durability, and the well-designed cartridge dimensions and strong action allow for reliable feeding in almost all conditions, even when the weapon is very dirty and/or corroded. AK-74M differs from AK-74 with folding stock mounted by default (shaped just like fixed polymer stock), new black-coloured polymer instead of wood or plum polymer and strengthened receiver. AK-105 is a service carbine of Russian army. Some of these rifles came with few of Mercenaries teams, which can hint at least some of the Mercenaries groups in The Zone are linked to Russia's government. They are considered to be better than older AKS-74 and AKS-74u carbines, but their prices are relatively high and some Stalkers prefer to buy a modern western-type weapon instead, or just stay with older AK.

%c[0,170,170,170]AMD-65 is a Hungarian carbine variant of AKM rifle, modified for use by paratroopers and vehicle crews. It has a folding stock, shorter barrel and redesigned handguard, which makes it more compact than standard AK variants, however, it's shorter sight radius lowers practical accuracy. AMD-65 was designed as a short AK variant, more handy to paratroopers and vehicle crews, who needed a weapon that provided good firepower but was easy to store in confined spaces. It sports a side folding stock of distinctive look and a shorter, 317mm (12.6") barrel, similar in lenght to that of the modern AK-105 rifle. Mechanically, the AMD-65 is just like AKM; it's a gas operated, selective fire weapon. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud. There are however a lot of changes to the weapon, not all of them good. It has special muzzle device that lowers the recoil considerably, but the redirection of gasses to the sides makes it deafeningly loud for the people standing beside the shooter. It doesn't have a wooden handguard and has a plastic front grip instead, which in theory should make it easier to control during fully automatic fire. Lack of wooden handguards helps with overheating, but also doesn't protect shooters' hand from hot barrel, which can cause accidental burns. It can use all types of AK magazines, but had special 20-round mags designed specially for use inside vehicles. AMD-65 was used in Hungarian army and was also exported to Middle East. Small batch of these rifles reached The Zone and can be bought for cheap on black market.

%c[0,170,170,170]ASh-12 is a Russian big-bore assault rifle adopted to counter-terrorist units in 2011. It uses a powerful 12.7x55mm ammunition (similar to the one of VSSK sniper rifle, but with different dimensions of bullet, so these two rounds are not interchangeable), which contains a heavy bullet that can penetrate even heaviest body armor, walls or metal plates and still deal significant tissue damage upon impact after penetration, maximizing chance of critical hit and disabling the enemy with the first shot. These rifles are employed only by Russian FSB in situations involving high risk to operators, where disabling the threat on the first hit is needed. Bringing down a human opponent requires either critical damage to nervous system or causing such a heavy blood loss that the subject passes out. To achieve this, ASh-12's ammunition, which already has high diameter, expands violently in tissue, causing severe damage to internal organs and extreme haemorrhaging - no other weapon of this type can match this kind of power. In tactical sense, the ASh-12 is an up-scaled version of AS Val - 9x39mm rifles were made with similar applications in mind (heavy, subsonic bullet with high penetration capabilities and good terminal ballistics). Mechanically Some of these rifles came to The Zone from yet unknown source (rumors say some of Mercenaries groups are maintaining close cooperation with Russian government agencies) and have been used by mutant hunters squads, most notably Duty detachments. These rifles are said to be very effective on close range, but their low-velocity bullets make them less useful on ranges exceeding 150 meters.

%c[0,170,170,170]Beretta 93R, also known as Raffica (Italian: "Burst") is a selective-fire machine pistol chambered in 9x19mm and developed in the late 1970s. It is basically a heavily redesigned Beretta 92, which is a short-recoil operated, locked-breech firearm with an aluminum frame. It uses the same base and system, but has different trigger (SA only) and has a fire selector with semi and burst mode, in which it fires three rounds with cyclic rate of 1100RPM. It has a crude vertical grip and a ported barrel to reduce muzzle climb, however it is still considered to be hard to control in burst fire mode. Very high rate of fire also means that it is more prone to jamming and stoppages. It was used in limited numbers of Italian counter-terrorists, Carabinieri, police and paramilitary forces as a PDW. Some of these weapons reached the black market in The Zone, where they are considered a cheap alternative to more modern machine pistols.

%c[0,170,170,170]Bizon is a Russian submachine gun of an unique construction. It was based on AKS-74u compact assault rifle and shares it's ergonomics, but uses a distinct helical magazine. It's chambered in relatively weak pistol cartridge, so it doesn't have range or power of assault rifles, but it uses high capacity magazine which can hold up to 64 9x18mm rounds. It was designed for counter-terrorist and law enforcement agencies, based on the AKS-74 assault rifle. It shares AK's external look and ergonomics, but uses a helical magazine similar to the one used by Calico SMG, which was a technical failure. The Bizon itself however performed well during the test and in 1996 became adopted by FSB. While Bizon looks and handles similar to AK, it uses different system. It is a straight blowback action weapon, with unlocked breech system, firing from closed bolt, which improves accuracy. Since the Bizon works on straight blowback principle, it has no gas system, therefore internals were modified accordingly - the piston rod and rotary bolt were removed and piston extension was plugged with steel insert. Overally, the PP-19 Bizon is a solid and effective weapon with some really well thought out solutions. It's low popularity comes probably from it's awkward appearance and the fact that 9x18mm ammunition is considered obsolete. In The Zone it is sometimes used as a light CQB weapon together with other submachine guns like Vityaz or MP5. However, due to it's less powerful cartridge and questionable reliability of helical magazine it never received as much appreciation as the former weapons.

%c[0,170,170,170]Borz (Chechen: "Wolf") is a homemade submachine gun chambered in 9x18mm. It was designed in Armenia, where it was produced for guerrilla fighters in underground workshops that did not have specialist equipment. Submachine guns are the weapons that are easiest to manufacture thanks to their simple construction. Mechanically, it is a simple blowback operated weapon that fires from open bolt. Receiver is made from steel stampings crudely welded together. It has very low accuracy and as a cheap, disposable weapon it can withstand only limited amount of shots. Plans for these weapons were gained by Zone technicians who make these weapons from scrap metal for stalkers who can't afford a serially produced automatic weapon.

%c[0,170,170,170]Saab CBJ-MS PDW is a Swedish submachine gun designed for personal defence weapon (PDW) role. It is a small and compact submachine gun of modular construction that can be chambered in 9x19mm and 6.5x25mm CBJ ammunition, which works similarly to other PDW cartridges like 5.7x28mm FN and 4.6x30mm HK. It is a blowback-operated, selective fire submachine gun which is based on the Israeli Uzi submachine gun. It fires from open bolt in standard configuration, but an alternative bolt system with separate firing pin can be installed for firing from closed bolt (for higher first-shot accuracy). Among it's features is unusual equipment for an SMG such as a bipod, 100-round magazine, frontal grip which can also act like spare magazine housing and an optics rail. Parts are made from stamped steel which was acid treated for improved resistance to rust and wear. The CBJ is relatively lightweight at 2.8kg, but compared to modern PDWs with polymer parts it is heavies of them all. In The Zone the CBJ is very rare, only a few came with Mercenary squads who use these weapons as sidearms to improve their firepower.

%c[0,170,170,170]CZ-75 is a semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x19mm Parabellum round, produced by famous Czech gun manufacturer, the Ceska Zbrojovka. It was one of the first "wonder nines" - modern steel-frame pistols featuring double-stack magazine, a huge advantage over revolvers and older pistols, which usually had 7 or 8 rounds in single-stack magazine. Mechanically it's a short recoil operated, locked breech pistol using the Browning locking system. The slide and frame are made of steel, it has an SA/DA trigger and manual safety. High quality barrel is hammer forged. The CZ-75 became a great hit and is widely considered one of the best steel-frame pistols ever made. It's strong sides are good accuracy, crisp trigger, high reliability and an ability to carry it safely in condition 1 - "cocked and locked" (with a round in a chamber, the hammer cocked, safety engaged); which made it a good weapon for concealed carry. It's disadvantage is mostly relatively heavy weight and lower ergonomics that those of more modern polymer-frame pistols. Second-generation variant, the CZ-75B, had a redesigned trigger guard and upgraded internal parts, most notably the firing pin. High accuracy made it very popular as a pistol for competitive shooting and a lot of top shooters in Europe use CZ-75s customized for accuracy. From 1989 the CZ-75 is standard pistol of Czech military, it is also used by more than 20 countries' military and law enforcement forces. More than a million of these pistols were manufactured. CZ-75 is currently the most popular 9x19mm pistol in Central and Eastern Europe, together with Glock 17. Because of this, it is one of the most commonly seen handguns in The Zone, where it can be bought for cheap. Stalkers like it for it's reliability, good price and chambering in 9x19mm rounds, which is an upgrade from 9x18mm pistols that are most commonly found in The Zone.

%c[0,170,170,170]CZ-52 is a semi-automatic pistol chambered in 7.62x25mm TT round, designed and produced in 1952 by famous then-Czechoslovak gun manufacturer, the Ceska Zbrojovka. It was first designed for 9x19mm Parabellum, but then, due to political pressures from USSR, was redesigned for 7.62x25mm round, which was used back then as standard pistol ammunition in USSR and countries of communist bloc (known later as Warsaw Pact countries). Mechanically it's a roller-locked, short-recoil operated pistol of unusual construction - the roller-locking system is taken from the famous German MG-42 machine gun. The CZ-52 was specially designed to withstand powerful overpressure 7.62x25mm ammunition used in Czech submachine gun, most notably the Sa vz.26. This ammunition was more than 25% more powerful and could damage pistols designed for standard-pressure ammunition, that's why the roller system was used and the pistol itself was overbuilt. However, the slides and pins were not produced with high quality and they sometimes cracked when using these overpressure loads, so even thought it was reinforced, the low quality control made these pistols a failure in these terms, as it did not withstand pressures it was designed for. Nonetheless, the CZ-52 is working fine when using standard 7.62x25mm loads. It is heavy and rather awkward, but works reliably and can do it's job. About 200 000 of these pistols were produced for Czechoslovak military. Some of them reached The Zone via the black market and are available there for very cheap, which makes them a viable choice for those stalkers who rarely use their sidearm and don't mind it's flaws.

%c[0,170,170,170]CZ 805 BREN is a Czech modular assault rifle offered in 5.56x45mm NATO, 7.62x39mm M43 and 6.8x43mm SPC chambering. It was developed in 2009 and was accepted as a successor to the Sa vz.58 rifle in Czech military. It has modern aesthetics and ergonomic design, similar to that of FN SCAR rifle, however, the weapon itself is not a SCAR clone, but an indigenous Czech construction. The BREN uses a short-stroke piston operated gas action with rotating bolt. It has a manual gas regulator which allows to adjust the action to conditions of harsh environment. The upper receiver is aluminum and lower receiver is polymer, which saves weight. One of it's outstanding features is quick-detachable barrel, which allows not only for switching overheated barrels but also to adjust the weapon for the mission by changing barrel lengths or calibers - the BREN is a modular weapon and by switching barrel and magazine well unit it can be rechambered from 5.56x45 NATO to 7.62x39mm or 6.8 SPC, similarly to weapons like Magpul ACR. The BREN also has other must-have features of modern assault rifle, such as mounting rails on whole rifle's length, adjustable, side-folding stock, ambidextrous charging handle (it can be mounted on both sides) and ability to mount various optical sights, grenade launchers and other advanced equipment. Overally, CZ 805 is one of the most advanced weapons currently available, even though it has it's flaws, that were however fixed in newest variant. It's relatively expensive, but it's high reliability, modularity and ergonomics are well worth it. BREN was adopted by multiple countries. Currently an improved variant, the BREN 2 is produced and is service rifle of Czech military. Some of these rifles reached The Zone, mainly used by PMCs and sold by arms smugglers, and are very valued by stalkers of all factions as one of the best rifles available.

The BREN also has other must-have features of modern assault rifle, such as mounting rails on whole rifle's length, adjustable, side-folding stock, ambidextrous charging handle (it can be mounted on both sides) and ability to mount various optical sights, grenade launchers and other advanced equipment. %c[0,170,170,170]Duplet is an improvised double-barreled shotgun manufactured by technicians in workshops near and in The Zone. It was produced by first stalkers in The Zone, since the black market of firearms was almost non-existent back then. Currently the Duplets are increasingly less common as more weaponry is available for cheap from traders and arms smugglers. It is a simple, crude firearm made from reinforced scrap metal and wood, with two barrels placed horizontally. The accuracy is low due to crude finish of the inside of the barrel, but it's not an issue since the gun is made for point-blank ranges. Two barrels hold one shell each and can be fired both in the same time. Since the weapon is manually operated, it works relatively reliably - the only issue can be misfires, but nonetheless they don't happen as often as jams in semi-automatic improvised weapons (like Borz or homemade pistols). The spread is very wide. The weapon features a stock that is mounted with a spring, which slightly reduces felt recoil, but also lowers the stability. The durability is very low and as with every improvised firearm, adequate safety precautions should be retained, as there's always a risk of catastrophic failure, which can injure the shooter. These weapons are sold for cheap and are the last ditch protection for those who can't spare more for a real weapon. Duplet can also be used as a cheap sidearm for those who want to buy a more expensive rifle or other primary weapon, but still want something as a backup.

%c[0,170,170,170]QBZ-95 is a Chinese bullpup assault rifle family which includes assault rifles, carbines and light machine guns chambered in various cartridges. One of them is QBZ-97, which is a variant chambered in 5.56x45mm NATO round and intended for export. Not much is known about this rifle and it's performance. It was developed in 1991 and in 1995 it entered production. Mechanically, it's a gas operated firearm featuring a short-stroke gas piston and a rotating bolt system. The housing is made of polymer which saves weight. Bullpup configuration makes it shorter and more handy, however the balance of the rifle is not as good as in modern bullpup rifles. It also has no rails for additional attachments. Officially these weapons are not sold to the west anymore, but some were reported to be seen in Middle East, and a small batch reached The Zone, probably with one of PMC groups. More information is unavailable.

%c[0,170,170,170]FN 1906, also called FN Baby, is a semi-automatic centerfire pocket pistol designed by famous genius gun designer John M. Browning (who also designed such famous weapons like M1911 pistol, Auto-5 shotgun, BAR, M1917, M1919 and M2 .50cal machine guns) and was manufactured by FN in Belgium and produced from 1906 to 1959. It featured a simple blowback action. FN 1906 used very small cartridge, with dimensions of 6.35x18mm. While the .22LR is roughly as effective, it is very prone to misfires and jamming and as such the 6.35x18mm is much more effective load for defensive weapon. The bullet has weak terminal ballistics, but is also very small, just like the pistol itself - it can be hid in pocket of a shirt, and on a point-blank range it can be enough to kill. FN Baby and other pocket pistols were very popular in 1920s and 1930s as they could be purchased without license back then. Millions of pistols of this type were produced and lots of them are still hidden in basements or attics of houses all around Eastern Europe - some of them were brought by stalkers into The Zone. Some of them did this because they didn't have anything better and quickly got rid of them after buying or finding better weapon, but some stalkers also use it as a backup weapon - apart from a full-size handgun in a holster, they also keep these pistols in their pockets or ankle holsters, ready to use in dire situations.

%c[0,170,170,170]FN Five-seveN is a modern semi-automatic pistol designed and manufactured by FN in Belgium. It was developed specially for new 5.7x28mm FN cartridge, which was designed as a high-velocity round which has penetration capabilities of a rifle. The production started in 1998 and first users adopted it in the year 2000; in 2013 it became a service pistol of Belgian Army (modernized Mk2 version). It was adopted by multiple law enforcement and military organizations all around the world. It is a modern, polymer-framed pistol, even slide is polymer-encased to reduce weight. It has a striker-fired trigger and is using a delayed blowback action. The magazine holds 20 rounds. Despite it's very light weight the Five-seveN has very low recoil, which improves accuracy in rapid fire. It's advantages are high capacity, good controllability and weight, which is lower than all other polymer pistols. It's disadvantages are it's high price and unsatisfactory terminal ballistics when it comes to engaging unarmored targets - in such situations typical pistol rounds tend to be much more effective. The 5.7x28mm rounds however have very good penetration capabilities - FMJ rounds can penetrate bulletproof vests even up to level III and dedicated AP rounds will penetrate level IV body armor - something that 9x19mm rounds can not achieve. Whether it is worth to invest in Five-seveN and trade terminal ballistics for penetration is up to user. Some counter-terrorist forces use these pistols when dealing with attackers in body armor and some mercenary teams in The Zone tend to carry them since most stalkers wear multiple layers of thick protective clothing and standard rounds might have trouble with penetration. Still, these pistols remain expensive and rare and are not as universal as other weapons chambered in more typical calibers.

%c[0,170,170,170]AR-18 is an American assault rifle chambered in 5.56x45mm. It was designed by E. Stoner, designer of the AR-15 rifle. It used completely new gas system which got rid of some of AR-15's problems. Mechanically, AR-18 is a gas operated rifle using a short piston stroke, rotating bolt locking mechanism. The two-part receiver is made from stamped sheet steel, the furniture is made of black polymer. AR-18 has a side-folding stock mounted by default - one of AR-15's problems is that the long buffer tube doesn't allow for usage of folding stock. Barrel's length is 18.25", which gives the 5.56mm bullet high velocity, improving it's terminal performance, as it relies on velocity to yaw and fragment in the tissue. The AR-18 is overally a more rigid and reliable rifle than AR-15, better suited to continuous abuse in the field. While the AR-18 itself wasn't successful and only about 20 000 were produced (compared to dozens of millions of AR-15s), the AR-18 design was very influential and most modern rifles are based on it's design, for example the G36. A lot of AR-18s reached the black market, they were one of the most common weapons of Provisional IRA during The Troubles in Northern Ireland, some were also sold to third world countries. In The Zone some AR-18 came via black market connections too, where they are well liked for their high reliability and good accuracy.

%c[0,170,170,170]The FNC is a Belgian assault rifle chambered in 5.56x45mm. It was developed as a successor to the venerable FN FAL which was chambered in more powerful 7.62x51mm round, since the weaker, but more controllable 5.56x45mm ammunition became the primary round of NATO forces. It became the service rifle of Belgian army in 1989 and around that time also became adopted in multiple other countries, among them Indonesia, Libya and Venezuela. Sweden adopted the FNC in modified configuration, designed for harsh subarctic conditions, and produced them locally on license as Ak5. While visually FNC is similar to the FAL rifle, mechanically it works somewhat differently. It uses a gas-operated long-stroke piston system and a rotating bolt locking mechanism, similar to the AK rifle. Upper receiver is made of stamped steel and lower receiver is made of aluminum alloy to save weight - the FNC weights relatively light at 3.84kg. Among it's strong sides are it's reliability, durability, relatively good ergonomics and effective flash hider mounted by default. Good sights layout provides long sight line, increasing the practical accuracy. FNC became available on the black market in The Zone where it came from Libya. Stalkers like FNC for it's improved accuracy and range, while retaining good reliability even in the hostile environment of The Zone.

%c[0,170,170,170]G3 is a 7.62x51mm battle rifle designed and manufactured by Heckler and Koch in former West Germany in 1950s. In 1956 the West German Border Guards adopted FN FAL rifles as their service weapons. It left great impression and the Germans decided to make their own battle rifle of similar construction and function. HK, together with Spanish CETME, designed their own rifle which was based on StG45 rifle system developed back in the Third Reich - it used roller delayed blowback system instead of gas operated action - something that was not common back then. Mechanically, G3 is a battle rifle of all-steel construction using a roller-delayed blowback action. The weapon was designed to use as much stamped steel parts as possible to reduce the cost. Early G3 rifles also used stamped steel handguards, but they were later changed to polymer ones. It can shoot in fully automatic mode but the heavy recoil of 7.62x51mm round makes it very ineffective; single, well aimed shots should be used instead. Every G3 rifle has diopter sights, fixed or telescopic stock, possibility of mounting a bipod, a bayonet and an optical sight, using a special rail. G3 became a service rifle of Bundeswehr in 1959 and was also adopted by more than 40 countries all around the world (including Sweden, Norway, Portugal and Turkey), and taking part in multiple conflicts where it proven itself as a reliable and effective rifle that can survive a lot of beating despite it's sheet metal construction. It's disadvantages are heavy recoil (the gas system however slightly reduces it compared to other battle rifles) and weight. It was replaced by G36 in the late 1990, but German army still uses it outfitted with scope as a marksman weapon. It was sent to many countries as military aid, including Middle East, where a lot of these rifles hit black market. A high number reached The Zone, where they are valued for powerful round that is very effective vs wild animals and mutants.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]Simplified, but reliable and powerful battle rifle. Relatively high recoil. Should be used with single, well placed shots. High damage per shot. Best on medium and long range. %c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]G3 is a 7.62x51mm battle rifle designed and manufactured by Heckler and Koch in former West Germany in 1950s. In 1956 the West German Border Guards adopted FN FAL rifles as their service weapons. It left great impression and the Germans decided to make their own battle rifle of similar construction and function. HK, together with Spanish CETME, designed their own rifle which was based on StG45 rifle system developed back in the Third Reich - it used roller delayed blowback system instead of gas operated action - something that was not common back then. Mechanically, G3 is a battle rifle of all-steel construction using a roller-delayed blowback action. The weapon was designed to use as much stamped steel parts as possible to reduce the cost. Early G3 rifles also used stamped steel handguards, but they were later changed to polymer ones. It can shoot in fully automatic mode but the heavy recoil of 7.62x51mm round makes it very ineffective; single, well aimed shots should be used instead. Every G3 rifle has diopter sights, fixed or telescopic stock, possibility of mounting a bipod, a bayonet and an optical sight, using a special rail. G3 became a service rifle of Bundeswehr in 1959 and was also adopted by more than 40 countries all around the world (including Sweden, Norway, Portugal and Turkey), and taking part in multiple conflicts where it proven itself as a reliable and effective rifle that can survive a lot of beating despite it's sheet metal construction. It's disadvantages are heavy recoil (the gas system however slightly reduces it compared to other battle rifles) and weight. It was replaced by G36 in the late 1990, but German army still uses it outfitted with scope as a marksman weapon. It was sent to many countries as military aid, including Middle East, where a lot of these rifles hit black market. A high number reached The Zone, where they are valued for powerful round that is very effective vs wild animals and mutants.

%c[0,170,170,170]HK51 is a shortened variant of G3 battle rifle. Contrary to it's name, it was not developed by Heckler and Koch, but Fleming Arms for British Special Forces. The G3 is a 7.62x51mm battle rifle designed and manufactured by Heckler and Koch in former West Germany in 1950s. In 1956 the West German Border Guards adopted FN FAL rifles as their service weapons. It left great impression and the Germans decided to make their own battle rifle of similar construction and function. Mechanically, G3 is a battle rifle of all-steel construction using a roller-delayed blowback action. The weapon was designed to use as much stamped steel parts as possible to reduce the cost. Early G3 rifles also used stamped steel handguards, but they were later changed to polymer ones. The HK51 is just a shortened G3, which improves it's handling but reduces reliability and makes the rifle overheat quicker. Another downside is brighter muzzle flash and louder sound signature together with increased recoil, which is already pretty high due to powerful 7.62x51mm round it uses. The round also loses some of it's muzzle velocity, which lowers it's power. The HK51 got adopted by SAS and SBS, but because of it's faults it was withdrawn quickly after the SAS received HK53 carbines, which used 5.56x45mm rounds that were more suitable for commando-length (~9-12.5" barrel) carbines. HK51 was later introduced into free market in semi-automatic variant, made from HK91 rifles (civilian semi-auto variant of G3). Small amount of these weapons reached black market and appeared in multiple places, including The Zone in Ukraine. Due to it's powerful round it is used as an effective weapon against mutants, as it is light, short and has high rate of fire - it can unload whole magazine of 7.62mm soft-point rounds very quickly, which is important when fighting dangerous mutants in melee range.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]One of the most precise sniper rifles. High quality, clear optics with 6x magnification. Best on medium and long range. %c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]PSG-1 is a precision rifle based on G3 battle rifle. It is designed from the beginning as a police sniper rifle for maximum precision. It boasts very high accuracy, but is also extremely expensive, which finally led to decline of sales. The works on the sniper rifle began after 1972 Munich massacre, which shown weaknesses of counter-terrorist forces back then. The Germans needed a semi-automatic rifle that would provide highest precision possible and that's how PSG-1 came into existence. Mechanically it is just like G3, it's a rifle of all-steel construction using a roller-delayed blowback action. Differences are the modifications for precision shooting purposes. PSG-1 has a heavy free-floating barrel with polygonal rifling, an adjustable stock made of strengthened polymer, a precision trigger that can be easily replaced for individual fitting, a tripod and suppressor. The default scope is Hensoldt ZF PSG-1 6x42 scope with an illuminated reticle. That magnification is a little too low for military shooting on far ranges (scopes from long before PSG-1 creation easily had 12x magnification), but it is usually enough for what the PSG-1 was designed for, the police sniper use. Nonetheless, the low-power scope choice was often criticized and new versions have interchangeable scopes of high-power magnification. The PSG-1's accuracy is close to that of bolt-action sniper rifles, which is exceptional for semi-automatic weapon. The main disadvantage is it's weight, which basically limits it mostly to stationary use. Another is the incredibly high price. The PSG-1 is one of the most expensive semi-automatic sniper rifles available, with a new rifle costing as much as 10.000$ per unit.

%c[0,170,170,170]The HK33 is a 5.56x45mm assault rifle designed and manufactured by Heckler and Koch in former West Germany in the late 1960s. It was developed as a scaled-down famous G3 rifle rechambered to a smaller cartridge, which later became NATO service round. It didn't gain as much fame as G3, but is nonetheless considered a very good and effective weapon, which, just like G3, works reliably in all conditions and can withstand continuous abuse. Mechanically, it is pretty much just like G3. It is an assault rifle of all-steel construction using a roller-delayed blowback action. The weapon was designed to use as much stamped steel parts as possible to reduce the cost, with the furniture made of strengthened polymer. Despite stamped steel construction, it is a durable weapon that is hard to break. The barrel has length of 390mm (15.4"), which provides good ballistics for small 5.56mm bullet that depends on velocity to tumble and fragment properly as a way to deal tissue damage. It is also not as long as other rifles of that time (for example M16A1 had 20" barrel), which improves the handling. The HK33 wasn't adopted by Bundeswehr, but was used by German police and security units and was adopted by multiple countries, most notably Turkey, Malaysia, Greece and special forces units like Navy SEALS and SAS. High numbers of these rifles, coming most likely from Pakistan region, were sold on black market and hit The Zone, where it is well-liked by stalkers as a relatively cheap, but effective and relatively modern weapon with high accuracy. The 40 round magazine improves the firepower over similar rifles, which can give it a substantial edge in firefights.

%c[0,170,170,170]HK53 is a commando-length carbine variant of HK33, a 5.56x45mm assault rifle designed and manufactured by Heckler and Koch in former West Germany in the late 1960s. The HK33 was developed as a scaled-down famous G3 rifle rechambered to a smaller cartridge, which later became NATO service round. HK53 has a very short, 211mm (8.4") barrel, which places it closer to AKS-74u than Colt XM177. Thanks to that, it is very easy to maneuver, but loses even more velocity - the 5.56mm bullet needs certain velocity to properly yaw and fragment in the tissue to deal damage, and barrels shorter than 12" don't provide it. HK53 is also marginally heavier than AKS-74u and XM177. Nonetheless, it was accepted by multiple law enforcement agencies and special forces units, most notably the British SAS. Mechanically, it is pretty much just like G3 and HK33. It is an assault rifle of all-steel construction using a roller-delayed blowback action. The weapon was designed to use as much stamped steel parts as possible to reduce the cost, with the furniture made of strengthened polymer. Despite stamped steel construction, it is a durable weapon that is hard to break. Some of these carbines, coming most likely from Pakistan region, were sold on black market and hit The Zone, where it is considered a more universal alternative to AKS-74u carbines.

%c[0,170,170,170]HS2000, also known as Springfield XDM, is a family of polymer-framed, striker-fired semi-automatic pistols available in various chamberings and barrel lengths. Original design, the HS2000, comes from Croatia, where it was made by HS Produkt for Croatian army. In early 2000s Springfield Armory Co. shown interest in Croatian design and started importing these pistols to USA. Springfield made a deal for licensing rights with HS Produkt and shortly after they made some improvements to HS2000; the improved pistol received the name of Springfield XDM (short for X-treme Duty, M is for Match barrel). The XDM sold excellently and became one of the most popular handguns in USA. The press awarded the XDM the title of Handgun of the Year, twice. More than 30 variants of XDM are offered, chambered in 9x19mm, .40SW, .45ACP and .357SIG, with barrel lengths of 3", 4" and 5.25", all designed for different niche. Mechanically, the HS2000 is a short recoil-operated, locked breech, striker fired semi-automatic pistol. The frame is made out of strong polymer with metal slide. Trigger is of moderate weight and can be replaced with lighter, match-grade one for higher accuracy. Variant chambered in 9x19mm holds 16 rounds in magazine, while .40 and .45 variants have 13 rounds capacity. Overally, the HS2000/XDM pistols are light, reliable, accurate and provide high capacity, all for low price. The pistol was however criticized for high bore axis which increases felt recoil and inconsistent quality control, as some pistols were found to be prone to breakage and stoppages. Those are however rare cases, and this weapon is considered by many to be amongst the best handguns currently available on market. It got adopted by Croatian military and various police departments in USA and Europe. It is also popular among civilian gun owners. In The Zone a lot of these pistols reached black market or were taken from homes by stalkers. Like all other modern 9x19mm pistols, the HS2000/XDMs are well liked and considered a solid choice for personal defense.

%c[0,170,170,170]Jericho 941 is an Israeli single action/double action semi-automatic pistol. It was developed by IMI (now IWI) in 1990s in cooperation with famous Czech (formerly Czechoslovak) Ceska Zbrojovka company and Tanfoglio company of Italy. Design of Jericho pistols is similar to that of Tanfoglio pistols which are themselves based on the famous Czechoslovak CZ-75, by many considered one of the best SA/DA pistols of that time. J941 was first designed in 9x19mm Parabellum and in .41 Action Express cartridge. .41 AE had ballistics similar to .40SW, but was designed to be used in 9x19mm pistols with minimal modifications (new barrel and return spring, and possibly new magazine), and thus had a rebated rim of the same diameter as the 9x19mm cartridge. Early Jericho pistols were often shipped with two sets of barrels and springs, one in 9x19mm and another in .41AE. Since .41AE wasn't a successful cartridge, later on the pistols were made in 9x19mm, with .40SW and .45ACP variants to follow up later. Mechanically, the Jericho is a locked breech, short recoil operated pistol. The frame and slide are all steel (compact variants were available in polymer frames too). Barrel has polygonal rifling, the trigger is SA/DA and provides relatively good accuracy. The drawback of Jericho is heavy weight and it's big dimensions with rather awkward grip, which both result in below average ergonomics. Nonetheless, the Jericho is a solid and reliable gun, on par with other steel-framed 9x19mm pistols. It was adopted by 14 countries' police and military forces, including Israeli military and security forces. It is also produced in Ukraine from 2009 under the name Fort-21.03 and is used by police and special forces, including military units carrying operations inside the Exclusion Zone. It is sometimes seen on black market in The Zone, where it is relatively popular together with other 9x19mm pistols, which are considered an upgrade over older Soviet-era 9x18mm pistols.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]PDW based on AR-15 design. Low recoil. Can shoot in bursts without loss in accuracy. Low damage output. Best on short range. %c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]KAC PDW is an experimental personal defense weapon developed by Knight's Armament Company (KAC), firing a new 6x35mm cartridge optimized for short barrel weapons. It is based on AR-15 rifle and is designed for the PDW role similarly to P90 and MP7. The KAC PDW combines new and off the shelf components in its design. The lower receiver, holding the magazine and trigger assembly, is essentially a shortened M16 rifle (AR-15) lower receiver, which makes the basic operating controls familiar to many potential users. Mechanically, AR-15 is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. KAC PDW has two gas pistons tapping hot gas from the barrel to operate its mechanism, located on the top left and right sides of the bolt carrier. The cartridge, upper receiver, and operating mechanism are all new designs by KAC. The KAC PDW fires a 6x35 mm cartridge, a full centimeter shorter than the western military standard 5.56x45mm NATO round. The 6mm bullet is slightly wider, and the standard 6x35mm bullet slightly heavier than the standard 5.56x45mm bullet. Fired from a 10-inch (250 mm) barrel, KAC claims that the 6x35mm cartridge reaches a muzzle velocity of 750m/s, slightly faster than the muzzle velocity of a 5.56mm cartridge fired from a similarly short barrel. The larger and shorter 6mm cartridge is optimized for these shorter barrel lengths, and would perform less efficiently from rifle-length barrels. KAC PDW was adopted only by US Secret Service and one PMC corporation. Some of them were later found in The Zone, but since the ammunition is not available (only way are handloads) those few KAC PDWs that were found reached black market mostly only as a curiosity.

%c[0,170,170,170]PP-9 Klin is a 9x18mm blowback operated submachine gun firing from closed bolt. It has simple construction and compact size, typical for Russian submachine guns of that time. The work on the new submachine gun started back in 1970s as the PP-71 on request from Soviet army, but then they lost interest in submachine guns and the project was shelved. Only in the early 90s Russian Ministry of Internal Affairs shown interest in a weapon that would be fit for police and counter-terrorist use, and the works started once again. PP-71 project was revived and modified, and that's how PP-91 Kedr was born. It was produced in limited numbers and issued to police and law enforcement units, such as OMON, in the year 1994. Two years later, the Kedr was modified again - the construction was strenghened to allow it reliably use new 9x18mm PMM cartridge, which is about 25% more powerful; this weapon was named PP-9 Klin. Both Kedr and Klin were produced and issued in limited numbers. Mechanically, PP-91 and PP-9 submachine guns are simple, blowback operated weapons firing from the closed bolt for improved accuracy. The Kedr/Klin is a compact and handy weapon, however other constructions like Bizon or Vityaz are considered much more effective.

%c[0,170,170,170]PP-9 Klin is a 9x18mm blowback operated submachine gun firing from closed bolt. It has simple construction and compact size, typical for Russian submachine guns of that time. The work on the new submachine gun started back in 1970s as the PP-71 on request from Soviet army, but then they lost interest in submachine guns and the project was shelved. Only in the early 90s Russian Ministry of Internal Affairs shown interest in a weapon that would be fit for police and counter-terrorist use, and the works started once again. PP-71 project was revived and modified, and that's how PP-91 Kedr was born. It was produced in limited numbers and issued to police and law enforcement units, such as OMON, in the year 1994. Two years later, the Kedr was modified again - the construction was strenghened to allow it reliably use new 9x18mm PMM cartridge, which is about 25% more powerful; this weapon was named PP-9 Klin. Both Kedr and Klin were produced and issued in limited numbers. Mechanically, PP-91 and PP-9 submachine guns are simple, blowback operated weapons firing from the closed bolt for improved accuracy. The Kedr/Klin is a compact and handy weapon, however other constructions like Bizon or Vityaz are considered much more effective.

%c[0,170,170,170]OTs-02 Kiparis (Russian: Cypress) is a Soviet 9x18mm submachine gun used by Russian law enforcement agencies. It was designed by KPB Bureau in Tula in the early 1970s, but because of lack of interest from military it was shelved until 1990s, when Ministry of Internal Affairs decided to arm policemen and law enforcement officers with a weapon that would give them more firepower. Kiparis was adopted in 1995 by MVD, Russian police forces and various law enforcement agencies such as OMON. Mechanically it's a simple blowback operated weapons firing from the closed bolt for improved accuracy.OTs-02 has high rate of fire of about 900 rounds per minute, but it is said to be relatively controllable, which makes it very effective as a close-range personal defense weapon. The Kiparis is a compact and handy weapon, however other constructions like Bizon or Vityaz are considered much more effective.

%c[0,170,170,170]M1 Garand is a World War II-era semi-automatic rifle that was the service rifle of the US military. It is one of the most famous rifles in the world, widely considered the best service rifle of entire WWII - General Patton called it "the greatest battle implement ever devised". M1 was developed in 1930s by John Garand, Canadian-American weapons designer, and was adopted by US Army in 1936, replacing Sprinfield M1903 bolt-action rifle. More than 5 million of M1 Garand rifles were produced, and they greatly increased the firepower of US infantry squads compared to typical squad of other countries, who used bolt-action rifles (not counting Germany, whose firepower was provided by a belt-fed machine gun). Mechanically, M1 is a gas operated firearm, using a long-stroke gas piston system with rotating bolt. It is fed by unique en-bloc clip holding 8 rounds. The M1 rifle was chambered in .30-06 Springfield round (7.62x63mm), which was standard cartridge back then, but small amount of these rifles was converted to .308 Win after the war (so called Navy Garands). Advantages of M1 Garand were high firepower, easy and quick reloading and satisfactory accuracy. It's drawbacks were heavy weight and slightly lower reliability than other rifles. It was also less accurate than bolt-action rifles on longer distances, which made them less effective as scoped rifle (two scoped variants were made, M1C and M1D). After the war, M1 Garand rifles were used by multiple countires, mostly those who received them as military aid from US, like Brazil, Denmark, Iran, South Korea, Turkey or South Vietnam. M1 rifles are also used by hunters, sport shooters and civilian gun enthusiasts. In Europe they are very rare, but some of them were imported from Vietnam and Philippines, reaching high prices on collector market. Some were probably stolen, as they appeared in The Zone as hunting rifles.

%c[0,170,170,170]Glock is a family of semi-automatic pistols developed by Austrian company Glock GmbH in the late 1970s. Glock was designed by Gaston Glock as a modern handgun using many revolutionary features and for a long time was one of the most advanced pistols available. Glock 17 is a full-size pistol chambered in 9x19mm round. It can be distinguished from Glock 19 by slightly longer barrel and longer grip with magazine holding 17 rounds. It is striker fired with medium-weight trigger and three independent safety mechanisms (with no classic safety lever), which make it fit for carrying with a round in a chamber and no need to disengage external safety - the gun can be shot immediately after drawing it from holster, which is a big advantage over classic hammer-fired pistols. Glock pistols have a new type of hammer-forged barrel with polygonal rifling, which slightly improves durability and accuracy, and also makes it easier to clean. The frame is made entirely out of reinforced polymer, which saves weight and is immune to corrosion. Despite initial concerns, the polymer slide was proven to be actually more resistant than some all-steel constructions, it is also resistant to heat and caustic chemicals. The slide is made out of steel and has Tenifer (ferritic nitrocarburized) finish, which is extremely hard and makes the gun very durable and resistant to wear and corrosion on levels exceeding these of stainless steel and chrome lining. Glocks were adopted by multiple countries' armies, special forces units (eg. Navy SEALS, Delta, SAS and Russian Spetsnaz) and countless police departments. 27 different variants of Glock pistols were designed, including full-size, compact and sub-compact size pistols available in different chamberings, mostly 9x19mm,.40SW and .45ACP. Due to very high reliability and durability of parts it was dubbed "AK of pistols". In the Central and Eastern Europe Glock is the most popular handgun, with CZ-75, P99 and Makarov right behind. In The Zone it is very popular due to it's low price and unmatched reliability, which is valued in harsh reality of anomalous regions.

%c[0,170,170,170]Glock is a family of semi-automatic pistols developed by Austrian company Glock GmbH in the late 1970s. Glock was designed by Gaston Glock as a modern handgun using many revolutionary features and for a long time was one of the most advanced pistols available. Glock 20 is a full-size pistol chambered in 10mm Auto round. Externally it looks just like Glock 17, it is only slightly thicker. It is striker fired with medium-weight trigger and three independent safety mechanisms (with no classic safety lever), which make it fit for carrying with a round in a chamber and no need to disengage external safety - the gun can be shot immediately after drawing it from holster, which is a big advantage over classic hammer-fired pistols. Glock pistols have a new type of hammer-forged barrel with polygonal rifling, which slightly improves durability and accuracy, and also makes it easier to clean. The frame is made entirely out of reinforced polymer, which saves weight and is immune to corrosion. Despite initial concerns, the polymer slide was proven to be actually more resistant than some all-steel constructions, it is also resistant to heat and caustic chemicals. The slide is made out of steel and has Tenifer (ferritic nitrocarburized) finish, which is extremely hard and makes the gun very durable and resistant to wear and corrosion on levels exceeding these of stainless steel and chrome lining. Glocks were adopted by multiple countries' armies, special forces units (eg. Navy SEALS, Delta, SAS and Russian Spetsnaz) and countless police departments. 27 different variants of Glock pistols were designed, including full-size, compact and sub-compact size pistols available in different chamberings, mostly 9x19mm,.40SW and .45ACP. Due to very high reliability and durability of parts it was dubbed "AK of pistols". In the Central and Eastern Europe Glock is the most popular handgun, with CZ-75, P99 and Makarov right behind. 10mm Auto chambering is a round close to .357 Magnum in power, which makes the Glock 20 a very powerful pistol with high capacity - because of that, the Glock 20 is very sought after in The Zone, as activity of wild animals and mutants often require more powerful loads to effectively defend yourself.

%c[0,170,170,170]Glock 18 is a 9x19mm machine pistol based on Glock 17, a modern polymer-framed, striker-fired pistol developed in the late 1970s in Austria. It has a fire selector mounted by default which has two positions, single shots and full-auto, which, due to non-modified action, fires with extremely high cyclic rate of 1200RPM. Apart from this, G18 is same as G17. Glocks are striker fired pistols with medium-weight trigger and three independent safety mechanisms (with no classic safety lever), which make it fit for carrying with a round in a chamber and no need to disengage external safety - the gun can be shot immediately after drawing it from holster, which is a big advantage over classic hammer-fired pistols. Glock pistols have a new type of hammer-forged barrel with polygonal rifling, which slightly improves durability and accuracy, and also makes it easier to clean. The frame is made entirely out of reinforced polymer, which saves weight and is immune to corrosion. Despite initial concerns, the polymer slide was proven to be actually more resistant than some all-steel constructions, it is also resistant to heat and caustic chemicals. The slide is made out of steel and has Tenifer (ferritic nitrocarburized) finish, which is extremely hard and makes the gun very durable and resistant to wear and corrosion on levels exceeding these of stainless steel and chrome lining. It can use magazines holding 17, 19, 22 or 33 rounds. Glock 18 was adopted by multiple countries' militaries, special forces units and police departments. It is used as a personal defense weapon for those who need highly concealable automatic weapons, like bodyguards and Secret Service agents. They are also often used by PMC and mercenaries as more powerful sidearms. Glock 18 machine pistols are not available to civilians and are usually much more expensive than standard Glock pistols.

%c[0,170,170,170]Glock 18C is a 9x19mm machine pistol with integral compensator based on Glock 17, a modern polymer-framed, striker-fired pistol developed in the late 1970s in Austria. It has a fire selector mounted by default which has two positions, single shots and full-auto, which, due to non-modified action, fires with extremely high cyclic rate of 1200RPM. Apart from this, G18 is same as G17. G18C additionally has a ported barrel to act as compensator to reduce muzzle rise in fully-automatic mode. Glocks are striker fired pistols with medium-weight trigger and three independent safety mechanisms (with no classic safety lever), which make it fit for carrying with a round in a chamber and no need to disengage external safety - the gun can be shot immediately after drawing it from holster, which is a big advantage over classic hammer-fired pistols. Glock pistols have a new type of hammer-forged barrel with polygonal rifling, which slightly improves durability and accuracy, and also makes it easier to clean. The frame is made entirely out of reinforced polymer, which saves weight and is immune to corrosion. Despite initial concerns, the polymer slide was proven to be actually more resistant than some all-steel constructions, it is also resistant to heat and caustic chemicals. The slide is made out of steel and has Tenifer (ferritic nitrocarburized) finish, which is extremely hard and makes the gun very durable and resistant to wear and corrosion on levels exceeding these of stainless steel and chrome lining. It can use magazines holding 17, 19, 22 or 33 rounds. Glock 18 was adopted by multiple countries' militaries, special forces units and police departments. It is used as a personal defense weapon for those who need highly concealable automatic weapons, like bodyguards and Secret Service agents. They are also often used by PMC and mercenaries as more powerful sidearms. Glock 18 machine pistols are not available to civilians and are usually much more expensive than standard Glock pistols.
