%c[0,170,170,170]MP-443 Grach (Russian: Rook), also known as PYa (standing for Pistolet Yarygina) is a Russian semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x19mm Parabellum cartridge. It was developed as a replacement for aging Makarov pistols, chambered in weaker 9x18mm cartridge. Mechanically, MP-443 is a steel-frame, short recoil operated, locked breech pistol. It uses a Double-Action trigger, which is relatively stiff and lowers practical accuracy, it does however improve safety. Slide and frame are made from carbon steel, barrel is made of stainless steel to prevent rusting. Hammer is external, but is covered to prevent snaggling on clothes and equipment. It uses a double stack magazine which holds 17 rounds of 9x19mm Parabellum ammunition. The pistol is made to withstand high-pressure loads of 9x19mm, such as 7N21 - the +P+ armor-piercing cartridge. MP-443 Grach is a sturdy pistol with high capacity. On the other hand, it has already aging construction, and all-steel design makes it way heavier than western competitors like Glock. The double-action trigger is also a requirement for police and not military weapon. Overally, the MP-443 is a controversial handgun and isn't well liked by all of the soldiers, however, it is definitely an upgrade over older PM pistols which were more suited for concealed carrying by policemen than as a sidearm for soldiers. Also the use of more powerful 9x19mm ammunition must be noted, as the MP-443 can use multiple types of ammunition, including expanding, tracer and armor-piercing rounds. Grach is currently only used by Russian army and law enforcement and Kazakhstan security companies. Some of these pistols came into The Zone with Russian PMCs and are also sold on civilian market.

%c[0,170,170,170]Dornaus and Dixon Enterprises Inc. from 1983 to 1986. While the Bren Ten's design has an appearance similar to the 9?19mm Parabellum CZ-75, it is larger and stronger with several unique design elements that make it a distinctly separate firearm. The design was produced only in small numbers before the company went bankrupt. Subsequent attempts to bring the firearm back into production have been unsuccessful. The Bren Ten was the handgun story of the early- to mid-1980s. The pundits drooled and salivated. It was predicted that the new cartridge that came out with it, the 10mm Auto, would take over the law enforcement market. It was not to be. Today, the 10mm is popular only among handgun cognoscenti. The Bren Ten itself has long since languished on the ash heap of firearms history. Its creator, the legend Jeff Cooper, wrote in his column in the April 2004 Guns and Ammo: "The Bren Ten was a concept of mine, and while I am not ashamed of it, I admit that this concept was not entirely sound." The words had the ring of a eulogy. The 10mm caliber is very sought after in The Zone, as activity of wild animals and mutants often require more powerful loads to effectively defend yourself.

%c[0,170,170,170]HK416 is a 5.56x45mm assault rifle developed in Germany by Heckler and Koch. It is based on AR-15 rifle, sharing the aesthetics and ergonomics with it, but it uses a gas piston system (used before in G36) which greatly increases the weapon's reliability. After the XM8 failure, HK decided to enter US market with new product - AR-15 rifle upgrade. The AR-15 is an American 5.56x45mm assault rifle developed by Eugene Stoner in 1960s. It was designed as a lightweight automatic rifle using a modern, light, small-bore ammunition which allowed the soldier to carry more ammunition. It was adopted as service rifle of US military as M16 rifle and M4 carbine, among others. These weapons were successful, as they're very ergonomic, easy to use, provide high firepower and boast very high accuracy; their drawback however was reliability - M4A1 was proven to jam even 3x more often than other rifles. HK416 was designed to fix that issue. AR-15 is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. HK416 system uses a short-stroke piston that forces the bolt carrier to the rear; this design prevents combustion gases from entering the weapon's interior — a drawback of direct impingement systems which reduces weapon's reliability and parts life. Other improvements include new buffer assembly, improved bolt, and a cold hammer forged barrel, as well as free-floating handguard with integral Picatinny-type rails, which improve accuracy while also allowing to attach additional equipment and optical sights. Receiver is made from high grade aluminum alloy, which is light and durable. The HK416 is considered by many to be one of the best assault rifles of modern times - it is light, reliable, ergonomic and can be customized to fit operator's needs. Multiple countries' militaries adopted this rifle, it also became a primary weapon of many special forces units, including those from US, Germany, France, Croatia and Poland. It is also used by many law enforcement agencies and PMC companies. In The Zone it is often seen in hands of mercenaries and foreign expeditions, but is rarely seen on black market.

Receiver is made from high grade aluminum alloy, which is light and durable. The HK416 is considered by many to be one of the best assault rifles of modern times - it is light, reliable, ergonomic and can be customized to fit operator's needs. HK416C has very short barrel, which improves the handling and makes it very light, but lowers the muzzle velocity, resulting in reduced tissue damage potential and limited range. HK416C with it's length is an equivalent of G36C and Mk18 carbines.

%c[0,170,170,170]Interdynamics AB-10, also known as TEC-9, is a blowback-operated machine pistol chambered in 9x19mm Parabellum. The TEC-9 design was started in Sweden, when the Interdynamic AB company of Stockholm developed a relatively simple submachine gun. Since Sweden was a poor market for such product, a subsidiary company Interdynamic was established in Miami (Florida, USA), to market Interdynamic guns in USA. As the full-automatic weapons market in USA is very restrictive, the basic submachine gun was converted in semi-automatic only variant, apparently suitable for civilian US market. This semi-automatic pistol, like its submachine gun predecessor, was a simple blowback design, firing from the open bolt, which made it easy to conver to fire in fully-automatic mode. Mechanically, AB-10/TEC-9 pistols are blowback operated, semi-automatic weapons firing from open bolt. The receivers of all versions are made from steel tube, the frames are made from polymer, integral with pistol grip and magazine housing ahead of the trigger guard. The tubular receiver is hinged to the front of the frame. There is no manual safety. Permanently fixed open sights were not adjustable, and often misaligned. Usually these weapons had questionable quality, but were very cheap and simple. The TEC-9 developed a negative reputation for its association with organized crime and mass shootings in the 1990s, getting itself a nickname of a "hood blaster". A lot of these weapons, converted illegally to automatic fire, found their way to the black market, including arms dealers in The Zone who sell them as cheap substitute of more refined PDWs and machine pistols.

%c[0,170,170,170]Custom-built AKS-74u rechambered for 5.56x45mm cartridge and outfitted with modern furniture. Custom builds for AKs are increasingly popular and their owners are taking these weapons to The Zone with them. AKS-74u (also known as Krinkov (in USA), Ksyuha, Suchka or Okurok) is a compact carbine variant of AK-74 rifle. It was developed around the time of AK-74's adoption and was intended as a personal defense weapon for vehicles' crews, helicopter pilots, special forces operators and personnel that didn't need long rifles or had trouble carrying one. It is way shorter than typical infantry rifle and is even slightly shorter than comparable weapons of it's era like XM177 or HK53. Mechanically it uses AK-74 gas action, but due to problems with insufficient pressure from shorter barrel, a special gas system was designed for it. In tactical sense it's something between a carbine and submachine gun - it has a 206mm (8") long barrel and a folding stock, which makes it lighter and way more maneuverable in close quarters than long AK-74 rifle. It's a controversial weapon - on one hand, it is light and compact, on the other, it has higher recoil than submachine gun, it's accurate only to about 100-150 meters and it overheats quickly. It is praised by some and hated by others. It became a popular weapon in The Zone for those who don't participate in fights but need something to defend themselves from mutants and bandits, and don't want a long and heavy rifle that would reduce the amount of loot they could carry due to it's weight and size.

%c[0,170,170,170]KRISS Vector is a family of modern submachine guns developed by the American company KRISS USA (formerly TDI). They use an unconventional delayed blowback system combined with in-line design to reduce felt recoil and muzzle climb of the weapon. Vector shoots with incredibly high cyclic rate of 1200 rounds per minute (for comparison, MP5 has rate of 800RPM), but recoil reducing mechanism makes it easy to control. Mechanically, Vector is a delayed blowback operated submachine gun, firing from closed bolt for enhanced first-shot accuracy. Very light bolt is connected to the vertically sliding weight, which is located within a polymer housing in front of the pistol grip. Firing controls include ambidextrous fire mode selector switch, located on the upper receiver, with settings for fully automatic, 2-round burst and semi-automatic mode and a separate ambidextrous manual safety switch, which is conveniently located just above the pistol grip. The weapon is fed from Glock magazines in various sizes, most notably of 13, 25 and 33 rounds capacity, which are very cheap and readily available all around the world. The Vector uses an articulated mechanism referred to as the "KRISS Super V," which allows the bolt and an inertia block to move downward into a recess behind the magazine well. The theory is that at the end of this travel, the energy is transmitted downward rather than rearward, thus reducing the felt recoil. When fired, the barrel axis is in line with the shoulder as in the M16 rifle, but also in line with the shooter's hand. This is intended to reduce muzzle climb when combined with the off-axis bolt travel. Vector is a relatively successful weapon and was adopted by multiple users, mainly police departments and security agencies in Europe (mostly the 9x19mm version), but was also received warmly on civilian market where it is sold in semi-automatic-only version (in USA it is sold with long, 16" barrel because of specific gun laws). In The Zone it is used by mercenary groups and loners who need a compact and light weapon for use as PDW, but due to it's extremely high rate of fire it is also used as weapon for mutant hunting - even short burst can send a lot bullets down range, increasing the chance of critical hit.

%c[0,170,170,170]Accuracy International Arctic Warfare rifle is a bolt-action sniper rifle designed and manufactured by the British company Accuracy International. It became popular as a hunting, police and military rifle since it's introduction in the 1980s. These rifles have features that improve their performance in very cold conditions, without impairing operation in normal weather. AI PM (Precision Marksman) rifle was designed in the early 1980s as a new sniper rifle for the British Army and was accepted into service as L96. Some time after the Swedish military also desired a new rifle, and in the early 1990s AI entered with an upgraded version of the PM, now known as the AW (Arctic Warfare). Special de-icing features allowed it to be used effectively at temperatures as low as ?40 °C (?104 °F). The AW rifle featured a modified bolt with milled slots to prevent freezing and problems caused by penetrating water, dirt or similar disturbances. It was accepted into use by the Swedish Army in 1991 and steadily became increasingly popular due to it's extreme durability, reliability and precision (up to 0.5MOA). The chassis is made of alluminum, the flat-sided receiver is a stressed part, machined in-house by AI from a solid piece of forged carbon steel. The bolt handle is bent to the rear, which makes it's operating easier. AW has a heavy, free-floating barrel and a light two-stage trigger. Overally, the AW is one of the most reliable and precise sniper rifle in the world. It was adopted by multiple military and police units around the world, most notably UK (as L96 and L118), USA, Sweden, Australia, Germany, Czech Republic and even Russia, who usually prefer their own designs. Despite the fact it's very expensive, the AW also became popular among hunters and civilian marksmen, who greatly value it's high accuracy. Since bolt action rifles are easily available on civilian market, more wealthy stalkers use these rifles as hunting rifles to shoot dangerous mutants from long distance, on which they themselves stay safe.

%c[0,170,170,170]M1 Carbine is a lightweight, semi-automatic carbine that was introduced to US military during World War II. It was meant to be a primary weapon of rear echelon troops and those soldiers who did not need or couldn't carry a long and heavy infantry rifle like M1 Garand (1.1m length and 4.3kg of weight), such as officers, drivers, forward observers and crew-served weapons (heavy machine guns, anti-tank and artillery guns, mortars) crews. At first some of these soldiers were just given pistols, but their limited range (max 50m, practically about 25-30m) and low capacity were unfit for regular fights; apart from that, range and combat experiences shown that pistols require much more training to use effectively. The M1 Carbine was an answer to this, as it was very light, compact, easy to use and was chambered in a light cartridge that produced low recoil, while remaining effective for longer ranges than pistols and submachine guns (.30 Carbine round is roughly an equivalent to .357 Magnum cartridge). Mechanically, the M1 uses the short-piston stroke gas operated action. When gun is fired, the powder gases are bleed from the barrel into the gas chamber and propel the gas piston violently to the rear. M1 has steel receiver and wooden furniture. It was very well liked in the WWII and after and is widely regarded as a reliable and effective weapon that is very easy to control even for less experienced shooters. Over 6 millions of these weapons were produced, more than any other US WWII weapon. After the war the M1 was used up until Vietnam war by US and even longer by more than 50 other countries (from which at least five use it up to this day) who used it, mainly South Vietnam, South Korea, Italy, Taiwan, Norway and France. M1 Carbine was sold in big numbers on civilian market in US, where it is very popular as a home defense and small-game hunting weapon, it was also used for hunting in Europe, albeit in smaller numbers. Some of these weapons reached the black market in The Zone, where they can be bought for cheap as a defensive weapon - it is liked by some scavengers for it's light weight and compact size as it doesn't encumber the user, allowing for more loot to be carried.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Ergonomics: %c[0,170,170,170]high

%c[0,170,170,170]M1A1 Carbine is a paratrooper variant of M1 Carbine, a lightweight, semi-automatic carbine that was introduced to US military during World War II. It was developed specially for paratroopers, as it was very light and folding stock made it easier to airdrop with it. Apart from folding stock, the weapon is exactly the same. M1 Carbine was meant to be a primary weapon of rear echelon troops and those soldiers who did not need or couldn't carry a long and heavy infantry rifle like M1 Garand (1.1m length and 4.3kg of weight), such as officers, drivers, forward observers and crew-served weapons (heavy machine guns, anti-tank and artillery guns, mortars) crews. At first some of these soldiers were just given pistols, but their limited range (max 50m, practically about 25-30m) and low capacity were unfit for regular fights; apart from that, range and combat experiences shown that pistols require much more training to use effectively. The M1 Carbine was an answer to this, as it was very light, compact, easy to use and was chambered in a light cartridge that produced low recoil, while remaining effective for longer ranges than pistols and submachine guns (.30 Carbine round is roughly an equivalent to .357 Magnum cartridge). Mechanically, the M1 uses the short-piston stroke gas operated action. When gun is fired, the powder gases are bleed from the barrel into the gas chamber and propel the gas piston violently to the rear. M1 has steel receiver and wooden furniture. It was very well liked in the WWII and after and is widely regarded as a reliable and effective weapon that is very easy to control even for less experienced shooters. Over 6 millions of these weapons were produced, more than any other US WWII weapon. Unlike the M1 Carbine, the M1A1 is a rare weapon and it is rarely seen outside museums and private collections. Small numbers of these weapons reached the black market in The Zone, where they can be bought for cheap as a defensive weapon - it is liked by some scavengers for it's light weight and compact size as it doesn't encumber the user, allowing for more loot to be carried.

%c[0,170,170,170]M3A1 Grease Gun is a submachine gun chambered in .45ACP developed for US military during World War II. It was designed as a cheap weapon fit for rapid mass production in style of Sten and PPS-43 submachine guns. Before the M3, the US military's service submachine gun was Thompson M1928A1. It was a very good weapon, but it was very heavy and extremely expensive in production, which limited the production capability of US war industry. M3 was made to fix this issue. It was a fully automatic, blowback-operated weapon that fired from an open bolt. Manufactured of plain sheet steel, the M3 receiver was stamped in two halves that were then welded together. To save time and cost, the barrel was cold-swaged. The weapon was not well finished and the appearance of M3 is very crude as it was rushed to reduce the cost as much as possible, it was only finished as much as to allow the weapon to function properly. Because of crude, industrial aesthetics, the M3 was called the "Greaser" or "Grease Gun". Nonetheless, it was a relatively reliable weapon that was "just-good-enough" for war time. Slow rate of fire improved the controllability of the weapon and allowed for more accurate fire even in long bursts. Single shots could also be fired without the need for fire selector. More than 600 000 of these guns were produced in only two years of 1943-1945. The Grease Gun remained in service with US military up to Vietnam war, and was even used as late as in 1990s by Abrams crews because of their compact size. It was used by multiple countries after the war, among them Vietnam, France, Afghanistan, Phillipines and Mexico. A lot of M3A1s reached black market in South America and Asia, some of them reached The Zone from Phillipines and Vietnam - they are used as cheap alternative to more modern submachine guns, but due to excessive weight they usually aren't well liked and are used only by those who can't afford more modern weapons.

%c[0,170,170,170]Mossberg 590 is an American pump-action shotgun, developed as a premium-class shotgun for military specification. It was based on Mossberg 500, the classic series of pump-action shotguns produced in multiple variants, chamberings and furniture sets. Mossberg shotguns are popular in law enforcement agencies and police departments, as well as among civilian gun owners and hunters. They are regarded as high-quality weapons that are dependable and of high quality. These shotguns utilize pump action, which is operated by a sliding forend. The forend is connected with the bolt group. The receiver is produced from lightweight aluminum alloy. Ammunition is fed from the tubular magazine that is located under the barrel. “Militarization” of Mossberg 500 into 590 included strengthening of the receiver and other parts, installation of the vented heat shield around the barrel, bayonet lug and extended magazine, as well as an aluminum trigger guard instead of a plastic one. Standard finish is of 590 is parkerizing, and the gun is usually provided with replacement pistol grip, which allows easy conversion to ‘Cruiser’ modification and back. Mossberg 590 was officially adopted into US Army and Marine Corps. While it was officially replaced in the US Army with the Benelli M1014 semi-automatic shotgun, Mossberg 590 shotguns are still widely used by the US Navy and Marine Corps. Pump action shotguns are popular in both the USA and Europe, and some stalkers brought these weapons, often legally owned, along with them into The Zone, where they are primarily used for defense against wild animals and mutants or hunting them. Like all other shotguns, the Mossberg 590 is liked for the sheer power that the 12 gauge shells provide.

%c[0,170,170,170]Benelli M4 Super 90 is a semi-automatic shotgun designed and developed in the late 1990s by Benelli Armi SpA of Italy. It was designed in response for US Army Armament Research Center request for a new 12 gauge semi-automatic shotgun for the US military. The M4 was the first gas-operated shotgun produced by Benelli. Its function is designed around an entirely new method called the "auto regulating gas operated" (ARGO) system, which provides an efficient cycling for the weapon. Additionally, the weapon is self-regulating for use with cartridges of varying length and power levels (for example the buckshot and the breaching rounds, which have different energy). The sights are military-style ghost ring and are adjustable. On top of the receiver a RIS rail is mounted by default, allowing for use of any optical sight of choice. The modular basis of the shotgun means many of its features can be reconfigured as needed. It allows a user to quickly exchange the various assembly groups (barrel, buttstock, forearm, etc.) without the use of tools. The Benelli M4 was adopted by US military in 1999 as M1014 and still serves. It is also used by militaries of another 20 countries, where it is used with great success. Users praise it's high quality, reliability and effectiveness. In The Zone, the Benelli M4 is mostly seen in hands of PMC mercenaries; some hunter squads also use the M4s due to their high firepower and higher rate of fire compared to classic pump-action shotguns.

%c[0,170,170,170]The Military Armament Corporation Model 10, more commonly known as the MAC-10, is a compact, blowback operated machine pistol that was developed by Gordon Ingram in 1964. This weapon was designed for close quarters combat and concealed carry for bodyguards and agents. It is a blowback-operated, selective-fire pistol that fires from an open bolt. The bolt is of telescoped design, with most of its weight located in front of the breech face, "wrapped" around the barrel. Shoulder stock was of telescoped design with a folding shoulder rest made of steel wire. To provide additional stability, a leather loop is attached to the front of the receiver, used to hold the gun by the non-firing hand. M-10 was used by US special forces in Vietnam, but was found to be very inaccurate with very hard recoil and muzzle rise when shooting bursts. These weapons were popular on civilian market and a lot of them ended up on black market where it was popular among gangsters in USA. M-10 design was also very easy to make at makeshift workshops, so improvised weapons based on M-10 were often encountered - case similar to the Sten gun. Some of the M-10 machine pistols reached The Zone where they are sometimes used as a cheap way to increase one's close-range firepower. However, due to it's excessive weight and relatively low reliability the M-10 is rather unpopular, especially considering abundance of other, more effective yet just as cheap compact submachine guns and machine pistols.

%c[0,170,170,170]Mauser C96 is a semi-automatic pistol chambered in 7.63x25mm Mauser cartridge, designed and manufactured by Mauser in Germany from 1896. It was one of the first successful semi-automatic pistols. It was a huge success on both military and civilian market, and to this day is a popular and recognizable firearm. Mechanically, the Mauser C96 is a recoil operated, locked breech, semi-automatic pistol. The distinctive characteristics of the C96 are the integral box magazine in front of the trigger. The whole pistol is made of metal with wooden handguards, most C96 pistols also have an option to add a wooden stock, which doubles as a holster. Overally, the C96 is a big pistol with relatively low handling, but it is pretty reliable, durable and accurate. It uses 7.63x25mm cartridge which is almost exact in dimensions to Soviet 7.62x25mm TT round (which was actually based on Mauser round). While TT pistol can use 7.63 Mauser rounds, the C96 shouldn't use 7.62 TT - the TT round produces much higher pressure. The round will chamber and fire without problems, but the gun will wear out much faster and can even explode. Mauser C96 was produced in more than a million copies. The M712 "Schnellfeuer" ("Quick-firing") variant could fire in full-auto mode and was also very popular. There was also 9x19mm variant called "Red Nine" (because it had a "9" stamped in red on the grip). The C96 and M712 were used by Germany in both world wars, Austria-Hungary, Russia (and USSR), Spain, Vietnam and China. China also produced their own C96 and M712 copies. Some of these guns survived all this time and remain in private hands Europe, some of them reached The Zone where they were brought by stalkers for personal protection. C96 is heavy and unwieldy, but is nonetheless better than nothing.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]High rate of fire. Heavy barrel allows for prolonged automatic fire without damaging the weapon. High capacity belt. Very high damage output. Very effective vs mutants or multiple enemies. %c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]MG3 is a modernized 7.62x51mm variant of the famous MG42 machine gun chambered in 7.92x57mm, called the "Hitler's buzzsaw". Main difference between MG3 and MG42 is chambering - MG3 uses modern 7.62x51mm NATO rounds. The MG42 is a German machine gun developed as a successor to MG34, which was a very good weapon, but was expensive to manufacture. MG42 was made entirely from stamped sheet metal, which made it a cheap and simple. Despite it's simplicity, the MG42 proved to be extremely reliable and effective machine gun. Mechanically, the MG42/MG3 is a short-recoil operated, air cooled, belt fed weapon which fires from an open bolt. The barrel is quick-changeable, and can be replaced in less than six seconds by a properly trained crew, although a heatproof glove is required to remove the hot barrel. The action uses a recoil-operated roller locking mechanism, later used in HK weapons. The MG42 had insane rate of fire of 1200RPM, which produced a terrifying sound. The ear could not easily discern the sound of individual shots being fired, instead hearing a sound described as like "ripping cloth" or a buzzsaw. It was enough to pin down entire allied squad and stop their advance until the MG nest was destroyed. MG3 has the fire rate lowered to 800-900RPM, but it can be changed back to 1200 by replacing the bolt. The receiver and barrel jacket are made in one unit, and formed from a sheet of rolled steel, cut to shape by pressing and stamping. The gun is fed using belts only. MG42/MG3 have two points for bipod attachment, one near the muzzle and another near the center of the gun. MG3 is still considered one of the finest machine guns in use. It is still used by more than 20 countries, among them Germany, Austria, Denmark, Italy and many more. Some of these weapons were sent to Middle East, from where part of them found their way to black market. In The Zone MG3s are relatively rare, but are very well liked for their reliability, durability and extremely high rate of fire, which make them perfect as suppresion platform or anti-mutant weapon. Some mutant hunters modify their MG3s with front grips, new stocks and optics to optimise them for hip-fire.

%c[0,170,170,170]MP-153 is a semi-automatic shotgun designed and developed in the late 1990s by Izhmash (trademark Baikal). The MP-153 shotgun uses more or less conventional gas-operated action with annular piston, located around the magazine tube. Gas system features self-adjusting gas valve which allows to fire a wide variety of loads. It feeds from magazine tube holding 4 rounds (the capacity can be extended). The receiver of MP-153 is made from aluminum forging, stocks(for end and buttstock) are available in wood or polymer. Barrels can be easily removed, and available in a variety of lengths. Barrels are equipped with interchangeable choke system. Baikal MP-153 is considered a well made and effective weapon. Semi-automatic shotguns are popular in law enforcement agencies and police departments, as well as among civilian gun owners and hunters. Semi-automatic shotguns are popular in both the USA and Europe, and some stalkers brought these weapons, often legally owned, along with them into The Zone, where they are primarily used for defense against wild animals and mutants or hunting them. Like all other shotguns, the MP-153 is liked for the sheer power that the 12 gauge shells provide and higher rate of fire compared to pump-action shotguns, which greatly improves the firepower.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]Advanced modular assault rifle. Low recoil. Can place follow-up shots reliably and quickly. Improved bullpup construction provides very good handling. Moderate damage output. Effective at all ranges.%c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]MSBS Grot is a modular rifles family developed by FB Radom in Poland. MSBS stands for "Modular Firearms System" and refers to it's main feature, as the standard 5.56x45mm assault rifle can be quickly converted into a bullpup carbine or battle rifle simply by switching the weapon's parts (similarly to Masada/ACR rifles). Standard variants are MSBS-5.56K (standard configuration), MSBS-5.56B (bullpup) and MSBS-7.62N (battle rifle in 7.62x51mm). One variant can be easily and quickly converted into another in field conditions. Mechanically, MSBS is a gas-operated assault rifle using short stroke gas piston with rotating bolt. The receiver is completely enclosed in housing made from strengthened polymer. Whole construction is specially made to be resistant and durable in harsh conditions and extreme temperatures, even when the weapon is heavily worn. The weapons is completely ambidextrous. The stock is adjustable in conventional variant. On whole receiver's length there is an universal rail which allows the user to mount optical sights of his choice, depending on mission needs. Standard barrel has length of 16", which provides good velocity for 5.56mm bullet, as it relies on velocity to yaw and fragment in the tissue. There are also available barrel lengths of 10" or 20". The MSBS is the first assault rifle that was developed in Poland from the scratch. While it lacks truly revolutionary features, it is the first rifle to successfully merge them and be accepted into military service. Magpul Masada (later known as Bushmaster ACR) was very similar, but the project failed and only few were sold comercially. MSBS Grot is currently used by GROM SF operators together with HK416 rifles and Polish Army is slowly replacing their Beryl rifles (AK variants in 5.56mm) with Grots. Only few of MSBS rifles were sold so far, as most of production goes for military needs. Some of these rifles were seen in The Zone in hands of PMC mercenary groups, where they are sought after for their modularity and high ergonomics coupled with high reliability in harsh conditions of anomalous zones.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Ergonomics: %c[0,170,170,170]high %c[0,140,140,140]

%c[0,170,170,170]Beretta Mx4 Storm is an Italian compact submachine gun designed and developed by Beretta Arms Factory. It is fully-automatic variant of Cx4 carbine. It uses same blowback operated action with polymer body of the gun and fixed shoulder stock, as well as same ambidextrous controls. Charging handle can be set at either side of the gun, ejection also can be arranged either to the left or to the right, according to user preferences. Double stack magazines are inserted into the pistol grip, standard magazine capacity is 30 rounds. Beretta MX4 submachine gun is normally equipped with iron sights, and an integral Picatinny rail is provided at the top of the receiver for installation of optical sights. The Mx4 has high rate of fire, is very ergonomic and build of high quality materials. It is currently in use with multiple law enforcement agencies, most notably in Italy, USA and Russia. Some of these weapons reached The Zone, mostly used by mercenary teams as personal defense weapon. They are rather rare and expensive, but well liked for their compact dimensions.

%c[0,170,170,170]Walther P38 is a German semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x19mm cartridge, designed and developed in 1930s for German military to replace the aging Luger P08. P38 was probably the most advanced pistol of WWII. It was one of the first handguns to use DA/SA trigger and had multiple novelty technical features that were later used in more modern pistols, like the famous Beretta 92, so even today it can be considered a modern construction. Walther P38 is a short-recoil operated, locked-breech pistol. Construction is steel with bakelite grips. DA/SA trigger allows to carry it safely with a round in the chamber; the P38 also has the loaded chamber indicator which allows to see if the pistol is loaded without need to open the chamber. The P38 is relatively light compared to other WWII pistols (0,8kg), but it's dimensions are similar to other designs of that time. Overally, it was not only an accurate, reliable and ergonomic, but also was an advanced pistol produced with high quality materials, making it one of the best of it's time. More than a million of these pistols were produced, and the production continued after the war in Germany and France. It was used by Germany (including West and East after the war), France, Spain, Norway and many more countries. Some of these pistols are available on the black market and are sometimes used by stalkers as cheap sidearm. It's main drawback is the low capacity of 8 rounds, so usually those who can spare some more money choose more modern 9x19mm pistol.

%c[0,170,170,170]Walther P1 is a post-war variant of the P38 - a German semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x19mm cartridge, designed and developed in 1930s for German military to replace the aging Luger P08. P38 was probably the most advanced pistol of WWII. It was one of the first handguns to use DA/SA trigger and had multiple novelty technical features that were later used in more modern pistols, like the famous Beretta 92, so even today it can be considered a modern construction. P1 differs from P38 only by frame - P1 has lighter aluminium frame, while P38 has all-steel frame. Thanks to that, P1 is lighter and better to carry around, it is however slightly less durable. Apart from that, both weapons are identical. Walther P38 is a short-recoil operated, locked-breech pistol. Construction is steel with bakelite grips. DA/SA trigger allows to carry it safely with a round in the chamber; the P38 also has the loaded chamber indicator which allows to see if the pistol is loaded without need to open the chamber. The P38 is relatively light compared to other WWII pistols (0,8kg), but it's dimensions are similar to other designs of that time. Overally, it was not only an accurate, reliable and ergonomic, but also was an advanced pistol produced with high quality materials, making it one of the best of it's time. More than a million of these pistols were produced, and the production continued after the war in Germany and France. It was used by Germany (including West and East after the war), France, Spain, Norway and many more countries. After P1's withdrawal from German army, a lot of these pistols became available on the black market and can quite often be seen used by stalkers as cheap sidearm. It's main drawback is the low capacity of 8 rounds, so usually those who can spare some more money choose more modern 9x19mm pistol.

%c[0,170,170,170]P90 is a Belgian submachine gun chambered in 5.7x28mm ammunition, developed by FN Herstal as a personal defense weapon for use with special high velocity ammunition. It was designed from ground up in response for NATO requirements for potential replacement of 9x19mm Parabellum round. Featuring a compact bullpup design with an integrated reflex sight and fully ambidextrous controls, the P90 is an unconventional weapon with a futuristic appearance. Its design incorporates several innovations such as a unique top-mounted magazine and FN's small-caliber, high-velocity 5.7x28mm ammunition. Mechanically, the P90 is a blowback operated weapon which fires from a closed bolt. The magazine lies at the top of the weapon, feeding from front-to-back, with spiral ramp built into the “rear” part. Spent cartridges are ejected straight down through the chute. Standard sighting device is non-magnified reflex sight with "ring and dot" reticle. The P90 is currently in service with military and police forces in over 40 nations, such as Austria, Canada, France and the United States. In the United States, the P90 is in use with over 200 law enforcement agencies, including the US Secret Service. It's biggest advantages are compact size, very low recoil and high velocity ammunition, which allows for reliable piercing of level IV plates (if AP rounds are used). However, the P90 received critique for it's insufficient lethality, as the small 5.7mm bullets have disappointing terminal ballistics and deal relatively low damage. In The Zone, it is sometimes used by mercenary squads and foreign expeditions, who praise the P90 for it's compact size, low weight and ability to pierce even heavy armor.

%c[0,170,170,170]PL-14 ("Pistolet Lebedeva", Lebedev's Pistol) is a Russian semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x19mm cartridge. It was designed as a high-quality handgun for sporting and military purposes. Lebedev PL-14 pistol is short recoil operated, locked breech handgun that uses modified Browning HP-type locking. Frame is made from aluminum alloy, and features extremely low bore axis, carefully calculated grip shape and angle that leads to great “pointability”, and minimal overall thickness of the gun (only 28mm across the widest part – the grip). Low bore axis reduce the recoil of the pistol. All controls (manual safeties, slide release levers and magazine release buttons) are fully ambidextrous. Trigger is of Double Action Only type, with concealed hammer. Trigger pull is short and consistent, with pull weight of 4kg and overall trigger travel of 7mm. The PL-15-01 variant features Striker-fired Single Action trigger with lighter and shorter pull. Gun is fed from proprietary double stack, single feed magazines with capacity of 15 rounds. Standard fixed sights are dovetailed to the slide. MIL-STD 1913 (Picatinny type) accessory rail is provided on the frame, below the barrel. Overally, the PL-14 is an accurate and effective high quality pistol with novelty design. Only a few were produced so far and serial production is said to soon be started.

%c[0,170,170,170]PP-2000 was developed for and adopted into law enforcement agencies in 2004. It's intended use is as a personal defense weapon - it has compact, simplified construction and has increased parts durability to make it adapted to shoot more powerful 7N21 and 7N31 armor-piercing 9x19mm rounds, which are loaded to very high pressures for improved performance, but cause high stress to weapon parts that can result in increased wear and even breakage. PP-2000 is developed as an answer to western types of PDWs and fills the same niche. It is a compact weapon which can be easily carried or concealed, shoots ammunition which is weaker than assault rifle, but can still penetrate body armor and can shoot in long bursts without big loss in accuracy. The difference is mainly in ammunition used. While P90 and MP7 use small-bore rounds that are visually basically short assault rifle rounds (5.7x28mm and 4.6x30mm) and work as such, the PP-2000 uses standard 9x19mm ammunition, but in modified variants. 7N21 and 7N31 are loaded to very high pressures (+P and +P+) and produce high muzzle velocity. This way they can do the same job as formerly mentioned PDW rounds, but user can also load standard 9x19mm rounds in various types into the weapon if needed - this makes PP-2000 more universal than P90 and MP7. The only advantage is that P90 and MP7 ammunition produces negligible recoil, which allow them to shoot even long bursts without loss of accuracy due to muzzle climb. Still, almost all 9x19mm submachines have controllable recoil and PP-2000 is no different, so it's still not a big issue. Mechanically, PP-2000 is a blowback operated weapon firing from closed bolt which improves accuracy. The bolt is of telescopic type, similar to the one used in Sa vz.26 and later in Uzi SMG.

%c[0,170,170,170]Walther PPK is a German compact semi-automatic pistol chambered in 7.65x17mmSR cartridge. Based on larger Walther PP, the PPK is a very compact pistol designed for concealed carry for police. PPK is an abbreviation for Polizeipistole Kriminalmodell (detective police pistol). The Walther PP/PPK is blowback-operated pistol with a fixed barrel of all-metal construction. The trigger is double-action, with an exposed hammer and a frame-mounted manual safety/decocker. Magazines are single-stack; the magazine release button is usually located at the left side of the frame, just below the slide and in front of the grip panel. These pistols are fitted with a loaded chamber indicator. Walther PPK is a famous and influential design. It is probably best known as the primary weapon of James Bond, but it's importance didn't end on popculture. Several pistols were based on PPK, including Makarov PM, Hungarian FEG PA-63, the Polish P-64 and several more. The PP and PPK were both popular with European police and civilians for being reliable and concealable. During World War II, they were issued to the German military, including the Luftwaffe, as well as the police. Today, the PPK still remains relatively popular as a concealed-carry weapon for it's small dimensions and light ammunition. Some stalkers brought their PPK pistols into The Zone with them, where they are sometimes used as backup pistols due to their compactness, typically carried in the pocket or in ankle holster. PPK and it's small 7.65mm bullets are not very effective vs wild animals and mutants, but can save your life when ambushed by bandits.

%c[0,170,170,170]PTRS-41 is a Soviet anti-tank rifle chambered in a powerful 14.5x114mm cartridge used with success throughout World War II. In the year 1941, operation "Barbarossa" was launched and the Nazi Germany attacked the Soviet Union with Panzer divisions and masses of mechanized infantry. The Soviet anti tank defenses were crippled and they desperately needed a weapon that would give their infantry a chance against German tanks and armored vehicles and would be cheaper and faster to produce than towed anti tank guns. Sergei Simonov designed a semi-automatic weapon that would become a great asset for the Soviets: the PTRS-41 anti-tank rifle. It was a gas-operated firearm that used a powerful 14.5x114mm cartridge, which sent a heavy anti-tank bullet filled with incendiary charge down range with speed of 1013m/s, reaching penetration value of up to 40mm of rolled homogeneous armor on the distance of 100 meters - enough to penetrate side armor of every German tank in early years of war. After German tanks became better armored, the PTRS was used as an anti-materiel rifle. It's high powered round makes it effective in this role, as it can shoot through walls, metal plates and other barriers and incendiary charge allows to effectively destroy equipment. The rifle is however extremely heavy, weighting more than 20kg, and even despite all it's mass the powerful round still has very high recoil, which can cause concussion, disorientation and even dislocate user's shoulder if not handled properly. PTRS is sometimes used in The Zone as a heavy anti-materiel rifle, but it was used with most success as a weapon to dispatch big, dangerous mutants from safe distance - one Duty hunter team allegedly killed a Pseudogiant with only two hits, to the upper torso and then the head, from range of about 620 meters.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]High power scope. Bolt-action mechanism - almost never jams. Rate of fire limited by manual operation. High accuracy. Best used on medium and long range with sniper rounds. %c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]Remington Model 700 is a series of bolt-action centerfire rifles manufactured by Remington Arms since 1962. This variant is standard heavy barrel profile, which improves accuracy and durability for cost of increased weight. After World War II, Remington Arms engineer Merle Walker began designing lower-cost alternatives to the Model 30, which resulted in the Model 721. Improvements to Model 721 created the Model 700 - one of the most famous and popular bolt-action rifles in the world. Remington 700 is a bolt-action rifle using Mauser-style bolt, similarly to famous Kar98k rifle. The bolt operates smoothly, which makes the rifle comfortable and increases rate of fire. It is designed for mass production and isn't as refined as more expensive models, but nonetheless Remington 700 is a solid and reliable rifle with very good accuracy. The M24 and M40 military sniper rifles used by the US Army and USMC are both based on the Model 700 design. Remington 700 variants are also used by police units all around the world. It is also one of the most popular hunting rifles and is often used as a platform for custom tactical rifles, often reaching very high levels of accuracy. In The Zone, Remington 700 rifles are used by hunters and snipers, outfitted with high-power scopes. It is available for cheap and is seen in relatively high numbers. Most stalkers prefer semi-automatic scoped rifles as they're more universal for most situations; however, the bolt-action rifles provide much higher level of precision and those who want to shoot on longer ranges value this precision over sheer firepower and ability to quickly put out follow-up shots.

%c[0,170,170,170]Winchester 70 is a bolt action hunting rifle and one of the most common hunting rifles in the world. It has an iconic place in American sporting culture and has been held in high regard by shooters since it was introduced in 1936, earning the moniker "The Rifleman's Rifle". The action has some design similarities to Mauser designs and it is a development of the earlier Winchester Model 54. Winchester 70 features new, simpler and easier to operate bolt design, simplified construction for quicker and cheaper production, Mauser action and hammer-forged barrel. It is an accurate and reliable rifle and is the main competitor of the famous Remington 700. It is available in multiple calibers and variants. Some W70 rifles were used by police departments and military forces, among them US Marine Corps who used these rifles in Vietnam together with M40 rifles (military variant of Remington 700). W70 is considered a good platform for a hunting rifle, but tactical and sport shooters often value R700 over W70 due to it's higher modification potential and abundance of aftermarket parts. In The Zone the Winchester 70 is used as hunting rifle or cheap yet effective sniper rifle, just like all other classic bolt-action rifles chambered in standard rifle calibers.

%c[0,170,170,170]Springfield M1903 is an American bolt-action rifle chambered in .30-06 Springfield, which served as the US military service rifle before it was replaced by the famed M1 Garand. It was adopted in 1903 and fought in both World Wars (in WWII, USMC didn't get M1 rifles before the end of 1942 and even after this they weren't rearmed with Garands entirely). It also remained as sniper rifle, used with 2.5x or 8x scopes until the early Vietnam war. Springfield M1903 is a rifle based on the German Mauser Gewehr 98 rifle. Just like Gew98 (or more famous Kar98k, which replaced the Gew98), the Springfield rifle is accurate, has smooth working bolt and works very reliably. It was well-liked and valued by those who used it. Two sniper variants were made, the M1903A1 "Marine" with 7.8x Unertl scope and M1903A4 with 2.5x scope. The Marine variant is considered to be a much better rifle, not only due to it's high-power optics, but also due to it's high quality finish and superior accuracy. Today Springfield rifles are used as target or hunting rifles all around the world. In the Europe Springfields are very rare, nonetheless they are sometimes seen. This specimen seems to come from Asia, where it was probably acquired on black market. It was rechambered to .308 Winchester, probably to cut hunting cost, as .308 ammunition is way cheaper and easier to obtain.

%c[0,170,170,170]M14 is an American battle rifle chambered in 7.62x51mm NATO, which for a short time served as a service rifle of US military. Experiences of WWII showed a need for improvements to be made to M1 Garand rifle. It was a good and solid semi-automatic rifle, but there was a lot of room for improvement. US military wanted a rifle with higher capacity (like BAR), using modern ammunition (.308 Win/7.62 NATO) and to be lighter than M1, which was excessively heavy. With higher capacity and better controllability, the M14 was meant to replace several weapon types, both the rifle, carbine, automatic rifle (M1918A2 BAR) and submachine gun - soldiers were to be armed entirely with M14s. However, it proved to be an impossible task to replace all these weapons. M14 was too uncontrollable in rapid fire, so it was useless as SMG and BAR replacement, it also didn't offer much over Garand except for higher magazine size. The M14 was also deemed "completely inferior" to the World War II M1 Garand in a 1962 report by the Department of Defense comptroller. M14 was replaced with M16 assault rifle, which was easier to operate, had very low recoil and was more reliable in most conditions. At the end of Vietnam war, M14 was mostly withdrawn. In general, the M14 was a controversial weapon. It had the accuracy and range of the "old time" military rifles, but was too long, heavy and lacked the automatic fire firepower of a true assault rifle, often required in the modern close combat. M14 was a short stroke gas operated firearm with rotating bolt. The gas system has cut-off feature, which limits the amount of gases used to operate the weapon. The stock was entirely made of wood, the receiver was steel. M14 is an obsolete design now, but it is used as a marksman rifle platform thanks to it's accuracy. It is also popular among hunters, civilian variant is produced by Springfield under M1A name. In The Zone, M14 rifles come from hunters or black market from Southeast Asia and are sometimes, albeit rarely, seen used as hunting rifles or sniper platforms with scopes.

%c[0,170,170,170]M21 is a semi-automatic sniper rifle adapted from M14 rifle. The US Army wanted an accurate sniper rifle during the Vietnam war. The M14 was selected because of its accuracy, reliability, and the ability for a quick follow up shot. As a result, the Rock Island Arsenal converted M14s by adding a Redfield ART Adjustable Ranging Telescope 3–9x scope and providing National Match grade ammunition (7.62 XM-118). M14 is an American battle rifle chambered in 7.62x51mm NATO, which for a short time served as a service rifle of US military. Experiences of WWII showed a need for improvements to be made to M1 Garand rifle. It was a good and solid semi-automatic rifle, but there was a lot of room for improvement. US military wanted a rifle with higher capacity (like BAR), using modern ammunition (.308 Win/7.62 NATO) and to be lighter than M1, which was excessively heavy. With higher capacity and better controllability, the M14 was meant to replace several weapon types, both the rifle, carbine, automatic rifle (M1918A2 BAR) and submachine gun - soldiers were to be armed entirely with M14s. The M14 was also deemed "completely inferior" to the World War II M1 Garand in a 1962 report by the Department of Defense comptroller. M14 was replaced with M16 assault rifle, which was easier to operate, had very low recoil and was more reliable in most conditions. M14 was a short stroke gas operated firearm with rotating bolt. The gas system has cut-off feature, which limits the amount of gases used to operate the weapon. The stock was entirely made of wood, the receiver was steel. M21 is still used as a sniper rifle, M14s with scopes are also popular among hunters and sport marksmen. Few of military M21 rifles reached The Zone, where they are liked for very good optical sights, which provide much better precision than low-power scopes of SVD rifles.

%c[0,170,170,170]Vis wz. 35 is a World War II-era Polish semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x19mm cartridge, designed and developed by FB Radom for Polish military in 1935. The design was generally based on American firearms inventor John Browning's Browning Hi-Power design. Vis was accepted in 1935 and was the service pistol of Polish Army. After the Nazi Germany defeated Poland in 1939, they occupied FB Radom and produced these pistols for their own use. More than 360 thousands of these pistols were produced, with most being captured by Germans. The Vis pistol is a single-action, hammer-fired, locked-breech design. The control on the slide is a decocking mechanism that releases the hammer while camming the firing pin up into the slide. Vis is considered one of the finest pistols of World War II. It's advantages are high accuracy, high reliability and very high production quality. When in German service, they were usually used by officers and soldiers of elite formations, like Fallschirmjaegers. Vis' drawbacks are typical for pistols of it's time and include low capacity of 8 rounds and relatively heavy weight because of all-steel construction. Nonetheless, when compared to other WWII designs, Vis is definitely one of the best pistols of that time, on par with M1911 and Browning HP. Today, wz. 35 pistols are very valued and reach high prices on collector market. Some of them survived the war in rural areas, later reaching the black market with low prices, from where they reached The Zone. Like other pistols of this type, Vis is considered a solid choice for those who don't have more money to spare on a modern pistol.

%c[0,170,170,170]Vis wz. 35 is a World War II-era Polish semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x19mm cartridge, designed and developed by FB Radom for Polish military in 1935. The design was generally based on American firearms inventor John Browning's Browning Hi-Power design. Vis was accepted in 1935 and was the service pistol of Polish Army. After the Nazi Germany defeated Poland in 1939, they occupied FB Radom and produced these pistols for their own use. More than 360 thousands of these pistols were produced, with most being captured by Germans. The Vis pistol is a single-action, hammer-fired, locked-breech design. The control on the slide is a decocking mechanism that releases the hammer while camming the firing pin up into the slide. Vis is considered one of the finest pistols of World War II. It's advantages are high accuracy, high reliability and very high production quality. When in German service, they were usually used by officers and soldiers of elite formations, like Fallschirmjaegers. Vis' drawbacks are typical for pistols of it's time and include low capacity of 8 rounds and relatively heavy weight because of all-steel construction. Nonetheless, when compared to other WWII designs, Vis is definitely one of the best pistols of that time, on par with M1911 and Browning HP. Today, wz. 35 pistols are very valued and reach high prices on collector market. Some of them survived the war in rural areas, later reaching the black market with low prices, from where they reached The Zone. Like other pistols of this type, Vis is considered a solid choice for those who don't have more money to spare on a modern pistol.

%c[0,170,170,170]Remington 870 is an American pump-action shotgun developed in 1950s by Remington Arms. It was the fourth major design in a series of Remington pump shotguns, which weren't very successful, especially in comparison to the famous Winchester Model 12. Remington sought to correct that in 1950 by introducing a modern, streamlined, rugged, reliable, and relatively inexpensive shotgun – the 870. The 870 features a bottom-loading, side ejecting receiver. Tubular magazine is located under the barrel, and, depending on the version and gauge, may hold from 3 to 8 cartridges. Model 870 was produced in multiple variants, barrel length versions and chamberings. It was used widely by civilian gun owners, hunters and in law enforcement agencies and police departments all around the world. More than 11 million of these shotguns were produced. Pump action shotguns are popular in both the USA and Europe, and some stalkers brought these weapons, often legally owned, along with them into The Zone, where they are primarily used for defense against wild animals and mutants or hunting them. Like all other shotguns, the Remington 870 is liked for the sheer power that the 12 gauge shells provide.

%c[0,170,170,170]Witness Protection model is a shortened variant of Remington 870, the American pump-action shotgun developed in 1950s by Remington Arms. It was the fourth major design in a series of Remington pump shotguns, which weren't very successful, especially in comparison to the famous Winchester Model 12. Remington sought to correct that in 1950 by introducing a modern, streamlined, rugged, reliable, and relatively inexpensive shotgun – the 870. The 870 features a bottom-loading, side ejecting receiver. Tubular magazine is located under the barrel, and, depending on the version and gauge, may hold from 3 to 8 cartridges. Model 870 was produced in multiple variants, barrel length versions and chamberings. It was used widely by civilian gun owners, hunters and in law enforcement agencies and police departments all around the world. More than 11 million of these shotguns were produced. Pump action shotguns are popular in both the USA and Europe, and some stalkers brought these weapons, often legally owned, along with them into The Zone, where they are primarily used for defense against wild animals and mutants or hunting them. Shortened shotguns like R870WP are used exclusively for personal defense, as they doesn't have enough range and velocity (due to shorter barrel muzzle velocity is lower and the projectiles have less energy than when shot from longer barreled shotguns) to be used effectively for hunting. It can however deal very high damage in short range and potentially bring down most mutants or human attackers in one well placed shot. It is regarded as a very effective weapon against snorks, stray dogs and other mutants who rely on ambushes and quick leaps to attack their victim, as the short and compact shotgun can be quickly drawn and is very maneuverable. Most stalkers prefer cheaper double-barrel sawn-off shotguns for this task, but shortened shotguns like Witness Protection model have slightly better handling and higher capacity.

%c[0,170,170,170]Stevens Model 620 is an American pump-action hammerless shotgun designed by famous genius gun designer John Browning. This shotgun is a hammerless, pump action, take-down design with a tubular magazine which holds 5 shells. All models can also be slam fired: the shotgun has no trigger disconnector and shells can be fired one after the other simply by working the slide if the trigger is held down. Model 620 was produced in trench gun variant for military and served in World War II, Korea and Vietnam war. About 200 000 of these guns were produced and they remain used until today as hunting weapons. Model 620 is considered a very well made and reliable shotgun of very high quality. Pump action shotguns are popular in both the USA and Europe, and some stalkers brought these weapons, often legally owned, along with them into The Zone, where they are primarily used for defense against wild animals and mutants or hunting them. Like all other shotguns, the Stevens M620 is liked for the sheer power that the 12 gauge shells provide.

%c[0,170,170,170]Ithaca Model 37 is an American pump-action shotgun made in large numbers for the civilian, military, and police purposes. It utilizes a novel combination ejection/loading port on the bottom of the gun which leaves the sides closed to the elements. The Model 37 is considered one of the most durable and reliable shotguns ever produced. The Ithaca 37 is based on a 1915 patent by the famous firearms designer John Browning, initially marketed as the Remington Model 17. Made in many different models, the Ithaca 37 has the longest production run for a pump-action shotgun in history, surpassing that of the Winchester Model 12 that had originally inspired Ithaca to produce pump-action shotguns. M37 has classic design, with pump-action mechanism and tubular magazine under the barrel. Pump action shotguns are popular in both the USA and Europe, and some stalkers brought these weapons, often legally owned, along with them into The Zone, where they are primarily used for defense against wild animals and mutants or hunting them. Like all other shotguns, the Ithaca M37 is liked for the sheer power that the 12 gauge shells provide.

%c[0,170,170,170]Kel-Tec RFB (Rifle, Forward-ejection, Bullpup) is a bullpup semi-automatic rifle produced since 2009 by Kel-Tec Industries of Florida. RFB is chambered in 7.62x51mm NATO and uses metric FAL magazines which insert straight into the magazine well. It uses a short-stroke gas piston operating system. The rifle uses a patented forward-ejection system via a tube placed over the barrel that ejects the spent case forwards, over the handguard of the rifle. Empty cases remain in the ejection chute until either the weapon is tilted downwards, the charging handle is operated, or they are pushed out by following cases - system similar to the one employed in FN F2000 assault rifle. The RFB is delivered without iron sights. A mil-spec Picatinny rail is provided for mounting a wide range of optics and tactical accessories. The barrel of the RFB is not fully free floated, it instead serves as the rigid "spine" of the weapon, to which all other components are attached (either directly or through other components). Advantages of RFB are compactness of bullpup system and light weight, it also has pretty good accuracy. RFB rifles are liked by hunters and target shooters, including those in The Zone, who like high power of 7.62x51mm rounds, especially for hunting wild animals and mutants.

%c[0,170,170,170]RPD is a Soviet belt fed light machine gun chambered in 7.62x39mm M43 cartridge. It was the first light machine gun that used the intermediate rounds and had a handguard to make it more ergonomic and allow firing from the hip - low recoil from intermediate cartridge and easier handling made it more universal than other portable machine guns of these times, such as MG42. It was developed in 1944 as a light machine gun chambered in 7.62x39mm M43 cartridge as a more universal replacement for DP-28 light machine gun, which used full-power 7.62x54mmR ammunition stored in pan magazines. While it was quickly replaced in Soviet military by RPK light machine gun, it became adopted by multiple countries who received them as military aid. It was most notably used as the service machine gun of North Vietnamese Army and gained respect of American troops. Mechanically, RPD is a gas operated firearm which uses long stroke gas piston with bolt locking system with locking flaps, similar to the one used in the DP-27 light machine gun. The weapon is fed from the belt of 50 rounds, which is stored in a so called belt holder (it's not technically a magazine). Each belt holder holds two such belts linked together, which provides ammo capacity of 100 rounds - that's more than twice as much as it's predecessor, the DP-27. The weapon has a heavy, 520mm (20") long barrel, which allows for prolonged firing, however the lack of quick-change mechanism limits it's practical firepower. It is also prone to jamming, which led to it's withdrawal from Soviet army. It is however lighter than typical LMG, easier to handle and has high capacity. All these advantages make it well liked in The Zone - thanks to it's sheer firepower it is often used when hunting hordes of mutants, it's also often employed on outposts and camps as defensive weapon.

%c[0,170,170,170]DP-28 is a Soviet light machine gun designed by Vasily Degtyarev in 1920s, chambered in 7.62x54mmR cartridge. It was adopted by Red Army in 1927, eventually becoming one of the most famous weapons of the WWII, later replaced by RPD. DP was cheap and simple LMG. Mechanically, it is an open bolt, gas operated weapon with long stroke gas piston, located under the barrel, which operates a bolt with two side-mounted locking flaps. Ammunition is fed from the top, from unique pan magazine, which holds 47 rounds. Among it's important parts are flash hider, bipod and heavy barrel. Rate of fire is about 550-600rpm, which places it on par with typical magazine-fed LMGs of that era. DP-28 has simple, but sturdy construction and magazine of relatively high capacity - contemporary magazine-fed LMGs, like BAR, Bren or ZB-26 usually held 20-30 rounds in magazine. However, DP also has it's flaws. It's reliability wasn't perfect and the weapon was prone to overheating. Recoil spring was located below the barrel, which made it possible to become damaged from high temperature. The barrel is removable, but requires a tool for removal, and as such can not be considered quick-changeable, like in Bren or ZB-26. Overally, the DP is considered a good weapon, but user must be aware of it's flaws. Near the end of WWII DP-28 was modernized and called DPM, with biggest difference being relocation of recoil spring to the rear and addition of pistol grip. It was also base to another weapon, called RP-46, which was essentially a belt-fed DPM. After WWII the RPD took over as main LMG in Red Army, but DP-28 was used in many countries of Eastern Bloc and those that sided with them, most notably the Yugoslavia, China and Vietnam. Today, a lot of DP-28 are sold as surplus, and some appeared in The Zone. It's heavy weight make it a rather poor choice for scavengers and explorers, but they are liked by mutant hunters due to it's hard-hitting cartridge, which provides higher range and causes more tissue damage than intermediate rounds of RPD and RPK.

%c[0,170,170,170]Ruger Mark III is a rimfire semi-automatic pistol introduced in 1949 as the first product manufactured by Sturm, Ruger and Co. It is marketed as an inexpensive .22 caliber rimfire intended for casual sport and target shooting, and plinking. The pistol's barrel is made from steel bar and is threaded into the receiver which is made from steel tube. The barrel is not removable without machining, though. The layout is similar to the Luger P08, although the operating mechanism was originally copied from the Japanese Nambu pistol. .22 caliber pistols are commonly used by civilians for training and recreational shooting. Some stalkers brought rimfire pistols with them to The Zone, since obviously they're better than nothing, but they're too weak to reliably bring down bigger animals. They are sometimes used to kill rats, tushkanos and crows.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]Advanced modular battle rifle. Moderate-high recoil. Should be used with single, well placed shots or short bursts. High damage output. Best on medium and long range. %c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]SCAR is a modern modular rifle designed and developed by FN Herstal from Belgium for the USSOCOM requirements. Two main versions exist, assault rifle SCAR-L chambered in 5.56x45mm and battle rifle SCAR-H in 7.62x51mm NATO. Both are available in short, medium and long barreled variants. Mechanically, SCAR is based on the F2000 assault rifle. It's a gas operated firearm with short stroke piston and rotating bolt using tappet system. Upper receiver is made of aluminum and upper receiver is from strengthened polymer; same with folding, adjustable "boot-shaped" stock. SCAR-L and SCAR-H use similar upper receivers that differ only in the size of ejection port. Other different parts include caliber-specific bolt, barrel, and lower receiver with integral magazine housing. Parts commonality is at astonishing 90%. Barrels are quick-detachable, and whole procedure needs only basic tools and takes only few minutes. Barrel has threading and has an effective muzzle device fitted by default, which significantly lowers the recoil of the rifle. Default sights are foldable and removable, on whole length of receiver there's an universal rail allowing for mounting of any type of optics. SCAR is currently considered one of the best modern rifles available. Advantages of SCAR are low recoil, good accuracy, high reliability and modularity level. SCARs are currently used by multiple special forces teams, most notably from USA, Germany, France and Finland. SCAR is also currently a service rifle of Belgian forces. In The Zone, SCAR rifles are sometimes used by PMC groups, in both L and H variants. They are considered very effective, light and dependable weapons and are very sought after. SCAR-H are especially liked for their powerful round, which make them very effective against mutants and enemies in body armor.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]Strongly built, all-steel pistol. High magazine capacity. SA/DA trigger provides higher practical accuracy. Exceptional reliability. %c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]P226 is a 9x19mm semi-automatic pistol developed by SIG Sauer GmbH as an improvement of P220 pistol. It was designed for requirements of US military for new service pistols, but Beretta 92 won the trials due to lower price, despite P226 being superior construction. Nonetheless, it was a successful design and went on to become one of the most popular service pistols all around the world. Mechanically, the P226 is a short-recoil operated, Browning-type locked-breech pistol, just like P220. Differences are in slightly redesigned shape and addition of double stack magazines, which can hold 15 to 18 rounds, depending on magazine type. Default variant is chambered in 9x19mm Parabellum, but there are also .40SW and .357SIG versions. The slide is milled from a single piece of stainless steel with Nitron coating for superior protection from rust and elements, and also to allow shooting hotter loads of .357 SIG and +P 9x19mm. The frame of most models is made from hard anodized aluminum alloy. Addition of decocker allows the pistol to be carried with a round in the chamber, which is very important for a concealed carry weapon. Overally, the P226 is considered to be one of the best pistols currently available. It's extremely durable and resistant to abuse, and provides flawless performance even in harshest environments. It is acclaimed by many special operation forces all around the world and became service weapon of numerous militaries and law enforcement agencies, including those from USA, Germany, UK, Switzerland, Finland, Poland, Netherlands and many more. In The Zone, the P226 is often used by various mercenary groups, as well as special forces operators, foreign expeditions security and various free stalkers who value it's high reliability and effectiveness, despite it's high price compared to other modern 9x19mm pistols.

%c[0,170,170,170]SR-1M pistol, known also as Gyurza (Russian: "Blunt-nosed viper", species of venomous snake - Macrovipera turanica) or Vektor is a semi-automatic handgun designed to be able to fight opponents wearing body armor. It is chambered in 9x21mm Gyurza cartridge, which is able to penetrate all kinds of soft body armor, which stopped standard 9x19mm Para and even 7.62x25mm TT rounds. 9x21mm Gyurza cartridge is more powerful than 9x19mm Parabellum, default load contains an armor piercing bullet with hardened steel core, which allows to penetrate body armor on distance of up to 150 meters. Initially SR-1M was developed by TsNIITochMash (famous for AS and VSS rifles) on request of Russian army, who wanted to have a pistol that could kill enemies wearing body armor on distance of 50 meters. The army lost interest in it, but the design was picked up by MVD and in 1996 it was adopted by Federal Security Service (FSB) and various other law enforcment agencies, including Russian elite police units (SWAT equivalent). The SR-1M is a short recoil operated, locked breech pistol, similar in function to Beretta 92 or Walther P38 pistols. It fires a powerful round, but it's quality of finish leaves a lot to desire and it is reported to have reliability problems. Some of these pistols can be rarely found on the black market in The Zone, but the problems with ammunition supply make it a questionable choice.

%c[0,170,170,170]SR-2M Veresk (Russian: Heather) is a submachine gun/machine pistol chambered in 9x21mm Gyurza cartridge, which is more powerful than comparable 9x19mm Parabellum round. SR-2 was developed in the late 1990s by TsNIITochMash (famous for AS and VSS rifles) on request of Russian Federal Security Service (FSB). It was meant to be a compact, concealable personal defense weapon that would be able to penetrate all kinds of soft body armor, which stopped standard 9x19mm Para and even 7.62x25mm TT rounds - similarly to western constructions like P90 or MP7. 9x21mm Gyurza cartridge is more powerful than 9x19mm Parabellum. Default load contains an armor piercing bullet with hardened steel core, which allows to penetrate body armor on distance of up to 150 meters - all this while keeping very compact size. Latest version, the SR-2M became adopted in early 2000s by FSB and various law enforcement agencies in Russia, but after successful development of armor-piercing loads for standard 9x19mm Parabellum cartridge, the 9x21mm Gyurza and SR-2M fell out of favor - weapons designed for 9x19mm AP rounds, like Vityaz SMG, are more universal, since they can also use standard 9x19mm ammunition. Mechanically, SR-2M is a pretty unique weapon, since unlike other submachine guns it is gas operated - it's action is based on SR-3M Vikhr assault rifle, but is said to be relatively reliable. Overally, SR-2M is a nice and effective weapon, but is less universal than comparable submachine guns chambered in 9x19mm Parabellum.

%c[0,170,170,170]SR-25 is a semi-automatic sniper rifle developed by Knight's Armament Company and Eugene Stoner (famous for his AR-10 and AR-15 rifles). It is loosely based on Stoner's AR-10, rebuilt in its original 7.62x51mm NATO caliber. The USSOCOM took interest in the SR-25, particularly in its high magazine capacity and faster engagement time compared to bolt-action rifles. After some modifications, SOCOM adopted the SR-25 as the Mk 11 Mod 0 in May 2000, and then it was adopted by US Army as M110 SASS. Mechanically it is just like AR-10 - a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. It is less reliable than comparable designs when dirty, but the closed system very effectively seals it from the outside, which prevents any dirt and mud from preventing the internals - this means that the AR-10s are less prone to external elements than eg. AKM. SR-25 is made from the beggining as a DMR/sniper rifle. Heavy, accurized barrel is free-floating, which, together with match trigger, provides very high accuracy (for a semi-automatic rifle) at 2 MoA and less. SR-25 has flat-top receiver with rails which allow for mounting any type of optical sights. Advantages of SR-25 are higher accuracy, better ergonomics and higher reliability than most of other comparable semi-automatic sniper rifles. Thanks to free-floating barrel it's accuracy is better than that of rifles such as M21 or SVD, and the rifle itself is easy to handle, light and comfortable to shoot. Overally, the M110 is considered one of the best semi-automatic sniper rifles in the world, topped only by sniper variants of SCAR and HK417, which currently replace it in US military. SR-25 is used by multiple countries and is also well liked on civilian market, despite it's high price. In The Zone, SR-25 rifles are rare, but very sought after and considered top of the shelf weapon. Some of them came with mercenary teams who use them as designated marksman rifles together with other similar designs.

%c[0,170,170,170]Sten is a family of British submachine guns chambered in 9x19mm and used extensively by British and Commonwealth forces throughout World War II and shortly after. They had a simple design and very low production cost, so they were also effective insurgency weapons for resistance groups. STEN is an acronym, from the names of the weapon's chief designers, Major Reginald V. Shepherd and Harold Turpin, and EN for Enfield. Mechanically it was blowback operated, automatic weapon that fired from the open bolt. The tubular receiver and the barrel shroud were made from rolled steel. The gun was fed from left side mounted box magazines. The stock was of skeleton type, made from steel. Sten was awfully crude, it's quality was low, it was prone to jamming and had low accuracy, but was cheap and easy to manufacture. There were six variants of Sten submachine gun. Sten Mk.II, the most common and well-known variant, was also most widely made, with about 2 millions of Mark 2 being made during the war. Sten Mk.V was a more refined version made for paratroopers and special forces, it had wooden stock and front grip, and, uncommonly for a submachine gun, also a bayonet mount. Over four million Stens in various versions were produced. A lot of them were also homemade by partizans, freedom fighters and criminals. Plans for Sten were sent all over occupied Europe and even now are circulating in the web. Sten SMG variants are some of the most common weapons on the black market, popular among those who can't get more modern weapons. In The Zone, Sten SMGs are somewhat popular as cheap weapons for personal defense, used mostly by stalkers who can't spare much for sidearm. Apart from original units that survived the war, some of those available on black market are produced locally in workshops by talented technicians.
