%c[0,170,170,170]SV-98 is a Russian bolt-action sniper rifle chambered in 7.62x54mmR cartridge, developed by Izhmash in the late 1990s. It entered the service in Russian military under name 6V10 Sniper System in 2003 and to this day it serves in Russian army as service sniper rifle. It was first used in war in Chechnya with good results. SV-98 sniper rifle is manually operated, rotary bolt action gun; the receiver is made from steel and the stock is made from laminated wood. Stock has characteristic thumb-hole "grip". Heavy match-grade barrel is free-floating and can be fitted with quick-detachable flash hider or suppressor. Trigger is very light, with pull weight of only 1-1.5kg. The rifle is said to be capable of about 1.15 MoA accuracy with 7N14 ammunition, which is slightly worse, but very close to it's western equivalent, the M24 rifle chambered in 7.62x51mm NATO ammunition. Optical sights are mounted using integrated Picatinny rail on top of the receiver, the rifle also has back-up iron sights; standard optics in Russian army are PKS-07 7x sight with fixed magnification and Giperon 1P59 3-10x variable magnification scope. Advantages of SV-98 are it's high reliability and accuracy, it's main drawback is heavy weight at above 7kg. SV-98 is currently in use with Russian army and law enforcement agencies, Armenian military and Syrian government forces. Some of these rifles came to The Zone with few of PMC teams, which can hint at least some of the Mercenaries groups in The Zone are linked to Russia's government.

%c[0,170,170,170]GOL-Sniper Magnum is a bolt-action sniper rifle designed by the German company Gol-Matic GmbH of Birkenau, Hessen. It is developed from Austrian Steyr SSG 69, Austrian military's service sniper rifle known for it's very high accuracy. The rifle was designed by professional German gunsmith Gottfried Prechtl, who specializes in custom Mauser rifles. Magnum caliber GOL-Sniper rifles are based on custom Magnum Mauser actions, manufactured by Prechtl, and fitted with Lothar Walther precision barrels. The bolt-action is based on Mauser M 98 Magnum system, which was introduced in the late 19th century on the Mauser Gewehr 98. Each rifle is custom made per requisitions of every customer, whether they be for tactical or sporting purposes, therefore there are many options and configurations. A Sto-Con walnut stock forms the body of the rifle which is mounted with a Lothar Walther precision barrel and Mauser bolt. The walnut stock increases the flexibility of the rifle butt and therefore reduces recoil allowing for more precision when shooting. These rifles are used by several German police units, as well as a numbers of European target and sport shooters. In The Zone, GOL rifles are seen extremely rarely, only units known are in hands of mercenaries who use them for long-range precision killing. Just like any other rifle chambered in .338 Lapua Magnum, GOL is very powerful, capable of knocking out targets in heavy body armor on ranges beyond 1000 meters. It is used to kill enemies in heavy body armor or to shoot dangerous mutants from long distance on which shooters themselves stay safe.

%c[0,170,170,170]SVT-40 ("Samozaryadnaya Vintovka Tokareva", Tokarev's Self-loading Rifle) is a Soviet WWII-era semi-automatic rifle chambered in 7.62x54mmR cartridge. It was one of the first successful semi-automatic rifles developed and it influenced many designs in the later years. SVT-40 is a gas operated, magazine fed self-loading rifle. It uses a short piston stroke gas action located above the barrel. The gas piston has its own return string which moved back when gun was fired. It gave a quick and powerful stroke to the bolt carrier, which carried the bolt under it, providing a reliable action even in harsh environment. Gas system had 5 settings to allow user adjust to different conditions and improve reliability. SVT can be reloaded either by replacing the 10-round magazine or by using 5-round stripper clips of the Mosin-Nagant, which can be inserted with no problem after bolt is locked back. SVT-40 has an one-piece wooden stock with shorter forend and separate upper handguard. Sighting is done by a post-type front sight and tangent type open rear sights, sniper variants had a rail to attach PU telescopic sight which was almost identical to the one used on Mosin-Nagant sniper rifles. The SVT-40 was reliable and effective weapon. It was ergonomic and had lower recoil than similar weapons. German soldiers considered SVT-40 a great weapon, often picked it up as trophy and used them in fight. 1.6 million of these rifles were produced. Production was partially stopped in WWII to give priority to less effective, but cheaper Mosin rifles. SVT-40 influenced a lot of future designs, such as Gewehr 43, FN-49 and the famous FN-FAL, widely considered one of the best rifles of cold war. In The Zone, SVT rifles come from the black market, where they are sold as a substitute to more modern battle rifles. Despite it's age, the SVT-40 is still a reliable and effective rifle. It's powerful round retains energy even on higher distances and, just like other full-size rifles, when used with soft-point ammunition the SVT can be very effective vs animals and mutants.

%c[0,170,170,170]SW459 is one of many variants of SW Model 59 - a double-action semi-automatic pistol introduced in 1971. It was developed by Smith and Wesson from the earlier SW Model 39 by adapting a 14-round capacity stagger-stack magazine. It was designed for the US Navy as a large-capacity version of the SW Model 39, the basis of their Mark 22 "Mark 22 Hush Puppy" silenced pistol. In 1965, the US Navy commissioned a version of the SW Model 39 that could take the 13-round magazine of the Browning Hi-Power. In early 1970, a dozen experimental all-stainless-steel prototypes were made and were issued to Navy SEAL commandos for evaluation in the field. The firearm was however not adopted, but entered civilian market instead. Three main variants of SW M59 exist, SW459 has alloy frame with blued finish, SW559 is all-steel with blued finish and SW659 has alloy frame with stainless steel finish. Mechanically, Model 59 is a recoil operated, locked breech firearm, utilizing Browning Hi-Power type locking principle and double action trigger with slide-mounted safety switch. It is considered a good and affordable medium-shelf pistol. Smith and Wesson is famous for their revolvers, but their semi-automatic pistols are also popular in the USA. In Europe, the Smith and Wesson's pistols aren't popular and are very rare to see, so also in The Zone they're very rare and stalkers usually prefer other weapons that are more familiar to them. Nonetheless, the 459 is a solid pistol and will not disappoint it's owner.

%c[0,170,170,170]Tavor is a bullpup assault rifle chambered in 5.56x45mm NATO, developed in the late 1990s by IWI for Israeli military. It is made to be a light and maneuverable, but also reliable and rugged rifle to work well in harsh conditions of desert terrain. It is available in several configurations, most notably TAR-21 (rifle, with 18" barrel) and CTAR-21 (carbine, with 15" barrel). Mechanically, TAR-21 is a gas operated, selective fire, magazine fed assault rifle of bullpup configuration. It utilizes a now-common long piston stroke, rotating bolt action (similar to AK-47), with the gas piston rigidly attached to the bolt carrier. The TAR-21 has no separate receiver. Instead, all parts are mounted within the high impact-resistant plastic housing, reinforced with steel inserts where appropriate. Early production TAR-21 rifles had no iron sights, but this has been fixed with introduction of the folded front and rear sights on current production models. Tavor rifles are fitted with the standard accessory rail on the top, which allows for any optical sight to be attached. It's long barrel allows for higher effective range and gives bullets high velocity, which means they tumble and fragment in tissue more efficiently, dealing higher damage. The weapon is partially ambidextrous. The ejection ports are made on both sides of the weapon, and the right or the left side ejection can be selected by installing the bolt with the ejector mounted on the right or on the left, respectively. This is higher level of ambidexterity than of older bullpups, but isn't as advanced as in more modern constructions, like F2000 or RFB; unlike these constructions, the shooter can't change hands during the fight. Overally, TAR-21 is a very effective and reliable weapon. It is considered to be one of the best bullpup assault rifles. In The Zone, Tavor rifles are used by mercenaries and stalkers alike. It's available on both legal and black market, however for a high price. It's well liked for it's great handling and low weight, which is important on long trips.

%c[0,170,170,170]X-95 is a modernized modular assault rifle based on battle-proven TAR-21 - a bullpup assault rifle chambered in 5.56x45mm NATO, developed in the late 1990s by IWI for Israeli military. It was made to be a light and maneuverable, but also reliable and rugged rifle to work well in harsh conditions of desert terrain. X-95 slightly differs from TAR-21, mostly in shape of polymer housing, shorter barrel and few other details. Its modular construction allows it to be quickly converted from 5.56x45mm to 9x19mm caliber. Mechanically, the X-95, just like TAR-21, is a gas operated, selective fire, magazine fed assault rifle of bullpup configuration. It utilizes a now-common long piston stroke, rotating bolt action (similar to AK-47), with the gas piston rigidly attached to the bolt carrier. X-95 has no separate receiver. Instead, all parts are mounted within the high impact-resistant plastic housing, reinforced with steel inserts where appropriate. Tavor rifles are fitted with the standard accessory rail on the top, which allows for any optical sight to be attached. The weapon is partially ambidextrous. The ejection ports are made on both sides of the weapon, and the right or the left side ejection can be selected by installing the bolt with the ejector mounted on the right or on the left, respectively. This is higher level of ambidexterity than of older bullpups, but isn't as advanced as in more modern constructions, like F2000 or RFB; unlike these constructions, the shooter can't change hands during the fight. X-95 is very compact and easy to maneuver, but short, 13" barrel doesn't provide enough muzzle velocity for 5.56mm bullet to be effective on longer ranges, as it relies on velocity to yaw and tumble in the tissue. Overally, X-95 is a very effective and reliable weapon. Together with other Tavor variants, it is considered to be one of the best bullpup assault rifles. In The Zone, Tavor rifles are used by mercenaries and stalkers alike. It's available on both legal and black market, however for a high price. It's well liked for it's great handling and low weight, which is important on long trips.

%c[0,170,170,170]Fort-224 is Ukrainian variant of TAR-21 rifle, rechambered to 5.45x39mm caliber. Tavor is a bullpup assault rifle chambered in 5.56x45mm NATO, developed in the late 1990s by IWI for Israeli military. It is made to be a light and maneuverable, but also reliable and rugged rifle to work well in harsh conditions of desert terrain. It is available in several configurations, most notably TAR-21 (rifle, with 18" barrel) and CTAR-21 (carbine, with 15" barrel). Mechanically, TAR-21 is a gas operated, selective fire, magazine fed assault rifle of bullpup configuration. It utilizes a now-common long piston stroke, rotating bolt action (similar to AK-47), with the gas piston rigidly attached to the bolt carrier. The TAR-21 has no separate receiver. Instead, all parts are mounted within the high impact-resistant plastic housing, reinforced with steel inserts where appropriate. Early production TAR-21 rifles had no iron sights, but this has been fixed with introduction of the folded front and rear sights on current production models. Tavor rifles are fitted with the standard accessory rail on the top, which allows for any optical sight to be attached. The weapon is partially ambidextrous. The ejection ports are made on both sides of the weapon, and the right or the left side ejection can be selected by installing the bolt with the ejector mounted on the right or on the left, respectively. This is higher level of ambidexterity than of older bullpups, but isn't as advanced as in more modern constructions, like F2000 or RFB; unlike these constructions, the shooter can't change hands during the fight. Overally, TAR-21 is a very effective and reliable weapon. It is considered to be one of the best bullpup assault rifles. In The Zone, Tavor rifles are used by mercenaries and stalkers alike. It's available on both legal and black market, however for a high price. Fort-224 is a popular choice due to it's 5.45x39mm chambering, which is more common and cheaper in Ukraine than 5.56x45mm ammo. It's well liked for it's great handling and low weight, which is important on long trips.

%c[0,170,170,170]Tavor is a bullpup assault rifle chambered in 5.56x45mm NATO, developed in the late 1990s by IWI for Israeli military. It is made to be a light and maneuverable, but also reliable and rugged rifle to work well in harsh conditions of desert terrain. It is available in several configurations, most notably TAR-21 (rifle, with 18" barrel) and CTAR-21 (carbine, with 15" barrel). Mechanically, TAR-21 is a gas operated, selective fire, magazine fed assault rifle of bullpup configuration. It utilizes a now-common long piston stroke, rotating bolt action (similar to AK-47), with the gas piston rigidly attached to the bolt carrier. The TAR-21 has no separate receiver. Instead, all parts are mounted within the high impact-resistant plastic housing, reinforced with steel inserts where appropriate. Early production TAR-21 rifles had no iron sights, but this has been fixed with introduction of the folded front and rear sights on current production models. Tavor rifles are fitted with the standard accessory rail on the top, which allows for any optical sight to be attached. It's long barrel allows for higher effective range and gives bullets high velocity, which means they tumble and fragment in tissue more efficiently, dealing higher damage. The weapon is partially ambidextrous. The ejection ports are made on both sides of the weapon, and the right or the left side ejection can be selected by installing the bolt with the ejector mounted on the right or on the left, respectively. This is higher level of ambidexterity than of older bullpups, but isn't as advanced as in more modern constructions, like F2000 or RFB; unlike these constructions, the shooter can't change hands during the fight. Overally, TAR-21 is a very effective and reliable weapon. It is considered to be one of the best bullpup assault rifles. In The Zone, Tavor rifles are used by mercenaries and stalkers alike. It's available on both legal and black market, however for a high price. It's well liked for it's great handling and low weight, which is important on long trips.

%c[0,170,170,170]M1928 is a primary variant of the Thompson, an American submachine gun, invented by John T. Thompson in 1918, that became infamous during the Prohibition era, being a signature weapon of various crime syndicates in the United States. Later on it became the service weapon of US military as the primary submachine gun in the World War II. M1928 has front grip and muzzle device mounted by default. Mechanically, Thompson is a fully-automatic firearm using delayed blowback action known as a ‘Blish lock’. Late-war M1 variant uses simple blowback action instead. Whole receiver is machined. Furniture included a pistol grip, detachable wooden shoulder stock and either a detachable forward grip or horizontal forearm. Sights on pre-war models included advanced sights adjustable for ranges up to 500m and windage. Since practical range was no more than 100m, wartime models (M1928A1, M1 and M1A1) used a simplified fixed aperture rear sight. Construction is complicated and required high workload, which made Thompson very expensive and unfit for a military weapon (later on it was replaced by M3 Grease Gun). Thompson was well liked for it's high firepower and controllability, but soldiers often complained about it's excessive weight at almost 5kg, which made it hard to carry on long distances. On the other hand, heavy weight and effective muzzle device reduced it's recoil, making it very easy to shoot even on longer bursts, despite it's rather powerful ammunition. Thompsons were used by US military for as long as to Vietnam war. They were also used by many countries after the war. Some of them were sent to USSR for Lend-Lease and it is probably from there that these weapons reached The Zone. While stalkers usually prefer lighter weapons for scavenging trips, the Thompsons are liked for their high firepower and sometimes used as anti-mutant weapons due to their high rate of fire and effective round, coupled with ability to use higher capacity drum magazines to further increase their capabilities. Nonetheless these weapons are rare in The Zone and see only limited use.

Thompson in 1918, that became infamous during the Prohibition era, being a signature weapon of various crime syndicates in the United States. Later on it became the service weapon of US military as the primary submachine gun in the World War II. M1A1 differs from M1928 mainly by simplified front handguard instead of front grip and lack of muzzle device. Mechanically, Thompson is a fully-automatic firearm using delayed blowback action known as a ‘Blish lock’. Late-war M1 variant uses simple blowback action instead. Whole receiver is machined. Furniture included a pistol grip, detachable wooden shoulder stock and either a detachable forward grip or horizontal forearm. Sights on pre-war models included advanced sights adjustable for ranges up to 500m and windage. Since practical range was no more than 100m, wartime models (M1928A1, M1 and M1A1) used a simplified fixed aperture rear sight. Construction is complicated and required high workload, which made Thompson very expensive and unfit for a military weapon (later on it was replaced by M3 Grease Gun). Thompson was well liked for it's high firepower and controllability, but soldiers often complained about it's excessive weight at almost 5kg, which made it hard to carry on long distances. On the other hand, heavy weight and effective muzzle device reduced it's recoil, making it very easy to shoot even on longer bursts, despite it's rather powerful ammunition. Thompsons were used by US military for as long as to Vietnam war. They were also used by many countries after the war. Some of them were sent to USSR for Lend-Lease and it is probably from there that these weapons reached The Zone. While stalkers usually prefer lighter weapons for scavenging trips, the Thompsons are liked for their high firepower and sometimes used as anti-mutant weapons due to their high rate of fire and effective round, coupled with ability to use higher capacity drum magazines to further increase their capabilities. Nonetheless these weapons are rare in The Zone and see only limited use.

%c[0,170,170,170]Uzi is a family of compact submachine guns developed in the late 1940s in Israel, entering the service in 1954. Uzi was one of the first weapons to use a telescoping bolt design which allows the magazine to be housed in the pistol grip to reduce the dimensions. It was designed by Uziel Gal, who based it on Czech Sa.26 submachine guns of similar construction. Mechanically, Uzi is a blowback operated submachine gun, firing from the open bolt. The receiver is made from stamped steel, with trigger unit and pistol grip pinned to its bottom at the center. The bolt is of “wrap-around” type, with most of its weight located in front of the breech face. Full-size Uzi submachine guns were fitted either with a detachable wooden shoulder stock, or with under folding metallic shoulder stock of indigenous design. More compact Mini-Uzi and Micro-Uzi are fitted with side-folding metallic buttstocks made from steel. Uzi feeds from 20- or 32-round stick magazines. Rate of fire is at 600 rounds per minute, which makes Uzi very controllable at fully automatic mode. Uzi is considered to be one of the most reliable weapons ever designed. Despite stamped sheet metal construction it is very durable and works flawlessly even in harsh environment. Uzi was adopted by more than 90 countries all around the world, including USA, Germany, India, Cuba, Australia and Argentina. Famously, US Secret Service used Uzi submachine guns for VIP protection duties, most notably they were used to protect Reagan from assassination attempt. Uzi was frequently featured in movies and video games, often in hands of black characters, which got it fame of "gangsters' weapon", similar to AK rifle. A lot of these weapons reached the black market, some of them are available in The Zone, where they are well liked by stalkers for their very high reliability and compact dimensions, which is especially important to scavengers and explorers who often go on long trips or carry heavy equipment. Very cheap 9x19mm ammunition means lower upkeep cost of submachine guns, including Uzi.

%c[0,170,170,170]Micro-Uzi is the smallest variant of Uzi - a family of compact submachine guns developed in the late 1940s in Israel, entering the service in 1954. Uzi was one of the first weapons to use a telescoping bolt design which allows the magazine to be housed in the pistol grip to reduce the dimensions. It was designed by Uziel Gal, who based it on Czech Sa.26 submachine guns of similar construction. Mechanically, Uzi is a blowback operated submachine gun, firing from the open bolt. The receiver is made from stamped steel, with trigger unit and pistol grip pinned to its bottom at the center. The bolt is of “wrap-around” type, with most of its weight located in front of the breech face. Full-size Uzi submachine guns were fitted either with a detachable wooden shoulder stock, or with under folding metallic shoulder stock of indigenous design. More compact Mini-Uzi and Micro-Uzi are fitted with side-folding metallic buttstocks made from steel. Uzi feeds from 20- or 32-round stick magazines. Rate of fire is at 1200 rounds per minute, which improves Micro-Uzi's effectiveness at very short distances. Uzi is considered to be one of the most reliable weapons ever designed. Despite stamped sheet metal construction it is very durable and works flawlessly even in harsh environment. Uzi was adopted by more than 90 countries all around the world, including USA, Germany, India, Cuba, Australia and Argentina. Famously, US Secret Service used Uzi submachine guns for VIP protection duties, most notably they were used to protect Reagan from assassination attempt. Uzi was frequently featured in movies and video games, often in hands of black characters, which got it fame of "gangsters' weapon", similar to AK rifle. A lot of these weapons reached the black market, some of them are available in The Zone, where they are used as a type of sidearm for those who need higher firepower than typical pistol can give. Very cheap 9x19mm ammunition means lower upkeep cost of submachine guns, including Uzi.

%c[0,170,170,170]Uzi Pro is an evolution of the Micro-Uzi submachine gun. It retains same blowback operated, closed bolt, select-fire action but with side-mounted bolt handle, and the most important change is replacement of the older stamped steel trigger housing with more lightweight polymer pistol grip / trigger housing unit of more ergonomic shape. Top of receiver is provided with permanently attached Picatinny rail, which is used to install various sights. Uzi is a family of compact submachine guns developed in the late 1940s in Israel, entering the service in 1954. Uzi was one of the first weapons to use a telescoping bolt design which allows the magazine to be housed in the pistol grip to reduce the dimensions. Mechanically, Uzi is a blowback operated submachine gun, firing from the open bolt. The receiver is made from stamped steel, with trigger unit and pistol grip pinned to its bottom at the center. The bolt is of “wrap-around” type, with most of its weight located in front of the breech face. Uzi Pro submachine gun uses same magazines as other weapons of the Uzi family, with 25-round ones being standard.

%c[0,170,170,170]Vepr (Ukrainian: "Wild Boar") is a civilan hunting rifle based on RPK light machine gun and produced by Molot factory from Russia. It shoots semi-auto only, is chambered in 7.62x39mm cartridge and is meant for medium-game hunting. Their external construction is modified for civilian standards - it has no bayonet lug, tool kits or cleaning rods and often have modified stocks, taking place of typical stock and pistol grip. Veprs found their way to The Zone as Stalkers often took their hunting rifles there, instead of buying military weapons on black market. They are well liked and sometimes preferred over AKs due to their higher accuracy and range. Their internals are exactly the same as RPK rifles, and therefore also identical to those of AK. Mechanically it's exactly the same as AK - it's a gas operated, selective fire weapon. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud.

Veprs found their way to The Zone as Stalkers often took their hunting rifles there, instead of buying military weapons on black market. They are well liked and sometimes preferred over AKs due to their higher accuracy and range. Their internals are exactly the same as RPK rifles, and therefore also identical to those of AK. Mechanically it's exactly the same as AK - it's a gas operated, selective fire weapon. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud.

%c[0,170,170,170]Vepr (Ukrainian: "Wild Boar") is a Ukrainian rifle, chambered in 5.45x39mm cartridge. It's based on AK-74 and built in bullpup configuration. It was advertised as a major improvement over AK-74, but it wasn't succesful and didn't enter mass production, meeting fate of other bullpup AK projects. Bullpup AKs have multiple problems and so far none of them catched on. Vepr suffers from the same problems: heavy trigger pull, which lowers practical accuracy, worse reliability and durability, higher weight and awkward handling (which bullpup configuration should improve, not reduce). Some prototypes were stolen and are now being sold in The Zone, where it isn't very popular either. Not much is known about this rifle apart from the fact that it's a bullpup AK-74 in polymer furniture. It's operation mechanism is the same as in AK - it's a gas operated, selective fire weapon. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud.

%c[0,170,170,170]VHS-2 is a modernized bullpup assault rifle developed in early 2000s by HS Product in Croatia for Croatian military, who needed a new service rifle. VHS-2 is improved variant of VHS rifle, differing mostly by new, more modern aesthetics and ambidexterity (first variant of VHS was only right-handed). Mechanically, VHS-2 is a gas operated, select-fire rifle with rotary bolt locking and a manual gas regulator. All controls are ambidextrous. It features dual ejection windows on both sides of the receiver, so the user can select which side to eject the spent cartridges. However, this operation does require partial disassembly of the gun, so it is not a "true" ambidextrous weapon like F2000 or RFB, being closer to TAR-21 instead. Whole receiver is covered by housing made of strengthened polymer. VHS rifles are available either with an integrated MIL-STD-1913 (Picatinny) rail above the receiver and back-up iron sight on removable bases, or with integrated 1.5x telescopic sight. An indigenous 40mm grenade launcher can be mounted below the barrel. 16" barrel provides good muzzle velocity for 5.56mm bullet, which relies on velocity to yaw and fragment in the tissue. These rifles are compatible with most types of STANAG (M16-type) magazines. VHS-2 was thoroughly tested and is considered to be reliable and effective. It was officially adopted into Croatian military on 2009, it is also used by Albania, Bosnia, Iraq, Syria and Romania. In The Zone, VHS-2 rifles are sometimes seen on black market, where, just like all other bullpup rifles, they are well liked for their great handling and compact dimensions, which is important on long trips and expeditions.

%c[0,170,170,170]PP-19-01 Vityaz is a Russian submachine gun chambered in 9x19mm Parabellum cartridge. It was based on the AKS-74u compact assault rifle and shares it's ergonomics. It is used by elite counter-terrorist and police forces in Russia. Chambered in relatively weak pistol cartridge it doesn't have range or power of assault rifles, but it is by default adapted to shoot increased power 7N21 and 7N31 armor-piercing cartridges, which can reach rifle penetration levels. The Vityaz (Russian: "Knight") is a lightweight select fire weapon that uses a simple closed bolt, straight blowback method of operation. As such, it has no gas system and the internal components have been modified accordingly. The bolt carrier with integral charging handle is similar to AK, however the piston rod and rotary bolt were removed and the piston extension was plugged with a steel insert. It is chambered for the 9?19mm Parabellum pistol cartridge and will also fire the new high-pressure armor-piercing 7N31 round that can penetrate body armor as efficiently as rifle rounds. Vityaz is used by Russian MVD and law enforcment. In The Zone it is used by some Mercenary teams as a light CQB weapon together with other submachine guns like MP5 or Bizon. It is well liked for it's reliability and easily available ammunition.

%c[0,170,170,170]Volkspistole 70 is a semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x19mm cartridge, developed for German military by Heckler and Koch. It was meant to be a cheap semi-automatic pistol that could be quickly repurposed into machine pistol/PDW by adding a polymer stock to it, which allowed the burst-fire mode to be enabled. VP70 was a pretty revolutionary design back then, it had many modern features. It was the first mass-produced polymer pistol, predating the Glock by 12 years and used a spring-loaded striker, it was also one of the first modern machine pistols of that type. VP-70 is a blowback operated, striker fired, double action only pistol. In military version, VP-70M, it can be used along with detachable shoulder stock – holster, which has built in fire selector device, that allows to fire single shots or three rounds bursts. Withouth the stock attached, only single shots can be fired. Despite the simply blowback operation, not so common in 9mm Luger/Para handguns, the VP-70 had modest felt recoil, but heavy and long trigger pull does not helped to improve accuracy. It was found that in 3-round burst mode the pistol was very inaccurate and as such the VP70 didn't catch on. The production ended in 1989. Currently, some VP70 pistols can be found on black market, including arms dealers in The Zone. Despite it's low accuracy, the VP70 is a solid and effective weapon for self-defense, but most people prefer a modern polymer-frame pistol instead, like a Glock or USP.

%c[0,170,170,170]VSSK is a Russian high-caliber, integrally suppressed sniper rifle. It shoots subsonic 12.7x54mm STs-130 rounds that are similar to 12.7x55mm ASh-12 cartridges, but feature an unique spitzer bullet that is twice as long, which greatly improves range and terminal ballistics over pistol-shaped bullets of ASh-12 rifle. VSSK is an accurate and powerful sniper rifle with range of up to 600 meters. It is a bolt action, straight pull bullpup sniper rifle designed for special operations which require silent precision fire and ability of armor and barrier penetration superior to that of VSS Vintorez sniper rifles. Ammunition types contain a solid bronze FMJ sniper bullet, which tumbles in tissue causing heavy damage or a bullet with armor piercing core, which can penetrate up to whopping 16mm of steel on 200 meters (9x39mm penetrates 8mm of steel on half the range) or level V body armor on 100 meters. It's not as powerful as KVSK sniper rifle, which uses 12.7x108mm rounds that have twice the muzzle energy, but nonetheless it is an effective and very deadly weapon. However, it's low availability and very expensive ammunition severely limits it's use outside the agencies that have first-hand source of ammo and spare parts. Because of this, VSSK should be used only for most demanding missions. In The Zone it is used with success against enemies in heavy body armor and for killing mutants from safe distance. Only few of these rifles are known to be in The Zone, with at least two being on possession of Duty hunting squads that use it mostly for dispatching humanoid mutants in urban areas.

%c[0,170,170,170]SA vz.58 is an assault rifle chambered in 7.62x39mm cartridge developed in 1950s by famous former-Czechoslovak arms manufacturer Ceska Zbrojovka. This rifle entered service in Czechoslovak army in 1958 and stayed as official service rifle until 2011, when modern CZ-805 BREN rifle started replacing it. It's aesthetics are similar to those of AK rifle, but internal mechanics are completely different and no parts are interchangeable. It was a successful rifle, considered by many to be accurate and reliable and was used by more than 15 countries other than Czechoslovakia, most notably Cuba, India, Libya and Vietnam. Some numbers of these rifles are also available on the black market and reached The Zone too. The Samopal vzor 1958 ("Automatic weapon" model 1958) was the standard assault rifle of the Czechoslovak army from the late 1950s and until the separation of the CSSR in the 1993. It didn't see much of real combat, so there's not much information how it fares compared to AKM or M16, but the overall quality, fit and finish of this rifle is excellent. Sa58's development began in 1956 and the rifle was adopted for service only 2 years later, in 1958. The rifle was manufactured by the state-owned arms factory "Ceska zbrojovka", located in the town of Uhersky Brod (CZ-UB). It is now being replaced by more modern CZ-805 rifle, which is by many considered one of the best modern assault rifles. Mechanically, vz.58 is a gas operated firearm using short stroke gas piston principle - it uses Walther P38 pistol action and Czech ZB-26 machine gun locking. It is considered a reliable and accurate rifle, on par with the famous AKM.

%c[0,170,170,170]Winchester 1300 is an American pump-action shotgun developed in 1960s by Winchester. It was introduced in 1964 as a low-cost replacement for the venerable Model 12. These shotguns utilize pump action, which is operated by a sliding the forend. The fore-end is located on the underside of the barrel and moves front to back. Ammunition is fed from the tubular magazine that is located under the barrel. Available versions may have a stock with or without a pistol grip. A bayonet could be attached to the front end of the barrel of the military variant of the Model 1200, it also had ventilated forend and sling swivels. Winchester 1200 has a hammerless action which means that there is no external hammer spur. There is an internal hammer which strikes the firing pin which - in turn - strikes the primer on the shell to ignite the powder in the round. The Model 1200 was the second shotgun to utilize a rotary bolt with four locking lugs secured within the barrel extension. The 1200 was Winchester's first shotgun to incorporate the company's patented Winchoke system, a quick change tube to allow the easy replacement of chokes. Overally, the Winchester 1300 is a reliable and well built pump action shotgun, even thought it didn't gain as much fame as it's rivals. Pump action shotguns are popular in both the USA and Europe, and some stalkers brought these weapons, often legally owned, along with them into The Zone, where they are primarily used for defense against wild animals and mutants or hunting them. Like all other shotguns, the Winchester 1300 is liked for the sheer power that the 12 gauge shells provide.

%c[0,170,170,170]Zastava M70 is a family of 7.62x39mm assault rifles developed and produced by Zastava Arms in former Yugoslavia. It was based on Soviet AKM rifle but sports multiple modifications that make it quite different and adapted to needs of Yugoslavian military. The AKM is a Soviet assault rifle chambered in 7.62x39mm M43 cartridge. It is a modernized variant of AK-47 rifle - the most famous firearm in the world, often called the most reliable rifle ever designed. Overengineered receiver and chrome lined barrel provide exceptional durability, and the well-designed cartridge dimensions and strong action allow for reliable feeding in almost all conditions, even when the weapon is very dirty and/or corroded. Due to it's great balance of firepower, accuracy, reliability and low price, the AK-47 is often considered the "gold standard" and a point of reference among assault rifles. It is reliable, easy to produce, easy to operate and very effective. Among it's disadvantages are it's relatively heavy weight (in comparison to more modern rifles), susceptibility to catching dirt and dust (it's not sealed from outside elements) and worse accuracy in comparison with M16 or AK-74. The AK is a gas operated, selective fire assault rifle. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud. Zastava M70 is a very solid AK variant and is just as good and maybe even better than original Soviet AKM. M70 rifles were first produced in the year 1970 and are still produced today. It became a service rifle of Yugoslavian People's Army and police forces and was widely exported, finding it's place all around the world, most notably in Africa and Middle East. After civil war in Yugoslavia quite a number of these rifles found it's place on the black market, finally reaching The Zone where it's well liked as an interesting and less-common AK variant.

%c[0,170,170,170]Zastava M70 is a family of 7.62x39mm assault rifles developed and produced by Zastava Arms in former Yugoslavia. It was based on Soviet AKM rifle but sports multiple modifications that make it quite different and adapted to needs of Yugoslavian military. It is a modernized variant of AK-47 rifle - the most famous firearm in the world, often called the most reliable rifle ever designed. Overengineered receiver and chrome lined barrel provide exceptional durability, and the well-designed cartridge dimensions and strong action allow for reliable feeding in almost all conditions, even when the weapon is very dirty and/or corroded. Due to it's great balance of firepower, accuracy, reliability and low price, the AK-47 is often considered the "gold standard" and a point of reference among assault rifles. It is reliable, easy to produce, easy to operate and very effective. Among it's disadvantages are it's relatively heavy weight (in comparison to more modern rifles), susceptibility to catching dirt and dust (it's not sealed from outside elements) and worse accuracy in comparison with M16 or AK-74. The AK is a gas operated, selective fire assault rifle. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud. Zastava M70 is a very solid AK variant and is just as good and maybe even better than original Soviet AKM. M70 rifles were first produced in the year 1970 and are still produced today. It became a service rifle of Yugoslavian People's Army and police forces and was widely exported, finding it's place all around the world, most notably in Africa and Middle East. After civil war in Yugoslavia quite a number of these rifles found it's place on the black market, finally reaching The Zone where it's well liked as an interesting and less-common AK variant.

%c[0,170,170,170]Zastava M92 is a shortened carbine variant of M70 rifle, being a Yugoslavian AKS-74u equivalent chambered in 7.62x39mm ammo. This heavier, more powerful cartridge makes it harder to control than AKS-74u, but there's one special characteristic of it: it loses very little of velocity when shot from shorter barrel, unlike 5.45x39mm cartridge. This means that M92 has similar range and potential damage factor as longer AK or M70 rifles, while AKS-74u is less powerful than AK-74. It's disadvantages are, as said before, higher recoil, noticeably higher mass and bigger muzzle flash. Nonetheless, in The Zone it's sometimes preferred over AKS-74u due to it's better wounding potential, especially when it comes to fighting wild animals and mutants. Zastava M92 follows the typical Kalashnikov-style design, with long stroke gas piston operation, rotary bolt locking and stamped steel receiver. It has relatively short, 254mm (10") barrel, with front sight mounted above the gas block and with the AKS-74u-style flash hider at the muzzle. Despite very short barrel it loses very little muzzle velocity compared to full-lenght AKM or M70 rifle, which means it has similar terminal ballistics like them - this is a huge advantage over AKS-74u, which loses some velocity, resulting in lower potential damage done to target's tissue. Rate of fire is same as standard M70 rifle - 620 rounds per minute, which is lower than AKS-74u, which shoots 735 rounds per minute on average. Shoulder stock is underfolding type, similar to that used in AKMS rifle.Furniture is different than in AKSu - handguard is similar as in M70, sporting three vent holes (which help with the overheating) and pistol grip is made from black polymer with specific shape similar to other Yugoslavian rifles. M92 can use all 7.62x39mm AK magazines. Overally, Zastava M92 is a good competitor to AKS-74u in The Zone. Stalker must choose if he wishes better damage or lower weight and higher rate of fire. Both these weapons have their own advantages and disadvantages and can be both a very good choice in their own niche.

%c[0,170,170,170]AKS-74 is a folding-stock variant of AK-74, a Soviet 5.45x39mm assault rifle that was designed in early 1970s as an answer to new US M16 rifle shooting new type of ammunition. Use of new, smaller cartridge increases accuracy and range and makes it much easier to take follow up shots with it, which increases the chances of hitting - all this while retaining durability and reliability of other AK rifles. AK-74 and it's variants still stay as service rifle of Ukrainian military and is one of the most popular weapons in The Zone due to it's reliability, accuracy, low price and readily available ammunition. Mechanically, it's a gas operated, selective fire assault rifle. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud. Overengineered receiver and chrome lined barrel provide exceptional durability, and the well-designed cartridge dimensions and strong action allow for reliable feeding in almost all conditions, even when the weapon is very dirty and/or corroded. Among main features of AKS-74 are the chambering in lighter and more accurate 5.45x39mm round and a new muzzle device, which further reduces the recoil, muzzle climb and the flash from firing, together with new type of stock which folds to the side. Furniture is slightly redesigned from AKM, early AK-74s used plywood furniture like AKM but big amount was also produced with dark-plum coloured polymer stock and handguards, which is more resistant to wear and slightly lighter than plywood. AK-74 and it's variants stay in service in more than 20 countries. AKS-74 also still stays as service rifle of Ukrainian military and is one of the most popular weapons in The Zone due to it's reliability, accuracy, low price and readily available ammunition. Lots of these rifles were stolen from military warehouses or bought off from corrupt military officials. Stalkers like AKS-74's folding stock as it is more compact, making it easier to carry.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]Greatly increased shot spread. Lowered weight and good handling. Very high damage. %c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]Homemade sawn-off variant of TOZ-66. Short barrel makes it lighter and more compact. It also increases shot spread greatly, improving the chance of hitting, however, because of spread and lower muzzle velocity the range is significantly lowered, making it uneffective beyond 40-50 meters. TOZ-66 is one of many side-by-side (SxS) double barrel shotguns manufactured by Tulsky Oruzheiny Zavod (Russian: Tula Arms Factory) in Soviet Union. It was designed in 1968 and the production ran until late 1970s. Like all other Soviet hunting weapons, it is a simple design, without decorations or any revolutionary solutions, but is a solid piece of work and does it's job as intended, all that for unmatched price. It has a "monoblock" construction, the breech area, including the locking lugs, are machined from one piece. These shotguns were popular among hunters and civilian shooting enthusiasts and were brought to The Zone by stalkers who owned them or bought them on black market. Two barrels hold one shell each and can be fired both in the same time. One disadvantage of SxS setup is that barrels of a double-barreled shotgun are not parallel, but slightly angled, so that shots from the barrels converge, usually at about 40 meters out. For the SxS configuration, the shotstring continues on its path to the opposite side of the rib after the converging point; for example, the left barrel's discharge travels on the left of the rib till it hits dead center at 40 yards out, after that, the discharge continues on to the right. Thus, double-barreled shotguns are accurate only at practical shotgun ranges, though the range of their ammunition easily exceeds four to six times that distance. Very long barrel provides tight spread and higher muzzle velocity than typical short combat shotguns and it basically guarantees a kill on up to 75m when aimed well. However, the tight spread and it's length mean it's rather unwieldy and less effective in close quarters - some users are sawing off the barrels to make it a light and compact weapon with wider spread, nonetheless the longer barrel is definitely more effective when it comes to big game hunting. Shotguns with sawn-off barrels are often kept as sidearms instead of relatively expensive pistols.

%c[0,170,170,170]Colt 1911 is a family of semi-automatic pistols. M1911 is chambered in .45 ACP cartridge. It was designed in 1911 for US Army by famous genius firearm designer, John M. Browning, and in 1924 the M1911A1 variant entered production. It is one of the first successful semi-automatic pistols and one of the most successful firearms ever designed - it is basically a grandfather of all modern pistols. Mechanically it's a short recoil operated firearm with SA trigger, fed from 7-round magazine by default, sporting manual and grip safety. It was a revolutionary design, as contemporary pistols were often expensive, big, heavy and awkward - it was the best pistol on the market for a long time. It became successful among soldiers, policemen and civilian gun owners alike. Today however the 1911 is a dated design - it's relatively big and heavy, and it's low capacity seriously limits it's potential as a combat weapon. Modern pistols can hold more than twice as much rounds while weighting half it's mass. The M1911 is somewhat less reliable and requires more care than modern pistols, it is nonetheless still an effective weapon, and if properly handled it can still be as deadly as one hundred years ago. Among it's strong sides are very good accuracy thanks to Single Action trigger and good susceptibility for upgrades, which can make a good match pistol out of it. Colt M1911A1 was a service pistol of US military from 1911 to 1986, when it was replaced by Beretta 92FS. In some countries it served for longer, eventually staying in service for more than 100 years. A lot of manufacturers, like Kimber, Remington or Wilson Combat produce modernized pistols based on M1911, with new barrels, match triggers and custom sights - they're often used for various competition. While immensely popular in North America, the 1911 pistols never gained much popularity in Europe (mainly because of .45 ACP chambering which is not popular here) and remain basically only a piece for collectors. In The Zone a batch of M1911A1 pistols was smuggled from storages in Vietnam and Philippines, and some stalkers use customized 1911 clones bought on civilian market.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]10mm round provides high damage per shot. Effective vs mutants. SA trigger provides higher practical accuracy. Rechambered to 10mm Auto. High damage with low magazine capacity. %c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]Colt Delta Elite is a modified M1911 Series-80 pistol, chambered in powerful 10mm Auto cartridge. It was one of the first pistols chambered in this powerful cartridge which is basically a .357 Magnum equivalent. Mechanically it is basically just like M1911 - it's a short recoil operated firearm with SA trigger, fed from 7-round magazine by default, sporting manual and grip safety. M1911 was a revolutionary design back in the day, but in 1980s it was already overshadowed by modern designs - it didn't stand chance against new "wonder nines" like CZ-75 or Beretta 92, which were lighter, more reliable and their double-stack magazines held twice as much rounds than 1911's humble 7 rounds of .45 ACP, a round that just doesn't have enough power to justify such low capacity. Colt Delta Elite was something else however. It didn't have higher capacity than classic 1911, it however used much more powerful round - the new 10mm Auto designed by famous gun expert Jeff Cooper, which had power exceeding the famous .357 Magnum loads. New cartridge gave the aging 1911 design new life, and Colt Delta Elite is a solid choice for those who want more power than typical 9x19mm or .45ACP cartridges can give. It has gotten popular in places where being attacked by wild animals is a major danger, like Alaska, but Delta Elites also gotten famous in The Zone - their power and semi-automatic mechanism makes them a good alternative to Magnum revolvers. They are however very rare and their prices can exceed typical revolver's price range significantly.

%c[0,170,170,170]Desert Eagle is a family of large-bore semi-automatic pistols, offered in variety of chamberings. It was developed in early '80s by Magnum Research Inc and manufactured under Israeli Military Industries. Desert Eagle is designed to fire powerful ammunition typically used in revolvers; most notably .357 Magnum and .44 Magnum. Most powerful variant is chambered in .50 Action Express, which is about 20% more powerful than .44 Magnum (depending on the cartridge load). It's one of the most famous weapons in the world due to it's attractive look and big size, it starred in many movies and games. It is large, heavy, and uses unique gas operated action usually found in rifles, to reliably feed powerful rounds in semi-automatic mode. Mechanically it is a hammer fired, gas operated, locked breech weapon that has a fixed, non-moving barrel. Trigger is single action only, with exposed hammer; the slide and frame are all made of steel (or other alloy). Desert Eagle works pretty reliable for a pistol that uses rimmed ammunition, but stoppages still occur more often than in "standard" pistols. It also has good accuracy which makes it effective in target shooting or hunting. The usage of gas action and it's heavy weight reduce the felt recoil of powerful rounds that the Desert Eagle fires, which makes it easier to handle than revolvers chambered in the same ammunition; the heavy muzzle flash and loud sound signature still remain, however. Desert Eagle is large and unwieldy; it is not a good choice for concealed carry and was never adopted by any military or law enforcement agency, it is only used by sport or recreational shooters. However, due to it's powerful rounds it is sometimes carried by people living in areas where wild animals attacks occur, such as Alaska. In The Zone the wild animals and mutants activity is high, so the Desert Eagle pistols were imported and are sold on black market, where they enjoy some limited popularity.

%c[0,170,170,170]Desert Eagle is a family of large-bore semi-automatic pistols, offered in variety of chamberings. It was developed in early '80s by Magnum Research Inc and manufactured under Israeli Military Industries. Desert Eagle is designed to fire powerful ammunition typically used in revolvers; most notably .357 Magnum and .44 Magnum. Most powerful variant is chambered in .50 Action Express, which is about 20% more powerful than .44 Magnum (depending on the cartridge load). It's one of the most famous weapons in the world due to it's attractive look and big size, it starred in many movies and games. It is large, heavy, and uses unique gas operated action usually found in rifles, to reliably feed powerful rounds in semi-automatic mode. Mechanically it is a hammer fired, gas operated, locked breech weapon that has a fixed, non-moving barrel. Trigger is single action only, with exposed hammer; the slide and frame are all made of steel (or other alloy). Desert Eagle works pretty reliable for a pistol that uses rimmed ammunition, but stoppages still occur more often than in "standard" pistols. It also has good accuracy which makes it effective in target shooting or hunting. The usage of gas action and it's heavy weight reduce the felt recoil of powerful rounds that the Desert Eagle fires, which makes it easier to handle than revolvers chambered in the same ammunition; the heavy muzzle flash and loud sound signature still remain, however. Desert Eagle is large and unwieldy; it is not a good choice for concealed carry and was never adopted by any military or law enforcement agency, it is only used by sport or recreational shooters. However, due to it's powerful rounds it is sometimes carried by people living in areas where wild animals attacks occur, such as Alaska. In The Zone the wild animals and mutants activity is high, so the Desert Eagle pistols were imported and are sold on black market, where they enjoy some limited popularity.

%c[0,170,170,170]F2000 is a modern assault rifle chambered in 5.56x45mm cartridge designed and manufactured in Belgium by FN. It is an advanced, modular weapon system that consists of a bullpup assault rifle and a grenade launcher with optoelectronic fire control system. Mechanically the F2000 is a gas operated firearm with short stroke piston and rotating bolt, using tappet system similarly to Steyr AUG, with which it has a lot in common. It has a steel receiver enclosed in reinforced polymer housing of compact layout, which seals the internals from any and all external elements, like dust, mud and sand, which makes the weapon very resistant to hard environment. The weapon has 16" barrel but is very compact and easy to handle due to efficient bullpup construction. One of the most outstanding features of F2000 is a unique ejection system, which ejects spent brass forward through a tube running above the barrel. This makes the rifle completely ambidextrous, making it a great choice for both right- and left-handed shooters, and also allows the operator to switch hands during engagements (for example when leaning to the side). The ejection system is actually very simple and is not possible to clog or damage, so it doesn't reduce the weapon's reliability. F2000 is easy to field strip and dismounts into only four parts. Standard variant is equipped with 1.6x telescopic sight in polymer housing, which gives it futuristic look. F2000 was adopted by some elite special forces units and also became service rifle of the Slovenian Army. It was used in various armed conflicts, where it proven itself as a reliable and effective weapon. In The Zone a few groups were using these rifles, most notably UN expedition forces and western PMC groups; substantial amount of these rifles were also observed in hands of Monolith fighters, who probably captured them from former owners. Few F2000s which were taken from dead Monolithians are shown off by veteran stalkers as a war trophy and a proof of their prowess and experience in fighting with Monolith.

%c[0,170,170,170]Fort-12 is an Ukrainian semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x18mm cartridge, designed in the late 1990s to replace the aging PM pistols. Mechanically it is an all-steel blowback operated pistol with manual safety and Double Action trigger. It was designed from the start as a police pistol, so the DA trigger is pretty heavy, reducing the practical accuracy - this type of triggers is mounted in police handguns to reduce the chances of accidental discharge in stressful situations. The pistol itself however is relatively reliable and accurate with slightly better handling than Makarov pistol (depending on user's preferences, of course), it also has bigger magazine holding 12 rounds - 50% more compared to PM, which is a substantial upgrade. It's disadvantages lie mostly in it's cartridge, which is rather obsolete and weaker than 9x19mm Parabellum. It is however available in Eastern Europe for cheap in big numbers. Most of these pistols went to Ukrainian police and elite law enforcement units, but some also reached the military. In The Zone it is common and easily available - airborne military units and Cordon guards use these pistols, and lots of them hit the black market, either stolen from storages or sold by corrupt officers. It is well liked by stalkers and deemed as an upgrade over old Makarov pistols mainly because of higher magazine capacity; however some stalkers prefer to save up for a more powerful western pistol chambered in 9x19mm Parabellum.

%c[0,170,170,170]Fort-14 is an Ukrainian semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x18mm cartridge, designed in 2003 as a modernization of Fort 12. It has higher capacity and easily detachable barrel which improves accuracy and makes it easier to clean. The rest is very similar to Fort 12. Mechanically it is an all-steel blowback operated pistol with manual safety and Double Action trigger. It was designed from the start as a police pistol, so the DA trigger is pretty heavy, reducing the practical accuracy - this type of triggers is mounted in police handguns to reduce the chances of accidental discharge in stressful situations. The pistol itself however is relatively reliable and accurate with slightly better handling than Makarov pistol (depending on user's preferences, of course), it also has bigger magazine holding 14 rounds, almost twice compared to PM, which is a substantial upgrade. It's disadvantages lie mostly in it's cartridge, which is rather obsolete and weaker than 9x19mm Parabellum, it is however available in Eastern Europe for cheap in big numbers. Only relatively small batch of these pistols was produced and all went to Ukrainian police and military, some were used by military units in The Zone and from there they hit the black market, where stalkers can buy them. Just like Fort 12 it is well liked and regarded as a solid handgun; however some stalkers prefer to save up for a more powerful western pistol chambered in 9x19mm Parabellum.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]Polymer frame substantially reduces weight. Extended magazine capacity. DA trigger limits practical accuracy. %c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]Fort-17 is an Ukrainian semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x18mm cartridge, designed in early 2000s as a further modernization of Fort-12 pistol. The main difference is polymer frame, which saves a lot on weight - Fort 12, despite being pretty light for a steel-framed pistol, was still much heavier than modern polymer designs, which were popular choice for police. Weighting 680g, Fort-17 is close to modern competitors, like Walther P99 or Glock 17 (605-625g). The internals are unchanged from Fort-12. Mechanically, it is a polymer-framed, blowback operated pistol with manual safety and Double Action trigger. It was designed from the start as a police pistol, so the DA trigger is pretty heavy, reducing the practical accuracy - this type of triggers is mounted in police handguns to reduce the chances of accidental discharge in stressful situations. The pistol itself however is relatively reliable and accurate with slightly better handling than Makarov pistol (depending on user's preferences, of course), it also has bigger magazine holding 13 rounds - one round more than Fort-12 and more than 50% more compared to PM, which is a substantial upgrade. It's disadvantages lie mostly in it's cartridge, which is rather obsolete and weaker than 9x19mm Parabellum. A small number of these pistols are used by Ukrainian law enforcement and military. In The Zone the Fort-17 pistols are rather rare, they can sometimes be seen used by military guards in Cordon or airborne units. Stalkers like Fort pistols and see them as an upgrade over old Makarovs mainly because of higher magazine capacity; however some stalkers prefer to save up for a more modern western pistol chambered in 9x19mm Parabellum.

%c[0,170,170,170]The FAMAS is a French assault rifle chambered for 5.56x45mm cartridge and built in bullpup configuration. The French military needed a new weapon to replace their aging MAS-49 rifles that used 7.5x54mm French cartridge which wasn't used by other NATO countries, and projects of new rifles quickly emerged. Meanwhile NATO adopted 5.56x45mm as service round and French decided to produce next prototypes in this caliber. The outcome was FAMAS F1, which, after long trials with several prototypes, was finally adopted as service rifle in 1978, replacing both MAS-49 rifle and MAT-49 submachine gun. The FAMAS was lighter, had higher capacity and was easier to use than more powerful battle rifle chambered in full-size cartridge. It's features are relatively light weight, bullpup configuration which improves handling, good sights and high rate of fire, which can be both it's advantage and disadvantage, depending on situation. Mechanically, it is quite an unique rifle, as it uses lever-delayed blowback action - system which utilizes leverage to delay the opening of the breech. The receiver is steel and the housing is made of polymer reinforced with fiberglass. First version of FAMAS, the FAMAS F1, was somewhat unreliable, as polymer parts were reported to break off and magazines deformed easily, which produced frequent jamming. Updated versions and new variant, FAMAS G2, fixed this problem almost completely, and FAMAS rifles are considered to be highly reliable. The FAMAS was official service rifle of France until 2018, when the military started replacing these weapons with German-made HK416F assault rifles. Some of FAMAS rifles were found on the black market in The Zone, where they were probably smuggled from Syria or Iraq who bought small batches of these rifles, but these informations are not yet confirmed.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]Designed for maximum durability. High recoil. High damage output. Best on long range. %c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]Galil AR 7.62 is a long-barreled version of Galil assault rifle, chambered in 7.62x51mm NATO cartridge. Full-size cartridge gives it longer range and good accuracy, but significantly increases the recoil, making it hard to control, especially in bursts. This version is a competitor to other battle rifles of the era, like G3 or FN FAL. It's reliable and efficient, it is however much heavier than comparable rifles of this type. Galil is an Israeli rifles family which were designed by Yisrael Galil and Yaacov Lior in the late 1960s, and produced by IMI (Israel Military Industries). Israelis wanted something that could withstand desert heat, sand and continuous abuse - Six-day war of 1967 showed that FN FAL had problems in desert terrain. Captured AK-47s were found to be much better adapted to harsh, desert terrain, and Israelis decided to make their own AK variant. Finnish Rk62 was chosen - it was a weapon that was renowned for it's durability and reliability, especially in harsh conditions. Galil project won the competition for the new rifle and it's mass production started. It however never became a main weapon of Israeli infantry - it's excessive weight (about 4kg) was too much for soldiers who spend most of the time marching, and almost every one of them preferred US-supplied M16A1 rifles instead, that used same ammunition, had long and precise barrels, but also weighted a lot less (2.89kg). Galils however stayed for long time as a support weapon (with bipod) and as a weapon for rear echelon troops. Galils however became well liked in other countries, where tactics were different and where they could show their strong sides - mainly in Africa and South America. Overally, it's a very good, reliable and combat proven weapon that can be counted on. It is very well liked in The Zone for it's reliability in even hardest conditions - it is considered a definite upgrade over AKs.

%c[0,170,170,170]Galil ARM is a long-barreled version of Galil assault rifle, chambered in 5.56x45mm. It's long barrel allows for higher effective range and gives bullets high velocity, which means they tumble and fragment in tissue more efficiently, dealing higher damage. It's reliable and efficient, it is however much heavier than comparable rifles of this type. Galil is an Israeli rifles family which were designed by Yisrael Galil and Yaacov Lior in the late 1960s, and produced by IMI (Israel Military Industries). Israelis wanted something that could withstand desert heat, sand and continuous abuse - Six-day war of 1967 showed that FN FAL had problems in desert terrain. Captured AK-47s were found to be much better adapted to harsh, desert terrain, and Israelis decided to make their own AK variant. Finnish Rk62 was chosen - it was a weapon that was renowned for it's durability and reliability, especially in harsh conditions. Galil project won the competition for the new rifle and it's mass production started. It however never became a main weapon of Israeli infantry - it's excessive weight (about 4kg) was too much for soldiers who spend most of the time marching, and almost every one of them preferred US-supplied M16A1 rifles instead, that used same ammunition, had long and precise barrels, but also weighted a lot less (2.89kg). Galils however stayed for long time as a support weapon (with bipod) and as a weapon for rear echelon troops. Galils however became well liked in other countries, where tactics were different and where they could show their strong sides - mainly in Africa and South America. Overally, it's a very good, reliable and combat proven weapon that can be counted on. It is very well liked in The Zone for it's reliability in even hardest conditions - it is considered a definite upgrade over AKs.

%c[0,170,170,170]Sturmgewehr 44 (literally "Storm Rifle"), also known as MP43 and MP44, is a German assault rifle chambered in 7.92x33mm Kurz cartridge. It was the first successful assault rifle. Despite aesthetic similarity to AK, those two rifles have little in common. Mechanically, StG44 is a gas operated, select-fire weapon, utilizing long-stroke piston and firing from a closed bolt. Almost all parts, except the stock, are made from metal stampings, which made StG44 much cheaper and quicker to produce than other WWII weapons. The ejector port is covered by dust cover, which makes the weapon well shielded from elements, increasing reliability. Overally, StG44 is a very good weapon, often named by experts as one of the best infantry weapons in WWII. It was also hugely influential, as every assault rifle after 1945 comes, directly or indirectly, from StG44. During the WWII, it gave German infantry squads very high firepower compared to their enemies, often entirely armed with bolt-action rifles. Today the StG44 is somewhat obsolete, but still very effective and can definitely stand it's ground in a fight. Advantages of StG44 are high reliability, good accuracy and low recoil. It's drawbacks however are heavy weight and parts made from sheet metal stampings, which are not as durable as later designs. StG44 was primarily used by Third Reich. Almost 500 000 were produced. After the war, StG44 rifles were used by West and East Germany, Czechoslovakia, France, Poland and Yugoslavia. After the Yugoslavia's downfall, StG44 rifles reached the black market. Especially big amount reached The Zone, where Sturmgewehrs are sold for cheaper price and used by stalkers together with AK rifles in the same way. Since the 7.92mm Kurz ammo is very scarce today, Zone technicians are handloading the cartridges from spent 7.62x39 brass. Stalkers prefer other rifles due to StG's excessive mass, which is a problem on long trips, but nonetheless they are well liked for their reliability and firepower.

%c[0,170,170,170]M16A1 is an American assault rifle which served as the service rifle of US military since the Vietnam war. Small number of M16s were equipped with heavy barrels and telescopic sights on carry handles and called Special High Profile (there was also Low Profile variant which had carry handle removed and optics placed right on top of the receiver), they were however deemed too inaccurate (match 5.56x45mm ammo wasn't available back then) and weren't accepted into service. M16 is based on the AR-15 rifle developed by Eugene Stoner in 1960s. Mechanically, AR-15 is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. It is less reliable than comparable designs when dirty, but the closed system very effectively seals it from the outside, which prevents any dirt and mud from preventing the internals - this means that the AR-15s are less prone to external elements than eg. AKM. in the late 1950s the AR-15 was sent to military tests, which shown that AR-15 provided up to 40% more firepower, was easier to use and - contrary to popular belief - was more reliable than M14s. In the 1963 the rifle was officially adopted as the M16. The M16 - unfairly - earned reputation of being unreliable and fragile, but these issues were mainly caused by ammunition filled with faulty powder to cut cost. After these issues were fixed in M16A1 version, the rifle worked flawlessly. "Sniper" M16A1s are extremely rare and almost never seen today. Few were seen in hands of stalkers and mercs in The Zone, it's possible they were smuggled from Southeast Asia together with other decommissioned weapons. Their low-power scope limits their long-range use, but nonetheless they are good enough for typical engagement ranges.

%c[0,170,170,170]M16A1 is an American assault rifle which served as the service rifle of US military since the Vietnam war. It is based on the AR-15 rifle developed by Eugene Stoner in 1960s. Mechanically, AR-15 is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. It is less reliable than comparable designs when dirty, but the closed system very effectively seals it from the outside, which prevents any dirt and mud from preventing the internals - this means that the AR-15s are less prone to external elements than eg. AKM. in the late 1950s the AR-15 was sent to military tests, which shown that AR-15 provided up to 40% more firepower, was easier to use and - contrary to popular belief - was more reliable than M14s. In the 1963 the rifle was officially adopted as the M16. The M16 - unfairly - earned reputation of being unreliable and fragile. First M16 had a lot of problems, but it wasn't an issue with a rifle itself. Main reason for M16's failure in Vietnam is faulty powder, which was used to cut the cost. Gas-operated weapons rely entirely on gas energy from powder and faulty powder means increased wear for the rifle, resulting in damage. They also didn't have chrome plated chambers which made them very prone to corrosion. After these issues were fixed in M16A1 version, the rifle worked flawlessly. A lot of M16A1 rifles came to Europe from Philippines and Vietnam, from where they were sold to civilian market. Some of them were stolen or sold on black market, since a number of M16A1 rifles are seen in The Zone and can be bought for cheap. Stalkers like these rifles for their light weight and high accuracy, especially when compared to old AK rifles.

%c[0,170,170,170]M16A2 is a modernized American assault rifle which was developed as a result of combat experience in Vietnam. M16 was based on the AR-15 design developed by Eugene Stoner in 1960s. Mechanically, AR-15 is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. It is less reliable than comparable designs when dirty, but the closed system very effectively seals it from the outside, which prevents any dirt and mud from preventing the internals - this means that the AR-15s are less prone to external elements than eg. AKM. in the late 1950s the AR-15 was sent to military tests, which shown that AR-15 provided up to 40% more firepower, was easier to use and - contrary to popular belief - was more reliable than M14s. In 1982 M16A1 was replaced by updated variant, the M16A2. Modifications were extensive, among them were new, faster rifling (1:7") for use with heavier SS109 round, a heavier barrel to resist bending and reduce overheating in sustained fire, an adjustable rear sight, with settings adapted for new heavy bullet, to allow sighting-in without the use of special tools or a cartridge. The new A2 flash hider was closed at the bottom to prevent dirt being kicked up when fired prone. The A1's full auto setting was replaced with a three round burst setting. Overally, M16A2 has higher reliability and has stronger construction, as well as improved accuracy. It was however criticized for weight increase and the lack of full-auto mode. High amount of M16A2 rifles were sold or given as military aid to a lot of US allies; some of them were stolen or captured and reached the black market in many places of the world, including The Zone. Stalkers are sometimes distrustful when it comes to these weapons, but M16 variants are nonetheless well liked for their comfortable ergonomics and accuracy, which are much higher than those of old AK rifles.

%c[0,170,170,170]M16A4 is the latest modern variant of M16 assault rifle and is the current service rifle of US military together with M4A1. M16 was based on the AR-15 design developed by Eugene Stoner in 1960s. Mechanically, AR-15 is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. It is less reliable than comparable designs when dirty, but the closed system very effectively seals it from the outside, which prevents any dirt and mud from preventing the internals - this means that the AR-15s are less prone to external elements than eg. AKM. In 1982 M16A1 was replaced by updated variant, the M16A2. M16A2 was heavily modified rifle. It had improved accuracy, heavier barrel and more durable construction than A1 and the full-auto mode was ditched for 3-round burst mode. The rifle was then updated with a removable carrying handle and a full length quad Picatinny rail for mounting optics and other ancillary devices - this weapon received the name of M16A4. It is the latest and most modern variant of M16 rifle. While the main weapon of US infantry is the short and light M4A1, the long M16A4 has a number of advantages; most notably higher accuracy and velocity on range - since 5.56mm bullet requires higher velocity to fragment, the 20" barrel of M16A4 provides high lethality of bullet on twice the range of M4A1. Some of these rifles were sold on black market in the Middle East, from where they reached The Zone, where they can be sometimes seen, albeit very rarely. Some of them are also used by western mercenary groups. Like with all other AR-15 type rifles, the M16A4 is well liked for it's high accuracy and ergonomics and can reach substantial prices on the black market.

%c[0,170,170,170]The M16A3 is a modified version of the M16A2 adopted in small numbers by the U.S. Navy SEAL, Seabee, and Security units. It features the M16A1 trigger group with full-auto and semi-auto mode, as opposed to M16A2's three-round burst instead of full-auto. M16A2 is a modernized American assault rifle which was developed as a result of combat experience in Vietnam. M16 was based on the AR-15 design developed by Eugene Stoner in 1960s. Mechanically, AR-15 is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. It is less reliable than comparable designs when dirty, but the closed system very effectively seals it from the outside, which prevents any dirt and mud from preventing the internals - this means that the AR-15s are less prone to external elements than eg. AKM. in the late 1950s the AR-15 was sent to military tests, which shown that AR-15 provided up to 40% more firepower, was easier to use and - contrary to popular belief - was more reliable than M14s. In the 1963 the rifle was officially adopted as the M16. In 1982 M16A1 was replaced by updated variant, the M16A2. Modifications were extensive, among them were new, faster rifling (1:7") for use with heavier SS109 round, a heavier barrel to resist bending and reduce overheating in sustained fire. Fully-automatic mode was ditched for three-round burst mode, which was highly criticized. Special Forces and Navy adopted the M16A3, which is basically just M16A2 with full-auto mode. Not many were produced officially, however, adapting burst-fire or semi-auto only weapons for fully-automatic mode is very often done in the field and such weapons are commonly seen.
