M16 was based on the AR-15 design developed by Eugene Stoner in 1960s. Mechanically, AR-15 is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. It is less reliable than comparable designs when dirty, but the closed system very effectively seals it from the outside, which prevents any dirt and mud from preventing the internals - this means that the AR-15s are less prone to external elements than eg. AKM. In 1982 M16A1 was replaced by updated variant, the M16A2. M16A2 was heavily modified rifle. It had improved accuracy, heavier barrel and more durable construction than A1 and the full-auto mode was ditched for 3-round burst mode. The rifle was then updated with a removable carrying handle and a full length quad Picatinny rail for mounting optics and other ancillary devices - this weapon received the name of M16A4. It is the latest and most modern variant of M16 rifle. While the main weapon of US infantry is the short and light M4A1, the long M16A4 has a number of advantages; most notably higher accuracy and velocity on range - since 5.56mm bullet requires higher velocity to fragment, the 20" barrel of M16A4 provides high lethality of bullet on twice the range of M4A1. Some of these rifles were sold on black market in the Middle East, from where they reached The Zone, where they can be sometimes seen, albeit very rarely. Some of them are also used by western mercenary groups. Like with all other AR-15 type rifles, the M16A4 is well liked for it's high accuracy and ergonomics and can reach substantial prices on the black market.

%c[0,170,170,170]The US Squad Designated Marksman Rifle (SDM-R) is a heavily modified M16-series rifle intended to provide increased accuracy at longer ranges, giving infantry squads greater firepower. It is basically an M16A4 outfitted with heavier, accurized, stainless-steel barrel, two-stage match trigger and a high-power scope. The barrel is free-floating with special type of handguard which doesn't come into contact with barrel. All this provides up to 2.5x higher accuracy compared to standard M16A4 rifle with only a scope installed. %c[0,170,170,170]M4A1 is a modified variant of M4, the shortened carbine version of M16A2, an assault rifle chambered in 5.56x45mm that was the service rifle of US military back then. It is based on the AR-15, an American 5.56x45mm assault rifle developed by Eugene Stoner in 1960s. Mechanically, AR-15 is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. It is less reliable than comparable designs when dirty, but the closed system very effectively seals it from the outside, which prevents any dirt and mud from preventing the internals - this means that the AR-15s are less prone to external elements than eg. AKM. The history of M4 started together with M16, when it's carbine variants, called CAR-15, was developed. M4 received a slightly longer 14.5" barrel (CAR-15s typically had 10-11") that provides acceptable velocity and range and also allows for mounting bayonet and grenade launcher. M4A1 differs from M4 mainly by having fully-automatic fire mode (M4 had only 3-round burst mode). Because the shorter M4A1 was lighter and more maneuverable in the fight, in the end it became the service rifle of US military and almost completely replaced M16A2 and M16A4. M4A1 is praised for it's high accuracy, light weight and exceptionally good ergonomics, but is also criticized for it's relatively low reliability compared to other modern rifles and unsatisfactory terminal ballistics because of reduced muzzle velocity compared to M16. M4A1 received many upgrades throughout it's service, mostly parts replacement that improve reliability. M4A1 carbines were adopted by more than 60 countries. Some of them were stolen or captured and reached the black market in many places of the world, including The Zone. Stalkers are sometimes distrustful when it comes to these weapons, since most of M4A1s on black market are old variants which are much less reliable than modernized M4A1s of US military, but these rifles are nonetheless well liked for their comfortable ergonomics and accuracy, which are much higher than those of old AK rifles.

%c[0,170,170,170]The AR-15 is an American assault rifle developed by Eugene Stoner in 1960s. It was designed as a lightweight automatic rifle using a modern, light, small-bore ammunition which allowed the soldier to carry more ammunition. in the late 1950s the AR-15 was sent to military tests, which shown that AR-15 provided up to 40% more firepower, was easier to use and - contrary to popular belief - was more reliable than M14s. In 1960 first AR-15 rifles were ordered for USAF, and in 1963 the rifle was officially adopted as the M16. It serves up to this day in multiple variants (most notably M4 and M16) and is still considered to be one of the most universal and modular weapons in the world. AR-15s are also well-liked by civilian gun owners, hunters and sportsmen for their accuracy, effectiveness and simplicity. Mechanically, AR-15 is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. It is less reliable than comparable designs when dirty, but the closed system very effectively seals it from the outside, which prevents any dirt and mud from preventing the internals - this means that the AR-15s are less prone to external elements than eg. AKM. AR-15s usually have 2-3x higher accuracy than rifles of AK system, which makes them much more fit for shooting for longer ranges, especially with optics that can be easily placed on RIS rail on top of the receiver (AK's receiver doesn't usually allow enough stability). In The Zone the AR-15 is a popular weapon for it's improved ergonomics and easiness of use coupled with acceptable price. It is considered an upgrade over AKs because of these advantages, but some stalkers prefer the reliability and ruggedness of AKs when it comes to harsh conditions of the anomalous zones. In the end, both these weapons have their strong and weak sides and it is one's choice which are more important to him.

%c[0,170,170,170]M607 was the first Colt Commando (CAR-15) - a family of AR-15 based shortened carbines manufactured by Colt in the 1960s and early 1970s. All CAR-15s are based on military variant of the AR-15, which is an American 5.56x45mm assault rifle developed by Eugene Stoner in 1960s and adopted into military as M16. Mechanically, AR-15 is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. It is less reliable than comparable designs when dirty, but the closed system very effectively seals it from the outside, which prevents any dirt and mud from preventing the internals - this means that the AR-15s are less prone to external elements than eg. AKM. During the Vietnam War, Colt made several short barreled carbines that were fielded. First of them was the Colt Model 607 with 10" barrel, which was adopted in 1966 and received the name XM177 (later replaced by XM177E1, which was based on Colt 609 and looked similar to M4). All Colt Commando carbines have short barrels which improve their maneuverability, but radically limits the muzzle velocity. Small and light 5.56mm bullet deals damage by fragmenting and yawing in the tissue, but it requires a certain velocity to do so and 10" barrel provides it only at the muzzle. Beyond point-blank range the bullet might not work properly and produce only "ice pick" wounds, as in, passes straight through without doing much damage - if it doesn't hit vital organs straight away, it will not disable the target and multiple hits might be needed. However, their compact size was a big enough advantage for these rifles to become favorites of special forces. A small batch of these weapons reached black market in The Zone, probably coming from Vietnam or Philippines. Just like other carbines, are very well liked for their compact size by scavengers who need to carry a lot of loot and a big rifle encumbers them too much.

%c[0,170,170,170]Mk18 is a special shortened carbine with commando-length barrel for improved handling and lower weight. The Mk18 is basically an M4A1 carbine outfitted with Close Quarter Battle Receiver (CQBR) - a replacement upper receiver featuring a barrel of 10.3" (262mm) in length. The shorter barrel makes the weapon significantly more compact, which makes it easier to use in and around vehicles and in tight confined spaces. Special units such as commandos boarding ships have found such shortened weapons very useful and use them very often. The Mk18 is an AR-15 variant. Mechanically, AR-15 is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. It is less reliable than comparable designs when dirty, but the closed system very effectively seals it from the outside, which prevents any dirt and mud from preventing the internals - this means that the AR-15s are less prone to external elements than eg. AKM. Mk18 is praised for it's light weight and short dimensions, which make it very easy to handle. It has it's drawbacks, however. The short barrel doesn't provide enough muzzle velocity for the bullet - small and light 5.56mm bullet deals damage by fragmenting and yawing in the tissue, but it requires a certain velocity to do so and Mk18 provides it only at the muzzle. Beyond point-blank range the bullet might not work properly and produces only "ice pick" wounds, as in, passes straight through without doing much damage - if it doesn't hit vital organs straight away, it will not disable the target and multiple hits might be needed. Because of this, US special forces use special dedicated frangible 5.56mm ammunition that deforms easily even at slower speeds. Without this ammunition however Mk18's terminal ballistics are rather disappointing. Nonetheless, the Mk18 is a very good weapon in it's niche and while it lacks universality of 14"-20"-barreled rifles it will not let it's user down in the situations it was designed for.

%c[0,170,170,170]The M27 Infantry Automatic Rifle is a lightweight automatic weapon based on the HK416 rifle designed to fulfill role of automatic rifleman's weapon. The M27 is meant to provide more precise suppression than M249 for the cost of lower volume of fire. At first it was intended to only replace SAWs in USMC, but later on it was chosen as a service weapon, replacing the M4A1 and M16A4. The M27 IAR was adopted as the standard issue service rifle of the Marine Corps infantry in 2018. The M27 is basically HK416 with heavy barrel, other differences are minor. HK416 is a 5.56x45mm assault rifle developed in Germany by Heckler and Koch. It is based on AR-15 rifle, sharing the aesthetics and ergonomics with it, but it uses a gas piston system (used before in G36) which greatly increases the weapon's reliability. HK416 system uses a short-stroke piston that forces the bolt carrier to the rear; this design prevents combustion gases from entering the weapon's interior — a drawback of direct impingement systems which reduces weapon's reliability and parts life. The HK416 is considered by many to be one of the best assault rifles of modern times - it is light, reliable, ergonomic and can be customized to fit operator's needs. M27's heavy barrel further increase the durability of weapon as it overheats slower, which increases the potential barrel life. Free-floating barrel provides exceptional accuracy up to 2MOA, which makes M27 fit for precise long range shooting - the M27 with high-power optics mounted were adopted as M38 Designated Marksman Rifle. M27s so far aren't used outside US Marine Corps and PMC companies who receive them on special conditions. Some mercenary teams in The Zone who are operating with Ukrainian government permit are using these weapons in small numbers during their operations, which started speculations about US government participation. However, since observers from most western countries, including US, are present in the cordon outposts, it is possible that these mercenaries simply bought or stole these rifles from US soldiers who were there only on security operation.

%c[0,170,170,170]ADAR 2-15 is a modified variant of the AR15, the civilian version with single fire mode only, intended for civilian use, an assault rifle chambered in 5.56x45mm and developed by ADAR Oruzhie in the mid 2010s. Mechanically, AR-15 is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. It is less reliable than comparable designs when dirty, but the closed system very effectively seals it from the outside, which prevents any dirt and mud from preventing the internals - this means that the AR-15s are less prone to external elements than eg. AKM. Stalkers are sometimes distrustful when it comes to these weapons, since most of the stalkers believe in the rumor saying that AR-15 rifles are more prone to jam in the zone, they prefer a relatively used AK rifle over a new AR-15, and due to these weapons on black market are old variants which are much less reliable than modernized units of US military. The ADAR 2-15 is a rather modern and new rifle, so it's less likely to find an old unit. These rifles are nonetheless well liked for their comfortable ergonomics and accuracy, which are much higher than those of old AK rifles.

%c[0,170,170,170]The Ruger Mini-14 is an American 5.56x45mm rifle developed in 1960s by Sturm, Ruger and Co. for civilian, hunting and law enforcement applications. The name Mini-14 was chosen because the weapon is similar to M14 rifle, but is chambered in smaller cartridge. Mechanically, Ruger Mini-14 is a gas operated, semi-automatic only weapon which uses Garand-type rotary bolt with two lugs. Action is operated by the long-stroke gas piston, which is located below the barrel and is concealed within forend of the stock. Manual safety is also patterned after M1 rifle, and is located at the front of the trigger guard. Standard stock of the Mini-14 is of single-piece type, with semi-pistol grip and separate heatshield above the barrel. Early Mini-14 rifles had wooden heatshileds which exposed operating rod; current production civilian guns feature polymer heatshields which cover most of the operating rod. Standard sights consist of a blade-type front and adjustable diopter-type rear sight; "Ranch" type rifles also had integral scope mounts on the receiver, which will accept proprietary Ruger scope rings. Overally, the Mini-14 is a relatively simple and cost-effective rifle and gained relatively high popularity in the USA, where for a long time it was a cheaper alternative to AR-15 rifles, however, after AR-15s became more popular and their prices dropped, Mini-14 sales diminished. Mini-14 has it's drawbacks compared to AR-15. It's "classic" stock design means it has higher recoil and muzzle rise, ergonomy is also worse than in AR-15. Some users were also critical of weapons' quality and design's reliability in difficult conditions. The rifle also never became popular in Europe, and are relatively rare on the black market; because of this, they're only very rarely seen in The Zone, where they're used as an alternative to military designs like AR-15 or AK-74.

%c[0,170,170,170]M60E3 is a modified variant of M60, an American general purpose machine gun chambered in 7.62x51mm NATO cartridge. During World War II, the US Army was under great impression of German MG34 and MG42 machine guns. After the war ended, US decided to copy both the German doctrine of light machine gun as a primary source of firepower of the squad, but also the weapon itself. Americans used solutions from MG42 and FG42 (paratrooper battle rifle) and put them together. The outcome was the M60 - gas-operated, air-cooled, belt-fed machine gun that fires from the open-bolt. All parts are made from stamped sheet metal for cheap and easy manufacture. One of the M60's unique features is that it was designed to be easy and effective while shooting from the shoulder or from the hip. Slow rate of fire and specially designed gas system reduce the recoil, and the polymer handguard - a feature often overlooked even in more modern LMGs - allows for relatively comfortable holding without the risk of burning one's hand from the heated receiver after prolonged fire. M60 was praised for it's controllability, light weight and high firepower, but was heavily criticized for unsatisfactory reliability and durability. It also had design flaws, for example lack of quick-change barrel or inseparability of the barrel from the gas system regulator and the bipod. Especially it's durability was the main reason the M60 was withdrawn from service. Old M60s in US service often jammed, the parts were breaking or separating and falling out. Newer variants fixed these issues, but not entirely. Old M60s were sold or sent to many countries as military aid. Currently a number of these machine guns are available on the black market, including the arms dealers in The Zone. These old M60s are not well liked due to it's low reliability in harsh conditions of anomalous zones, but are valued for their ability of effective shooting from the shoulder. They are sometimes used by mutant hunters squad, as they can bring high firepower without need to deploy and can bring mutants down quickly.

%c[0,170,170,170]Barrett M82 is an American .50 caliber (12.7x99mm) anti-materiel rifle. It's one of the most powerful rifles used by militaries for anti-materiel and sniper duty. In early 1980s Ronnie Barrett started works on his rifle inspired by use of .50cal heavy machine guns for long-range shooting in Vietnam - famous sniper Carlos Hathcock set a world record for long range kill with M2 HMG. The M82 was a success and, under the name M107, it is used as an anti-materiel rifle for destroying unexploded ordnance, radios, antennas, vehicle engines or fuel tanks. .50 caliber bullet can pierce thick walls, metal plates and go through vehicle engine block while retaining enough energy to remain lethal, making it a perfect weapon for stopping vehicles and killing enemies behind heavy cover or in heavy body armor. The Barret M82 is a recoil operated, short barrel stroke, semi-automatic firearm. The receiver consists of two parts made from stamped sheet metal, connected by cross-pins. Heavy barrel is fluted to improve heat dissipation and save weight, and fitted with large and effective reactive muzzle brake. M82A1 rifles are fitted with a bipod, scope mount and a folding backup iron sights. Picatinny rail on receiver allows for using any type of optical sight; military standard is usually Leupold M-series 10x scope. The Barrett M82 is an effective weapon that was a revolutionary design which started the era of .50cal sniper rifles - after it's success a lot of new anti-materiel weapons and high caliber sniper rifles emerged. It is large and heavy, but it's expected with weapon of this type. It's real drawbacks are less than perfect reliability and the unsatisfactory accuracy at about 3MOA (similar to M16A4 rifle) which doesn't let it use full potential of .50 caliber bullet on ranges above 800m (however, it was never intended to be a "true" sniper rifle). Instead, sniper teams tend to use dedicated .50 caliber sniper rifles, like MacMillan TAC-50, while the M82 is used against enemies behind cover or in vehicles on more typical engagement ranges. M82 can be bought on civilian market with right permit and some stalkers smuggled these rifles to The Zone for use as high-power hunting weapons. Just like all other high-bore rifles, the M82 excels at engaging big mutants from the long range, where the shooter remains safe.

%c[0,170,170,170]Minimi is a Belgian belt-fed light machine gun chambered in 5.56x45mm cartridge, designed and developed by FN Herstal. It is classified as Squad Automatic Weapon - a subcategory of light machine guns chambered in intermediate cartridge, similar to Soviet RPD light machine gun. It's production began in 1982 and it became an instant hit, being adopted by more than 75 countries, most notably Australia, Great Britain, Italy and USA, which adopted it as M249 SAW. Mechanically, Minimi is an air cooled, gas operated, belt fed automatic weapon. It uses a conventional gas action with the gas piston located below the barrel, and the barrel is locked using the traditional rotary bolt. Open bolt reduces the overheating and allows for prolonged fire. The barrel is quick-detachable, with carrying handle to aid in barrel change procedure. Minimi can be fed using ammunition belts or AR-15 magazines, however, the magazine feeding is only for emergency situations as stoppages commonly occur when using it. Belts are fed from special 200 round plastic boxes that can be clipped beneath the receiver. The Minimi's biggest advantages are high rate of fire and very good controllability with minimal recoil, which make it very easy to provide suppressing fire with, without the need to deploy it on the bipod. High rate of fire allows to send a lot of lead down range in short duration. It is also very compact compared to typical light machine guns, which improves the maneuverability and handling. The Minimi however is relatively heavy at 7.5kg (RPK-74 weights 4.7kg), however it's still lighter than M60 or M240 LMGs. Another drawback is it's accuracy, which is lower than that of typical assault rifles chambered in the same 5.56x45mm caliber. Minimi was also criticized for unsatisfactory reliability, however, most of the problems with it in US military are from the old age of these guns which were heavily used and not properly maintenanced. In The Zone, Minimis can be sometimes (albeit rarely) seen on black market, coming from withdrawn military surplus, which then reached the black market. Some PMC mercenary groups also use Minimis and M249s for extra firepower, especially for expeditions in the areas with high mutant activity.

%c[0,170,170,170]The M24 Sniper Weapon System (SWS) is a military variant of Remington 700 rifle. Remington Model 700 is a series of bolt-action centerfire rifles manufactured by Remington Arms since 1962. After World War II, Remington Arms engineer Merle Walker began designing lower-cost alternatives to the Model 30, which resulted in the Model 721. Improvements to Model 721 created the Model 700 - one of the most famous and popular bolt-action rifles in the world. Remington 700 is a bolt-action rifle using Mauser-style bolt, similarly to famous Kar98k rifle. The bolt operates smoothly, which makes the rifle comfortable and increases rate of fire. It is designed for mass production and isn't as refined as more expensive models, but nonetheless Remington 700 is a solid and reliable rifle with very good accuracy. The M24 and M40 military sniper rifles used by the US Army and USMC are both based on the Model 700 design. Remington 700 variants are also used by police units all around the world. It is also one of the most popular hunting rifles and is often used as a platform for custom tactical rifles, often reaching very high levels of accuracy. M24 is a variant created for military needs. It has stainless steel match barrel and stock made out of a composite of Kevlar and graphite. M24 can chamber both 7.62x51mm NATO and .300 Winchester Magnum rounds for higher lethality and range. This particular rifle was rechambered to more powerful .338 Lapua Magnum cartridge and outfitted with high-power variable magnification scope.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Ergonomics: %c[0,170,170,170]above average %c[0,140,140,140]

%c[0,170,170,170]The Mosin M1891/30 rifle, officially called the "three-line rifle of 1891 pattern", is a Russian bolt-action rifle chambered in 7.62x54mmR. It was adopted in 1891 into the Tsarist armed forces of Russian Empire and stayed as the service rifle of Soviet Union until early 1950s, when it started to be gradually replaced by SKS carbines and, later, the famous AK assault rifles. However, the Mosin rifle still is used by multiple countries, mostly as a cheap sniper rifle, and is popular among civilians as target and hunting rifle. The Mosin is a manually operated, bolt-action rifle fed from internal, non-removable magazine holding 5 rounds. The magazine is loaded from top via clips or single rounds. The receiver is made of steel and is covered by wooden stock on whole length. The bolt of the rifle is of rather crude construction. It's biggest strength is it's durability and reliability. The construction has big tolerances which allows the user to operate the rifle reliably even when it is dirty or frozen. It's biggest drawback is the bolt, which requires relatively high amount of strength to operate it, which limits the speed with which it can be operated and in effect reduces the practical rate of fire. Mosin's accuracy is, contrary to popular belief, on par with other WWII bolt-action rifles. More than 40 millions of these rifles were produced. They remains on battlefields up to this day, often seen in Middle East, Asia, Africa and, lately, in the Ukraine. In The Zone the Mosin rifles are available for very cheap in huge amounts from both the civilian stocks or black market. Mosins are often used as hunting rifles, so some stalkers bring their own Mosins to The Zone with them. They are used there as hunting weapons or cheap sniper rifles, either using original sniper variants with factory-mounted scopes or field modifications with scope mounts welded on by technicians.

%c[0,170,170,170]Obrez is a sawn-off Mosin rifle. Revolutionaries, various irregular forces and common criminals cut down the Mosin–Nagant rifles to pistol size for easy concealment. This practice was born during the Revolution, but sawn-off Mosins were also popular among partizans and others who needed a compact and concealable weapon yet couldn't get themselves a pistol or a compact submachine gun. The Mosin M1891/30 rifle, officially called the "three-line rifle of 1891 pattern", is a Russian bolt-action rifle chambered in 7.62x54mmR. It was adopted in 1891 into the Tsarist armed forces of Russian Empire and stayed as the service rifle of Soviet Union until early 1950s, when it started to be gradually replaced by SKS carbines and, later, the famous AK assault rifles. They remains on battlefields up to this day, often seen in Middle East, Asia, Africa and, lately, in the Ukraine. In The Zone the Mosin rifles are available for very cheap in huge amounts from both the civilian stocks or black market. Since Mosin rifles are extremely cheap, they can be sawn-off to get cheapest possible compact weapon. In The Zone, Obrez are rarely made and used as last-ditch protection against wild animals and mutants. Powerful 7.62x54mmR cartridge has significant power, however, from such a short barrel the velocity loss is very high and the bullet doesn't have enough time to gain speed and accuracy. It is called a "budget hand cannon" for it's extreme recoil and muzzle flash.

%c[0,170,170,170]AKS-74 is a folding-stock variant of AK-74, a Soviet 5.45x39mm assault rifle that was designed in early 1970s as an answer to new US M16 rifle shooting new type of ammunition. Use of new, smaller cartridge increases accuracy and range and makes it much easier to take follow up shots with it, which increases the chances of hitting - all this while retaining durability and reliability of other AK rifles. AK-74 and it's variants still stay as service rifle of Ukrainian military and is one of the most popular weapons in The Zone due to it's reliability, accuracy, low price and readily available ammunition. Mechanically, it's a gas operated, selective fire assault rifle. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud. Overengineered receiver and chrome lined barrel provide exceptional durability, and the well-designed cartridge dimensions and strong action allow for reliable feeding in almost all conditions, even when the weapon is very dirty and/or corroded. Among main features of AKS-74 are the chambering in lighter and more accurate 5.45x39mm round and a new muzzle device, which further reduces the recoil, muzzle climb and the flash from firing, together with new type of stock which folds to the side. Furniture is slightly redesigned from AKM, early AK-74s used plywood furniture like AKM but big amount was also produced with dark-plum coloured polymer stock and handguards, which is more resistant to wear and slightly lighter than plywood. AK-74 and it's variants stay in service in more than 20 countries. AKS-74 also still stays as service rifle of Ukrainian military and is one of the most popular weapons in The Zone due to it's reliability, accuracy, low price and readily available ammunition. Lots of these rifles were stolen from military warehouses or bought off from corrupt military officials. Stalkers like AKS-74's folding stock as it is more compact, making it easier to carry.

%c[0,170,170,170]FAL is a 7.62x51mm battle rifle designed and manufactured in Belgium by FN. It is one of the most famous firearms of XX century, having been in service with more than 90(!) countries, which makes it almost as widespread as Soviet AK rifle. Works on the FAL began as early as in 1946 and in 1953 the FAL as it is known today was first produced. In 1956 it was adopted by Belgian Army, and almost at the same time the new rifle was adopted by UK, Austria, Canada, Australia, Argentina, Brazil and many more countries. Mechanically, FN FAL is a gas-operated firearm using a short-stroke gas piston system with tilting breechblock. The receiver is all steel with polymer furniture (L1A1 variant used by UK used wooden furniture). Adjustable and effective gas system reduces the recoil and makes FAL much more controllable than other battle rifles chambered in full-size cartridges (still, it is not advised to shoot it in bursts). It was produced in many variants and a lot of countries produced their own modernized versions. The FAL was used in many conflicts, including those with communist regimes (most notably Vietnam and Rhodesia), which got it a name "Right Arm of the Free World". It is regarded as effective, reliable and very durable rifle. It's disadvantage is a heavy, hard-hitting cartridge which makes it less universal as service rifle. It was finally replaced by more modern rifles chambered in 5.56x45mm NATO round, which is lighter and allows for higher volume of fire for the cost of range and power. FAL however still has it's niche and is used alongside newer assault rifles. Brazilian law enforcement and counter-terrorist units field it very often because of high-powered cartridge that provides very high wall penetration, which is important in firefights in favelas. Relatively high amount of FALs reached The Zone, where they are highly valued just like other battle rifles - their powerful round is desirable there due to it's higher effectiveness vs wild animals and mutants.

%c[0,170,170,170]FS2000 is a semi-automatic variant of F2000, a modern assault rifle chambered in 5.56x45mm cartridge designed and manufactured in Belgium by FN. It is an advanced, modular weapon system that consists of a bullpup assault rifle and a grenade launcher with optoelectronic fire control system. Mechanically the F2000 is a gas operated firearm with short stroke piston and rotating bolt, using tappet system similarly to Steyr AUG, with which it has a lot in common. It has a steel receiver enclosed in reinforced polymer housing of compact layout, which seals the internals from any and all external elements, like dust, mud and sand, which makes the weapon very resistant to hard environment. The weapon has 16" barrel but is very compact and easy to handle due to efficient bullpup construction. One of the most outstanding features of F2000 is a unique ejection system, which ejects spent brass forward through a tube running above the barrel. This makes the rifle completely ambidextrous, making it a great choice for both right- and left-handed shooters, and also allows the operator to switch hands during engagements (for example when leaning to the side). The ejection system is actually very simple and is not possible to clog or damage, so it doesn't reduce the weapon's reliability. F2000 is easy to field strip and dismounts into only four parts. Standard variant is equipped with 1.6x telescopic sight in polymer housing, which gives it futuristic look. F2000 was adopted by some elite special forces units and also became service rifle of the Slovenian Army. It was used in various armed conflicts, where it proven itself as a reliable and effective weapon. FN also made a civilian variant - FS2000, which fires only in semi-automatic mode. This FS2000 was fitted with heavy barrel, match trigger and hunting scope in order to make it effective on long range shooting.

%c[0,170,170,170]RPK-74 is a 5.45x39mm light machine gun (or squad automatic weapon) introduced together with AK-74 rifle in 1974. It was designed to replace older RPK light machine guns that used same ammunition as AK and AKM. Among differences there are longer, 590mm (23"), heavier barrel which overheats slower and allows for sustained fire, strenghened receiver and redesigned buttstock. It also has bipod mounted by default. It weights around 4.7kg which is heavy when compared to AK-74s, but is actually very nice when compared to other LMGs of it's time, like DP-28 (9.1kg), RPD or Minimi (around 7.5kg for both). It's weak sides are big dimensions and small capacity (it's fed from 45-rounds magazines, only 15 more than AK-74s) that reduces practical rate of fire, especially when compared to belt-fed light machine guns. The RPK-74 (Ruchnoy Pulemyot Kalashnikova - "Kalashnikov's Light Machine Gun") is a gas operated, magazine fed, air cooled, selective fire weapon. The basic action, with a long-stroke gas piston located above the barrel and a rotating bolt, is similar to that of the Kalashnikov assault rifle. The barrel is permanently fixed to the receiver and cannot be replaced in the field, which also limits it's potential as support weapon. A big plus is that RPK-74 and AK-74 magazines are interchangeable - RPK-74 has dedicated magazines with extended capacity, but it can use AK-74 mags when needed. Overally, RPK-74 is a weapon that provides longer range and allows to keep up the fire for longer than AK-74 rifle, but it's weight makes it less universal. It is liked in The Zone as a weapon for defensive purposes or when patrol needs heavier firepower than that given by AK rifles.

%c[0,170,170,170]RPK-74M is a 5.45x39mm light machine gun (or squad automatic weapon) which is a modernized variant of RPK-74, which was designed to replace older RPK light machine guns that used same ammunition as AK and AKM. Among differences there are longer, 590mm (23"), heavier barrel which overheats slower and allows for sustained fire, strenghened receiver and redesigned buttstock. It also has bipod mounted by default. It weights around 4.7kg which is heavy when compared to AK-74s, but is actually very nice when compared to other LMGs of it's time, like DP-28 (9.1kg), RPD or Minimi (around 7.5kg for both). It's weak sides are big dimensions and small capacity (it's fed from 45-rounds magazines, only 15 more than AK-74s) that reduces practical rate of fire, especially when compared to belt-fed light machine guns. The RPK-74 (Ruchnoy Pulemyot Kalashnikova - "Kalashnikov's Light Machine Gun") is a gas operated, magazine fed, air cooled, selective fire weapon. The basic action, with a long-stroke gas piston located above the barrel and a rotating bolt, is similar to that of the Kalashnikov assault rifle. The barrel is permanently fixed to the receiver and cannot be replaced in the field, which also limits it's potential as support weapon. A big plus is that RPK-74 and AK-74 magazines are interchangeable - RPK-74 has dedicated magazines with extended capacity, but it can use AK-74 mags when needed. Overally, RPK-74 is a weapon that provides longer range and allows to keep up the fire for longer than AK-74 rifle, but it's weight makes it less universal. The difference between RPK-74 and RPK-74M are basically only furniture - RPK-74M stock and handguards are made from glass-filled polyamide, which is more durable than wood or bakelite.

%c[0,170,170,170]RPK is a 7.62x39mm light machine gun (or squad automatic weapon) developed parallel with AKM rifle in the late 1950s. It was designed to replace RPD light machine guns that were considered to be relatively unreliable. RPK uses same ammunition as AK and AKM. Among differences there are longer, 590mm (23"), heavier barrel which overheats slower and allows for sustained fire, strengthened receiver and redesigned buttstock, RPK also has a bipod mounted by default. It weights around 5kg which is heavy when compared to AKs, but is actually very nice when compared to other LMGs of it's time, like DP-28 (9.1kg), RPD or Minimi (around 7.5kg for both). It's weak sides are big dimensions and small capacity (it's fed from 40-rounds magazines, only 10 more than AKs) that reduces practical rate of fire, especially when compared to belt-fed light machine guns. The RPK (Ruchnoy Pulemyot Kalashnikova - "Kalashnikov's Light Machine Gun") is a gas operated, magazine fed, air cooled, selective fire weapon. The basic action, with a long-stroke gas piston located above the barrel and a rotating bolt, is similar to that of the Kalashnikov assault rifle. The barrel is permanently fixed to the receiver and cannot be replaced in the field, which also limits it's potential as support weapon. A big plus is that RPK and AKM magazines are interchangeable - RPK has dedicated magazines with extended capacity, but it can use AK mags when needed. Overally, RPK is a weapon that provides longer range and allows to keep up the fire for longer than AKM rifle, but it's weight makes it less universal. It is liked in The Zone as a weapon for defensive purposes or when patrol needs heavier firepower than that given by AK rifles.

%c[0,170,170,170]XM8 is a modular assault rifle system developed by Heckler and Koch for US military in early 2000s. The XM8 design was originally part of the Objective Individual Combat Weapon program (OICW), which was developing a "smart" grenade launcher system with an underslung carbine rifle. The system was unable to meet performance and weight requirements and was eventually canceled. In the aftermath, the two portions of the OICW were separated, resulting in the XM8 and XM25 projects. Technically, XM8 is a derivative of the HK G36 assault rifle, and thus it is almost identical to that rifle in design and functioning. XM8 features a short piston stroke, gas operated action, with rotating bolt locking. Barrels are quick detachable and available in various lengths. The entire construction is modular and built around the polymer receiver with boltgroup; Magazine housings could be easily swapped for compatibility with various types of magazines; various buttstocks could be installed in a second for various roles (standard buttstock is a telescoped 5 position adjustable one).Top of the receiver is fitted with proprietary sight rail, which can accept illuminated red-dot sight, or any other type of sighting equipment. Detachable forend will be available in various sizes, and could be replaced with M320 40mm grenade launcher. Since XM8 didn't offer as much edge over AR-15-type rifles, like M4A1, the whole project was dropped, and the XM8 program was shut down. XM8 were adopted in small numbers by Malaysian special forces. Single units seem to be stolen since at least 3 of them were found in Ukrainian Exlusion Zone. They are, just like G36, liked for their low weight and higher reliability over AR-15 rifles, but lack of parts make them expensive in maintenance.

%c[0,170,170,170]VSK-94 is a 9x39mm rifle designed as a so called "para-sniper" weapon for use with scope and suppressor. It is basically an accurized version of 9A-91 rifle, developed as a cheaper alternative to VSS Vintorez rifle. Like 9A-91, it's made from steel stampings and it's construction is extremely simplified. It's distinctive feature is it's fixed skeletonized stock, similar to the one used in VSS Vintorez, but made entirely out of black polymer. It has scope rail and threaded barrel for attaching suppressor mounted by default - it is meant to be used as a marksman weapon with scope and silencer. It provides higher level of accuracy than 9A-91 rifle, but it is still not a rival for VSS when it comes to precision. Internally it's the same weapon as 9A-91. It's a gas operated firearm which utilizes a long stroke gas piston, located above the barrel, and a rotating bolt, just like Val. It's mostly used by Russian government agencies, but also military. Some VSK-94 rifles were also sold to Russia's allies, lately also Syria, where it's used by loyalist forces. In The Zone it can be relatively rarely found in hands of military and mercenaries or on black market.

%c[0,170,170,170]SKS is a Soviet semi-automatic carbine chambered in 7.62x39mm M43 cartridge. It was the first weapon designed for then-new 7.62x39mm M43 cartridge, the first Soviet intermediate round, which later became famous as chambering for the most famous rifle in the world, the AK. It was developed in 1943 by Sergei Simonov and became adopted in 1949. It was introduced together with AK rifle as Soviets were not sure if new automatic weapon will meet the expectations - however AK shown itself as an exceptionally good weapon and quickly replaced SKS in Soviet army. SKS started to become withdrawn in mid-1950s, shortly after it's adoption, as AK was better in almost every aspect. SKS carbines that were already produced were given to rear echelon troops and border guards, and the rest were sent to ally states of USSR, amongst them East Germany, China, North Korea and, most notably, the North Vietnam, where SKS rifles were deployed en masse and for the long time were the primary weapon of Vietnamese soldiers and guerilla fighters. Overally, the gun was a solid and successful design, it just came too late and couldn't rival the Kalashnikov's assault rifle design as a military weapon. It has way lower firepower than AK since it's practical rate of fire is limited by the non-removable magazine (it must be reloaded from stripper clips) and it can only fire in semi-automatic mode, but it has up to 50% higher accuracy compared to AK which makes it slightly more effective on distances above 200 meters. Mechanically, the SKS is a gas operated firearm with a short-stroke gas piston action, using basically the same principle as the PTRS-41 anti-tank rifle action - also the design of Sergei Simonov. It's biggest advantage today is that it's one of the cheapest military surplus rifles available, being a good choice for those who don't want to spend much for their first weapon.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]Shortened pump-action shotgun. Greatly increased shot spread. Lowered weight and good handling. %c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]Serbu Super-Shorty is a compact, stockless, 12 gauge pump-action shotgun. It is based on Mossberg 500 or Maverick 88 receiver. The shotgun features a spring-loaded, folding foregrip. Except for ultra-short barrel and cut-down magazine tube (which reduces capacity to only 3 or 4 rounds) the weapon is almost the same as it's parent. Mossberg shotguns are popular in law enforcement agencies and police departments, as well as among civilian gun owners and hunters. They are regarded as high-quality weapons that are dependable and of high quality. These shotguns utilize pump action, which is operated by a sliding forend. The forend is connected with the bolt group. The receiver is produced from lightweight aluminum alloy. Ammunition is fed from the tubular magazine that is located under the barrel. Pump action shotguns are popular in both the USA and Europe, and some stalkers brought these weapons, often legally owned, along with them into The Zone, where they are primarily used for defense against wild animals and mutants or hunting them. Super-shorty is a shotgun that is used exclusively for personal defense, as it doesn't have enough range and velocity (due to shorter barrel muzzle velocity is lower and the projectiles have less energy than when shot from longer barreled shotguns) to be used effectively for hunting. It can however deal very high damage in short range and potentially bring down most mutants or human attackers in one well placed shot. It is regarded as a very effective weapon against snorks, stray dogs and other mutants who rely on ambushes and quick leaps to attack their victim, as the short and compact shotgun can be quickly drawn and is very maneuverable. Most stalkers prefer cheaper double-barrel sawn-off shotguns for this task, but shortened shotguns like Serbu Super-Shorty have better handling and slightly higher capacity.

%c[0,170,170,170]Mossberg 590 Compact Cruiser is a compact, stockless, 12 gauge pump-action shotgun. It is based on Mossberg 590 - an American pump-action shotgun, developed as a premium-class shotgun for military specification. Mossberg shotguns are popular in law enforcement agencies and police departments, as well as among civilian gun owners and hunters. They are regarded as high-quality weapons that are dependable and of high quality. These shotguns utilize pump action, which is operated by a sliding forend. The forend is connected with the bolt group. The receiver is produced from lightweight aluminum alloy. Ammunition is fed from the tubular magazine that is located under the barrel. “Militarization” of Mossberg 500 into 590 included strengthening of the receiver and other parts, installation of the vented heat shield around the barrel, bayonet lug and extended magazine, as well as an aluminum trigger guard instead of a plastic one. Pump action shotguns are popular in both the USA and Europe, and some stalkers brought these weapons, often legally owned, along with them into The Zone, where they are primarily used for defense against wild animals and mutants or hunting them. Compact Cruiser is a shotgun that is used exclusively for personal defense, as it doesn't have enough range and velocity (due to shorter barrel muzzle velocity is lower and the projectiles have less energy than when shot from longer barreled shotguns) to be used effectively for hunting. It can however deal very high damage in short range and potentially bring down most mutants or human attackers in one well placed shot. It is regarded as a very effective weapon against snorks, stray dogs and other mutants who rely on ambushes and quick leaps to attack their victim, as the short and compact shotgun can be quickly drawn and is very maneuverable. Most stalkers prefer cheaper double-barrel sawn-off shotguns for this task, but shortened shotguns like Compact Cruiser have slightly better handling and higher capacity.

%c[0,170,170,170]Karabiner 43, also known as Gewehr 43, is a German World War II-era semi-automatic rifle chambered in 7.92x57mm Mauser cartridge. It was developed as a successor to Gew41(W) rifle, which was relatively unreliable. After the Wehrmacht invaded USSR, they captured SVT-40 semi-automatic rifle, which used excellent short-stroke piston gas system that worked flawlessly. Walther company copied this system and incorporated it into their design, creating the Gewehr 43 rifle. It is a steel-receiver semi-automatic rifle with wooden furniture, fed from a removable 10-round magazine, with manufacturing process simplified for mass production - while the rifle quality was held to highest standards, the parts are crudely finished and don't look as refined as pre-war Kar98k rifles. Every rifle has a scope rail, which allows for quick attachment of ZF-4 4x sniper scope (the plans for G43 featured adding one soldier with scoped rifle to every infantry squad of 12 soldiers, similarly to modern Designated Marksman tactic, but these plans never came into life). The G43 was a very effective weapon that worked reliably in the field, was very effective and well liked by soldiers. While it's accuracy is lower than that of bolt action Kar98k rifles, which means it's not as good as sniper weapon, it added much needed firepower to infantry squad, and it's precision was good enough for typical engagement ranges for use with 4x scope. After the war, these rifles were captured by Soviets and were sent to Middle East and Asia, while some were hidden by partisans in Eastern Europe. Probably this is the source of them in Ukraine, since they were in rare cases seen in The Zone in hands of stalkers, who use them as marksman rifles on long ranges where AKs don't do well. They can be acquired for cheap on black market, even though they reach very high prices on legal market, where they are sought after by collectors.

%c[0,170,170,170]The Ruger Redhawk is a DA/SA, large-frame revolver that was first introduced in 1979 by Sturm Ruger and Company. Made from high-grade steel, it is available in a stainless steel finish. Revolver is a repeating handgun that is fed from a revolving cylinder containing multiple chambers. Since the cylinder doesn't rely on gas or blowback for the cycling, it will cycle with each trigger pull, even if misfire occured - because of this, revolvers are usually considered much more reliable than semi-automatic pistols. They however have very complicated internals and are expensive to manufacture. The Redhawk is reinforced to handle extra stress of high-pressure loads, making it very popular for use by handloaders as it is able to handle the most powerful .45 Colt and .44 Magnum loads easily. In addition, the cylinder itself is longer than most competitors', allowing ammunition to be loaded to a longer overall length. This allows for either increased powder capacity, heavier (and therefore longer) bullets without compromising the powder load, or a combination of both. Custom ammunition manufacturers even have loads made specifically for Ruger revolvers that cannot fit in shorter chambers or revolvers of weaker construction (such as the Smith and Wesson Model 29). This makes the Redhawk a good choice as a bear defense gun among hunters and trappers. .44 Magnum revolvers, together with Redhawk, are a popular sidearm in areas with high activity of wild animals, such as Alaska or Ukrainian Exclusion Zone.

%c[0,170,170,170]The Model 19 is a .357 Magnum revolver produced by Smith and Wesson on its K-frame. The K-frame is somewhat smaller and lighter than the original N-frame .357, usually known as the SW Model 27. Revolver is a repeating handgun that is fed from a revolving cylinder containing multiple chambers. Since the cylinder doesn't rely on gas or blowback for the cycling, it will cycle with each trigger pull, even if misfire occured - because of this, revolvers are usually considered much more reliable than semi-automatic pistols. They however have very complicated internals and are expensive to manufacture. It was introduced in 1957 and still remains a valued weapon. Model 19 is considered a durable and well-finished revolver that works flawlessly. It was produced with blued steel or nickel-plated finish and wooden grips. It was adopted by multiple law enforcement organizations and police departments, and was also used as a concealed carry weapon by detectives, agents and civilians. It is less durable than Model 27, but also lighter than it, which makes it slightly better for a carry weapon. .357 Magnum loads have higher recoil than standard handgun rounds, but are nonetheless still controllable. Due to it's high power it is effective at defeating both human attackers and wild animals. Because of this, .357 Magnum revolvers, together with Model 19, are still a popular sidearm for personal defense against robberies and in areas with high activity of wild animals, such as Alaska or Ukrainian Exclusion Zone.

%c[0,170,170,170]The Smith and Wesson Model 29 is a double action handgun chambered for the .44 Magnum cartridge. Smith and Wesson Revolvers have a reputation for accuracy, smooth trigger pull, and a tight cylinder lock-up. They are similar in size and function to the Colt Trooper and Colt Lawman revolvers. Smith and Wesson revolvers are available in many variants, M29, M629, Quiet Special Purpose Revolvers (QSPR), Mountain Gun Variation, and others. The Model 29 was offered with 3, 4, 5, 6, 6 1/2, 8 3/8 and 10 5/8 inches (76, 102, 127, 152, 165, 213 and 270 mm) barrels as standard models. Other barrel lengths were available either by special order from Smith and Wesson's Custom Shop or custom built by gunsmiths. The 5 inches (130 mm) barreled variant had a full length underlug. Finish options available included a highly polished blued or nickel-plated surface. The six-inch model was the most popular generally, and the 8-inch model was intended for hunting. A 3-inch barrel version is very collectible, although not rare. A revolver is a repeating handgun that is fed from a revolving cylinder containing multiple chambers. Since the cylinder doesn't rely on gas or blowback for the cycling, it will cycle with each trigger pull, even if misfire occured - because of this, revolvers are usually considered much more reliable than semi-automatic pistols. They however have very complicated internals and are expensive to manufacture. The Model 29 was known for its very high quality finish and outstanding durability. The grip is very well profiled and the hand instantly takes a perfect position for accurate aiming. This revolver is still used and valued as a defensive sidearm. It is heavy and .44 Magnum loads have higher recoil than standard handgun rounds, but are nonetheless still controllable. Due to its high power it is effective at defeating both human attackers and wild animals. Because of this, .44 Magnum revolvers are still a popular sidearm for personal defense against robberies and in areas with high activity of wild animals, such as Alaska or Ukrainian Exclusion Zone. Model 29 was made famous worldwide by association with the fictional character "Dirty Harry" Callahan.

%c[0,170,170,170]Taurus M44 is a 6-round .44 Magnum double action revolver that was developed and produced by Taurus in Brazil. Revolver is a repeating handgun that is fed from a revolving cylinder containing multiple chambers. Since the cylinder doesn't rely on gas or blowback for the cycling, it will cycle with each trigger pull, even if misfire occured - because of this, revolvers are usually considered much more reliable than semi-automatic pistols. They however have very complicated internals and are expensive to manufacture. Taurus revolvers are based on Smith and Wesson designs, they are less finely-finished but are also much cheaper. Model 44 is chambered in powerful .44 Magnum cartridge. It has opinion of a reliable and relatively well made revolver, but it's durability and barrel life is considerably lower than that of high-end guns. It is nonetheless good enough for typical gun owner who need a weapon for personal defense or hunting. .44 Magnum loads have way higher recoil than standard handgun rounds or even .357 Magnum, which makes pulling off follow up shots harder, so they're not advised as a weapon against human attackers for those who haven't mastered this caliber. However, due to it's high power it is very effective at defeating wild animals, which makes it fit for both defensive use and hunting. .44 Magnum revolvers, together with Taurus M44, are a popular sidearm in areas with high activity of wild animals, such as Alaska or Ukrainian Exclusion Zone. In the latter case, the .44 Mag revolvers are often used as sidearms by mutant hunters, who need weapons using powerful ammunition that will provide highest possible ballistic performance.

%c[0,170,170,170]Mateba 6 Unica is a recoil operated semi-automatic revolver, one of only a few of this type ever produced. It was developed by Mateba company from Italy. The Mateba Model 6 uses the recoil from firing to rotate the cylinder and cock the hammer, unlike conventional revolvers, which depend on the user physically pulling the trigger and/or cocking the hammer to actuate the weapon's mechanism of operation. The Mateba Autorevolver's barrel alignment is different from most other revolvers. The barrel is aligned with the bottom of the cylinder instead of the top. This lowers the bore axis (line of the barrel) which directs the recoil in line with the shooter's hand thereby reducing the twisting motion or muzzle flip of normal revolvers. The gun's entire upper assembly (barrel, cylinder and frame) are mounted on rails on the lower frame, which houses the trigger, hammer, and grip, and recoils on firing. The rearward motion of the upper assembly cocks the hammer, and the cylinder is rotated on the forward stroke. This unique action makes this revolver a semi automatic weapon, making it one of the very few semi automatic revolver designs. This innovative design has it's drawbacks, however. Since the cylinder cycles on gas action, the Autorevolver loses one of revolvers' advantage which is the cylinder cycling anyway, even on misfire - in Unica the cylinder will jam, which means it is not more reliable than semi-automatic pistols. This means that Unica has disadvantages of both revolvers and pistols while not gaining much advantages, which limits it's usefulness, however, the low bore axis makes it a pretty accurate weapon. Since it uses powerful .44 Magnum cartridges, it can be used as an effective hunting handgun.

%c[0,170,170,170]Taurus Raging Judge is a five shot revolver designed and produced by Taurus International, capable of shooting .410 bore or 28 gauge shot shells. Taurus promotes the Judge as a self-defense tool against carjacking and for home protection. Mechanically it is a standard revolver - a repeating handgun that is fed from a revolving cylinder containing multiple chambers. Since the cylinder doesn't rely on gas or blowback for the cycling, it will cycle with each trigger pull, even if misfire occured - because of this, revolvers are usually considered much more reliable than semi-automatic pistols. The rifling of Judge's barrel is shallower than normal, giving bullets less stabilization than in typical handguns, but also reducing the rapid dispersion of the shot from shot shells. The Judge is a controversial weapon of niche usefulness. The shot shell discharged from short barrel provides very high power in point-blank ranges, but rapidly loses effectiveness past even as little as few meters. It is sometimes used as a sidearm similarly to large-bore Magnum revolvers in areas with risk of attacks by wild animals, such as bears. It is also very rarely used by mutant hunters in The Zone as a defensive weapon, however it's disappointing range and relatively high price results in many preferring a sawn-off shotgun instead. The Judge's advantage is five rounds in the cylinder and higher compactness. Whether it is worth it or not depends on situation and purpose.

%c[0,170,170,170]Smith and Wesson Model 500 is a five-shot, double/single action large-bore revolver firing the .500SW Magnum cartridge - the most powerful handgun cartridge in existence. Mechanically it is a standard revolver - a repeating handgun that is fed from a revolving cylinder containing multiple chambers. Since the cylinder doesn't rely on gas or blowback for the cycling, it will cycle with each trigger pull, even if misfire occured - because of this, revolvers are usually considered much more reliable than semi-automatic pistols. Model 500 was built on the entirely new X-Frame, which was developed exclusively to handle the immense muzzle velocity and pressures generated by the .500 Magnum cartridge. Instead of a traditional barrel, the SW500 uses a rifled tube inside a barrel shroud that is secured by tension from the front. This tensioning leads to stability, making barrels cheaper to produce and resulting in a more accurate revolver. The advanced design of the firearm helps in counteracting the recoil felt by the shooter. This includes the sheer weight of the firearm, use of rubber grips, the forward balance, and the use of a compensator. Nonetheless, the .500SW cartridge produces immense recoil, there were cases when the Model 500 simply flew off hands of untrained shooters. It is used only as a recreational or big-game hunting weapon, because of high recoil follow-up shots are almost impossible to take unless the shooter is strong and has excellent training, and it is advised against using it as a defensive weapon against human attackers, muggers or intruders. These guns gained unexpected rise in popularity in Eastern Europe after Exclusion Zone emerged in Ukraine. Since this place has high activity of wild animals and mutants and it is more probable that inhabitants and stalkers will be attacked by them rather than human attackers, high caliber Magnum revolvers, including the SW500, became an obvious choice as a defensive carry weapon. While less powerful cartridges such as .44Mag and .50AE are enough in most cases, the .500SW weapons also became used by mutant hunters and stalkers exploring The Zone for their sheer power and ability to kill even most fierce mutants in few hits.

%c[0,170,170,170]Manurhin MR-96 is a French-manufactured, double-action revolver chambered in .357 Magnum. Revolver is a repeating handgun that is fed from a revolving cylinder containing multiple chambers. Since the cylinder doesn't rely on gas or blowback for the cycling, it will cycle with each trigger pull, even if misfire occured - because of this, revolvers are usually considered much more reliable than semi-automatic pistols. They however have very complicated internals and are expensive to manufacture. Manurhin revolvers are made for exceptional durability and accuracy - the barrel and trigger are match grade. The frame, cylinder, and barrel of the MR73 are made from ordnance-certified, alloyed steel. Barrels are manufactured by cold-hammering. The rifling is formed during the forging process, eliminating the need to cut the rifling as a separate manufacturing step. This creates an extremely hard and microscopically smooth internal barrel surface. MR-73 and MR-96 are used by multiple police forces, including GIGN. MR-96 are very rare on market and they reach relatively high prices. .357 Magnum loads have higher recoil than standard handgun rounds, but are nonetheless still controllable. Due to it's high power it is effective at defeating both human attackers and wild animals. Because of this, .357 Magnum revolvers, together with Model 19, are still a popular sidearm for personal defense against robberies and in areas with high activity of wild animals, such as Alaska or Ukrainian Exclusion Zone.

%c[0,170,170,170]FAR-15 is a custom weapon based on AR-15 rifle with customized parts, rechambered to 6.8x43mm SPC catridge which provides better terminal ballistics. The AR-15 is an American 5.56x45mm assault rifle developed by Eugene Stoner in 1960s. It was designed as a lightweight automatic rifle using a modern, light, small-bore ammunition which allowed the soldier to carry more ammunition. In 1960 first AR-15 rifles were ordered for USAF, and in 1963 the rifle was officially adopted as the M16. It serves up to this day in multiple variants and is still considered to be one of the most universal and modular weapons in the world. AR-15s are also well-liked by civilian gun owners, hunters and sportsmen for their accuracy, effectiveness and simplicity. Mechanically, AR-15 is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. It is less reliable than comparable designs when dirty, but the closed system very effectively seals it from the outside, which prevents any dirt and mud from preventing the internals - this means that the AR-15s are less prone to external elements than eg. AKM. In the 2002 the 6.8 SPC cartridge was developed, and first AR-15s chambered in this cartridge appeared. It provides good terminal ballistics even when fired from short barrels (5.56 fragments only when muzzle velocity is high enough) and is only slightly heavier; the only disadvantage is it's high price. For those who don't mind higher price, for example shooting using optics, the AR-15 chambered in 6.8 SPC might be a good idea. In The Zone some of these rifles were brought in by stalkers and mercenaries who want to bring in more power to the field, especially vs mutants.

%c[0,170,170,170]Skorpion vz. 61 is a Czechoslovak 7.62x17mmSR machine pistol developed in 1959 for Czechoslovak military. It was designed as a personal defense weapon for drivers, tankers, pilots and artillery crews, who needed higher firepower than that of a pistol, yet didn't need (or couldn't have) heavy and long rifles. Mechanically, it's a select-fire, straight blowback-operated weapon that fires from the closed bolt. The cartridge used produces a very low recoil impulse and this enables simple unlocked blowback operation to be employed. Skorpion’s compact dimensions were achieved by using a telescopic bolt assembly that wraps around a considerable portion of the barrel. As the bolt is relatively light, an inertial rate reducer device housed inside the wooden pistol grip lowers the weapon's rate of fire from 1000RPM to a more manageable 850RPM. Skorpion's advantages are very low recoil, small dimensions and simplicity of construction. It's main drawback is the ammunition which deals weak tissue damage, however, with it's rate of fire and controllability, several hits can be achieved to counteract this. These weapons were pretty successful and were used by a lot of countries, including USSR, East Germany, Vietnam, Yugoslavia, Libya and Egypt. A lot of them reached the black market, which gained them reputation of "gangster weapon". They're plentiful all over the Europe, including Ukrainian Exclusion Zone, where they are well liked and often used for personal defense or as a cheap alternative to "true" submachine guns.

%c[0,170,170,170]The Scorpion EVO 3 is a modern Czech submachine gun, developed by Ceska Zbrojovka in 2009. It's name is a nod to old vz. 61 machine pistol called Skorpion (written with "k"), but it's not mechanically similar nor is in same category, being closer to MP5 or UMP submachine guns. It is a simple blowback operated, selective fired weapon that fires from closed bolt. It has a separate hammer unit, with ambidextrous safety / fire mode selector, that offers single shots, 3-round bursts and full automatic fire modes. The receiver, pistol grip / trigger unit and the forend all are made from polymer. The side-folding shoulder stock is also made from polymer, and can be adjusted for length of pull due to telescopic design. The receiver has universal rails added by default, which allows for optical sights and additional attachments being mounted, depending on operator's needs. Scorpion EVO is considered to be one of the best modern submachine guns. It's produced with very high quality materials, it is very light, compact and comfortable to shoot, allowing to shoot even long bursts with minimal recoil. Multiple countries adopted EVO to their police, counter-terrorist and special forces units, including Czech Republic, Finland, Poland, Serbia and Argentina. In The Zone, EVO is used mostly by mercenaries and those who need a light and compact weapon when they need to carry heavy weight and loot, or those who carry an unwieldy primary weapon such as heavy sniper rifles, and need something for protection in close range.

%c[0,170,170,170]PPSh-41 ("Pistolet Pulemyot Shpagina" - Shpagin's Submachine Gun), is a famous Soviet 7.62x25mm submachine gun designed by G. Shpagin. It saw extensive use in the Red Army during World War II and became one of the most famed and widely known weapons ever - it's distinct shape is instantly recognized by anyone who is interested in World War II. PPSh was developed by Georgy Shpagin in 1941 to replace expensive and less-reliable PPD-40 submachine gun. Shpagin's idea was to produce a submachine of very simple design and with parts made from metal stamping - production process that was revolutionary back then. The PPSh-41 was a great success - by the spring of 1942, the Soviet factories produced 3000 "papashas" every day, and until end of production in 1947 more than six millions of these weapons were made. Mechanically, it is a blowback operated submachine gun firing from an open bolt. To decrease the recoil stress, gun was fitted with bolt buffer at the rear of receiver. It is very simple to maintain, upon field strip only three parts come out that need to be cleaned. Most parts are made from metal stampings, stock is made of wood. It's only flaw was rushed quality control - some specimens have badly fitted parts and some can't even use magazines from other units, because they simply won't fit. Later on, only stick magazines were produced as drums were heavy, awkward to handle and increased chances of jamming. The PPSh was very efficient and reliable and was well respected even by it's opponents - Germans actually officially adopted captured PPSh-41s into service and Americans used some of them in Korean war. High amounts of these submachine guns were sent to countries like China, Vietnam, Laos, Iraq and many others, in the end about 30 countries all around the world. Today it is still used and can be seen in the Middle East, North Africa and Ukraine. Black market is flooded with these weapons and they are readily available in The Zone for very low prices, which makes them very affordable and popular as a first choice for defensive close-range weapon, especially for those stalkers who don't need to fight on long ranges and are more worried of mutant activity.

%c[0,170,170,170]UMP is a submachine gun family designed and manufactured by Heckler and Koch in the late 1990s as a successor to the famous MP5 submachine guns. It was meant to be cheaper and less complicated in production, but the MP5's high demand caused it to still remain in production alongside UMP. The UMP is a blowback-operated select-fire submachine gun firing from a closed bolt. The receiver is made of polymer and controls are fully ambidextrous. UMP can be fired in full-auto, in single shots, and in 2 or 3 round bursts (optional). It also has a bolt hold-open device, which traps the bolt in the open position when the last round from the magazine has been fired. This submachine gun has a side-folding stock and two sets of Picatinny rails, allowing to mount various types of optical sights and other equipment. UMP was at first designed for .40SW and .45ACP cartridges for higher effectiveness against unarmored enemies, but soon the 9x19mm variant also entered production. All three variants are used by various counter-terrorist and special forces groups all around the world. The UMP is said to be more reliable in harsh environment than MP5, and as such more fit for military service, it is also lighter than MP5. It is currently one of the most commonly used submachine gun in Europe. In The Zone, UMP submachine guns are rarely available on black market and are well liked for their great handling, low weight and compact size, making it very good weapon for scavengers and artifact hunters who don't need a fighting weapon and just want something light to carry on them for personal defense from mutants and bandits at close range.

%c[0,170,170,170]APS is a Soviet machine pistol chambered in 9x18mm. It was developed as a personal defense weapon for soldiers who need more firepower than pistol can provide, but also deem an assault rifle an overkill, like artillerymen, vehicle crews and pilots, among others. Igor Stechkin made his first machine pistol as early as in 1948, and after some upgrades, in the 1951 the APS as we know it entered the service. Mechanically, it is a simple blowback pistol of steel construction, with external hammer and a double action trigger. It has a fire rate reducer installed, which lowers it's cyclic rate to 650-750 RPM - significantly lower than other typical machine pistols (like M93R or G18) that often have rates of 1000-1300RPM because of the blowback system; so the difference is very high and Stechkin is easier to control because of that. Users praised it's firepower improvement over typical pistol and compact size when compared to typical submachine gun. However, the APS was declared too heavy, uneffective on longer ranges, and also it's reliability was too low - it was jamming too often for a military weapon. The AKS-74u replaced Stechkin in rear echelon units and vehicle and team weapon crews and the new Russian SMGs replaced it in law enforcement agencies. The special operators and some soldiers however kept using it as a sidearm providing high firepower. In this role it is however also being replaced by OTs-33 Pernach.

%c[0,170,170,170]GSh-18 is a Russian semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x19mm Parabellum cartridge. It was developed specially for use with improved armor-piercing ammunition which produces very high chamber pressure. GSh-18 stands for names of designers, Grazev and Shipunov (famous for their aircraft autocannons, like GSh-23), 18 stands for ammo capacity. Mechanically, GSh-18 is a rotating-barrel, short recoil, locked-breech pistol with 10 locking lugs spaced equally around the barrel, the large locking surface area resulting in a strong lockup, making it suitable for high-velocity ammunition loads. The frame is made of polymer, which reduces weight greatly - GSh-18 is one of the lightest military pistols. The trigger is striker fired, like in Glock pistols, which allows for safe carrying with round in the chamber, but is relatively stiff, which limits practical accuracy. Pistol featured low bore axis, similar to sport pistols, which reduces recoil and improves accuracy. Whole GSh-18 design was made to withstand high pressure of 9x19mm armor-piercing loads, which makes the pistol more resistant to wear from shooting, however, users reported inadequate quality of slide and various parts, which makes the pistol more prone to breakages from different mechanical damage. Another disadvantage is trouble with magazines, which require special tools for loading - if the tool is lost, the magazines can't be loaded past 10 rounds. The pistol also has high recoil despite low bore axis construction. Overally it is rather a niche weapon and is definitely not an universal pistol, but it's barrel life and high capacity might make it a good tool for those who can make use of AP ammunition. GSh-18 are used only by Russian army and special forces. Small batch of these pistols came with some Mercenaries groups, who are rumored to receive funding from Russia. Other than that, these pistols are rather rarely seen.

%c[0,170,170,170]AKM is a modernized variant of AK rifle ("Avtomat Kalashnikova", Kalashnikov's Automatic Rifle), a Soviet assault rifle chambered in 7.62x39mm M43 cartridge, designed and developed by Mikhail Kalashnikov as a replacement for old rifles and submachine guns, which went on to become the most famous assault rifle ever designed, serving in many countries with more than 100 million units made. Mechanically, it's a gas operated, selective fire assault rifle. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud. Overengineered receiver and chrome lined barrel provide exceptional durability, and the well-designed cartridge dimensions and strong action allow for reliable feeding in almost all conditions, even when the weapon is very dirty and/or corroded. Due to it's great balance of firepower, accuracy, reliability and low price, the AK is often considered the "gold standard" and a point of reference among assault rifles. AKM has many improvements over first AK-47s, biggest ones being stamped receiver, which reduced weight by nearly 1 kilogram compared to milled receiver AK, new barrel mount type that improves accuracy and straight buttstock made of plywood, which reduces felt recoil and is more resistant than old-type stock made from one part of wood. All these changes make AKM even more effective weapon than original AK-47. However, it still has it's drawbacks, such as still subpar accuracy when compared to newer designs, use of corrosive ammunition which is harsh on internals and finally ergonomics which are average at best. In The Zone the AKM rifles are very common since it's one of Ukrainian military rifles and a lot of them were stolen from warehouses or bought from corrupt military officials. They are well liked for their very high reliability and firepower, and it's powerful 7.62mm round makes it more effective against wild animals and mutants than comparable 5.45x39mm and 5.56x45mm chambered rifles.

%c[0,170,170,170]Saiga-12 is a Russian shotgun available in multiple variants and configurations based on the famous AK rifle's action that is widely considered as the most reliable in the world. It is a powerful and reliable weapon, on par with modern semi-automatic shotguns of western production. It is a well liked and respected weapon and, apart from high popularity among hunters and civilian gun owners, it became adopted by various government units, like Russian internal affairs special forces, US law enforcment agencies and Ukrainian Navy. Saiga-12 is a gas operated firearm that uses the same long stroke gas piston action as all rifles of Kalashnikov system. It's a gas operated, selective fire weapon. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud. Since shotgun shells are nearly twice as wide as 7.62x39mm cartridge, the extraction port in the side of the dust cover had to be increased in size. It is often used and well liked in The Zone, as it's sheer power coupled with power of 12-gauge shotgun shells makes it a very effective weapon against wild animals and mutants that pose the greatest risk there. Duty faction hunter squads require owning a weapon that has "above average big-game hunting potential" for those who wish to join them and listed Saiga-12 as an example of effective hunting weapon.
