%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]Semi-automatic shotgun based on AK layout. Very high damage output. Shortened barrel increases ergonomy and effectiveness in CQB.%c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]Saiga-12 is a Russian shotgun available in multiple variants and configurations based on the famous AK rifle's action that is widely considered as the most reliable in the world. It is a powerful and reliable weapon, on par with modern semi-automatic shotguns of western production. It is a well liked and respected weapon and, apart from high popularity among hunters and civilian gun owners, it became adopted by various government units, like Russian internal affairs special forces, US law enforcment agencies and Ukrainian Navy. Saiga-12 is a gas operated firearm that uses the same long stroke gas piston action as all rifles of Kalashnikov system. It's a gas operated, selective fire weapon. The gas operated action has a massive bolt carrier with a permanently attached long stroke gas piston. The bolt carrier moves on the two rails with visible clearances between the parts, which allows the gun to operate even when it's interior is severely fouled with sand or mud. Since shotgun shells are nearly twice as wide as 7.62x39mm cartridge, the extraction port in the side of the dust cover had to be increased in size. It is often used and well liked in The Zone, as it's sheer power coupled with power of 12-gauge shotgun shells makes it a very effective weapon against wild animals and mutants that pose the greatest risk there. Duty faction hunter squads require owning a weapon that has "above average big-game hunting potential" for those who wish to join them and listed Saiga-12 as an example of effective hunting weapon.

%c[0,170,170,170]TT-33 is a Soviet semi-automatic pistol chambered in 7.62x25mm TT round. It was developed in the early 1930s by F. Tokarev as a service pistol for the Soviet military to replace the already obsolete Nagant M1895 revolver. It served in Soviet military until 1952 when it started being replaced by Makarov's PM pistol. Almost 2 millions of these pistols were produced and after the war were used multiple countries that used USSR's military aid. Externally, the TT-33 is very similar to John Browning's blowback operated FN Model 1903 semiautomatic pistol, and internally it uses Browning's short recoil tilting-barrel system from the M1911 pistol. The Tokarev TT is a short recoil operated, locked breech pistol of all-steel construction. It wasn't the best design and often failed. The single action trigger has no safeties. The only safe way to carry TT is to always have an empty chamber. The production quality was rather low, and unlike other Soviet designs, in TT-33 it is actually a big problem. The pistols' durability is sub-par and it rusts quickly, so it requires a lot of maintenance. Nonetheless, the TT-33 is in no way an ineffective weapon and if kept clean it will serve it's owner well. It's biggest advantage in modern times is it's chambering - 7.62x25mm round is very powerful and can penetrate soft body armor. This ability, together with it's low price which made it basically a throw-away weapon made it a perfect choice of assassination weapon for mafia members in 1990s Russia. TT pistols are plentiful on black market and are very common in The Zone. Very low price make them a good choice for rookie stalkers who don't have much money to spend on more modern handgun.

%c[0,170,170,170]OTs-33 Pernach is a Russian machine pistol chambered in 9x18mm, developed by Igor Stechkin as a successor to the famous APS machine pistol. The designers were tasked with resolving the difficulty of controlling recoil in full-auto mode present in the Stechkin APS pistol and simplifying it for combat deployment. The new pistol has a "square" shape, which is simpler (and less expensive) to manufacture and has a novel operating principle that increases controllability and reduces recoil. OTs-33 is a hammer fired, blowback operated handgun with double action trigger. The construction is all steel. Fire selector and manual safety are present. To reduce recoil and muzzle rise, some propellant gases are diverted into a ported slide cavity that acts as a muzzle brake and compensator, deflecting the gases upward to stabilize the barrel. Thanks to it, Pernach is easier to control than APS. It however still has some drawbacks, most notably it's weight, dimensions and awkward double action trigger. OTs-33 was adopted into MVD and law enforcement agencies, but it didn't replace APS completely. Some of these handguns reached the black market in the exlusion zone, where they are well liked and used as a sidearm for extra firepower, just like all other machine pistols.

%c[0,170,170,170]Karabiner 98 kurz, also known as Kar98k, is a German bolt-action rifle chambered in 7.92x57mm cartridge (also known as 8mm Mauser), designed and developed by Mauser in 1930s for request of German army. Kar98k is in essence a shortened version of Gewehr 98 rifle which was the service rifle of German army from 1898 and became the most successful bolt-action rifle of it's time. German army found that shortening the barrel greatly improved handling and made maneuvering the rifle much easier, while the loss of accuracy and range was almost non-existant. That way the Kar98k became the service rifle of German army and completely replaced the long and unwieldy Gew98. Mechanically, the Mauser Kar98k is a manually operated, bolt-action rifle fed from internal, non-removable magazine holding 5 rounds. It uses bolt of Mauser M98 system, which is extremely reliable and works very smoothly. Kar98k bolt handle is bend downwards, which makes it easier to store and carry and also allows for more comfortable bolt operation over straight bolt, like in Gew98 or Mosin rifle. Mauser action became the most successful bolt-action design in the world and almost every modern bolt action rifle, including high-end sniper rifles, use Mauser type action. The magazine is loaded from top via clips or single rounds. Sights consist of simple notch front sight and leaf type rear sight, which allow for relatively good practical accuracy. Overally, Kar98k is an extremely successful design, by many considered to be the best bolt-action rifle of WWII. It provides extremely high reliability, easiness of use, simple construction and high accuracy. It was however criticized for it's sights, which are rather obsolete compared to peep sights of M1903A3 or Lee-Enfield sights that provide longer sight line, allowing for more precise aiming. 15 millions of Kar98k rifles were produced to 1945. Most of them survived the war and were stored in warehouses, then sold to poorer countries as military aid or on civilian market as hunting rifles - Kar98k rifles make up for biggest part of hunting rifles in Europe. These rifles are common in The Zone where they are used for hunting and long-range shooting.

%c[0,170,170,170]G36 is a 5.56x45mm assault rifle designed in the early 1990s by Heckler and Koch in Germany as a replacement for the heavier G3 battle rifle, which was chambered in full-power 7.62x51mm round. In the years 1990-1995 the HK50 project was developed, and in 1996 the new rifle, accepted into Bundeswehr as G36, entered the production. The G36 is completely different from other designs like G3, HK33 or MP5; it is a gas operated firearm using a short stroke gas piston with rotating bolt, similarly to AR-18 system. Whole external housing, carrying handle and folding stock is made of carbon fiber-reinforced polymer which is very durable and immune to corrosion. Hammer forged, chrome-lined barrel is free-floating, which improves accuracy. G36 comes with optical sights by default; the standard variant has a 3x scope and a reflex sight, export variants (G36E, G36V) have 1.5x sight; the rifle also accepts AG36 underbarrel grenade launcher and all other attachments that can fit on RIS rails (in newer variants). G36 has a long, 480mm (18.9") barrel, which provides high muzzle velocity, increasing performance of 5.56mm bullet which needs certain velocity to yaw and fragment in tissue properly to deal damage. Apart from German Army a lot of other countries use it as army service rifles or weapons for special forces. G36 was used in Iraq and Afghanistan, where it proved itself as a reliable and effective weapon. At one point, German forces had overheating problems with these weapons, they were however traced to faulty ammo and not the G36 rifles themselves. A lot of G36s were sent to Kurdistan's Peshmerga, who use them with great success. Relatively high numbers of these rifles reached The Zone, probably from the Middle East, and multiple European PMC groups came armed with these weapons. They are very valued by stalkers for their high precision and very good ergonomics.

%c[0,170,170,170]G36K is a carbine variant of the G36, a 5.56x45mm assault rifle designed in the early 1990s by Heckler and Koch in Germany as a replacement for the heavier G3 battle rifle, which was chambered in full-power 7.62x51mm round. In the years 1990-1995 the HK50 project was developed, and in 1996 the new rifle, accepted into Bundeswehr as G36, entered the production. The G36 is completely different from other designs like G3, HK33 or MP5; it is a gas operated firearm using a short stroke gas piston with rotating bolt, similarly to AR-18 system. Whole external housing, carrying handle and folding stock is made of carbon fiber-reinforced polymer which is very durable and immune to corrosion. Hammer forged, chrome-lined barrel is free-floating, which improves accuracy. G36K has ironsights and can mount any optical sight on top rail while the standard variant has a 3x scope and a reflex sight; the rifle also accepts AG36 underbarrel grenade launcher and all other attachments that can fit on RIS rails (in newer variants). G36K has a shortened 318mm (12.5") barrel, which makes it a rough equivalent of carbines such as M4A1. Short length makes it easier to maneuver, but somewhat limits the performance of 5.56mm bullet which needs certain velocity to yaw and fragment in tissue properly to deal damage. G36K was used in Iraq and Afghanistan, where it proved itself as a reliable and effective weapon. At one point, German forces had overheating problems with these weapons, they were however traced to faulty ammo and not the G36 rifles themselves. Some of of these weapons reached The Zone used by European PMC groups that came armed with these weapons. They are very valued by stalkers for their high precision and very good ergonomics.

Whole external housing, carrying handle and folding stock is made of carbon fiber-reinforced polymer which is very durable and immune to corrosion. Hammer forged, chrome-lined barrel is free-floating, which improves accuracy. G36K has ironsights and can mount any optical sight on top rail while the standard variant has a 3x scope and a reflex sight; the rifle also accepts AG36 underbarrel grenade launcher and all other attachments that can fit on RIS rails (in newer variants). G36K has a shortened 318mm (12.5") barrel, which makes it a rough equivalent of carbines such as M4A1. Short length makes it easier to maneuver, but somewhat limits the performance of 5.56mm bullet which needs certain velocity to yaw and fragment in tissue properly to deal damage. G36K was used in Iraq and Afghanistan, where it proved itself as a reliable and effective weapon. At one point, German forces had overheating problems with these weapons, they were however traced to faulty ammo and not the G36 rifles themselves. Some of of these weapons reached The Zone used by European PMC groups that came armed with these weapons. They are very valued by stalkers for their high precision and very good ergonomics.

%c[0,170,170,170]G36C is a commando-length carbine variant of G36, a 5.56x45mm assault rifle designed in the early 1990s by Heckler and Koch in Germany as a replacement for the heavier G3 battle rifle, which was chambered in full-power 7.62x51mm round. G36 was adopted to Bundeswehr in 1996 together with it's carbine variant, the G36K. In 2001, an even shorter version, designed for police units and special forces operators, was unveiled - the G36C. It has 228mm (9") barrel, which is closer to HK53 or AKS-74u than M4A1 or G36K. This makes the G36C very compact and maneuverable, but also lowers the velocity and potential tissue damage of bullet, as small 5.56mm bullets need certain velocity to tumble and fragment in tissue. The range is also lower compared to G36K. Mechanically, the G36C is just as standard G36, which is a gas operated firearm using a short stroke gas piston with rotating bolt, similarly to AR-18 system. Whole external housing, carrying handle and folding stock is made of carbon fiber-reinforced polymer which is very durable and immune to corrosion. G36C doesn't have an optical sight by default, but has a RIS rail on the carrying handle where user can mount desired optics. G36C is a very successful weapon, it was adopted by multiple countries' special forces units and police departments, most notably in USA, Great Britain, Canada, France and Germany, and is considered a reliable and effective weapon. In The Zone it was used by UN expedition forces and multiple Mercenaries groups are using these carbines alongside full-size G36 rifles. G36C's are very valued by all stalkers for their compact size and light weight, which makes it very easy to carry on long expeditions, where one must carry a lot of loot.

%c[0,170,170,170]MG36 is a light machine gun (or SAW/LSW, depending on nomenclature) based on the G36, a 5.56x45mm assault rifle designed in the early 1990s by Heckler and Koch in Germany. It is slightly more resistant to heat and is designed to be used with 100-round C-Mag magazine for increased firepower. Mechanically the MG36 is based on G36, which is a gas operated firearm using a short stroke gas piston with rotating bolt, similarly to AR-18 system. Whole external housing, carrying handle and folding stock is made of carbon fiber-reinforced polymer which is very durable and immune to corrosion. MG36 has a slightly heavier barrel which can fire higher amount of rounds without overheating. It was supposed to provide suppressing fire without risk of barrel damage or so called cook-off (explosion of cartridge due to high temperature), however, the added thickness wasn't very big and the MG36 was deemed to be only marginally more heat-resistant than standard G36 rifle. It also has a bipod mounted by default. The weapon feeds from 100-rounds Beta C-Mag, which however sometimes jams easily; standard G36 magazines can be used when needed. MG36 comes with 3x telescopic sight and reflex sight combo just like standard G36, some were modified to use RIS rail handles instead, on which other optical sights can be mounted. Overally, the MG36 wasn't a very successful weapon and is no longer offered by HK. Some of these machine guns were seen in The Zone, probably sold by former users to PMCs.

%c[0,170,170,170]Object 62 is an experimental kinetic weapon system developed as a top secret project back in Soviet Union. The weapon works on Gauss rifle (also known as coil gun) principle. It is a type of projectile accelerator consisting of one or more coils used as electromagnets in the configuration of a linear motor that accelerate a ferromagnetic or conducting projectile to high velocity. Since the electromagnets require very high energy to reliably accelerate projectiles, it was first developed as a mounted anti-tank gun, but after Soviet Union collapsed, the works on the Gauss gun stopped. It is unknown what happened with the project after the Second Disaster, but small arms similar to resized Soviet Gauss anti-tank guns started being found in hands of Monolith fighters. Scientific analysis found that the weapon uses the power of Flash artifact to supply the coils with energy and sends 9mm projectiles down range with ultra high velocity. The rifle is incredibly accurate and has very flat trajectory. The projectile's velocity provides very high penetration, exceeding that of high-velocity bullets with tungsten-core fired from classic firearms that use combustion gases as means of shooting bullets. Since the velocity is very high, the projectile ice-picks through tissue and does relatively low damage compared to it's huge energy, but it's still roughly equivalent of .338 Lapua Magnum bullet. Contrary to popular belief, the Gauss rifle has high recoil due to very high energy, but as the energy is dispersed over time it is greatly reduced compared to sheer power. The Object 62 rifles are very powerful sniper and anti-materiel rifles and are extremely expensive. All Object 62 rifles are an object of interest to military and should be brought back for military evaluation.

%c[0,170,170,170]OTs-14 is a Russian modular assault rifle built in bullpup configuration. It was intended for special operation forces, law enforcement and counter-terrorist agencies. It was planned in multiple versions, but only 9x39mm variant saw actual use. Due to unsatisfactory performance these weapons weren't issued since 1999. OTs-14 Groza (Russian: "Thunderstorm") is based on the standard AKS-74u receiver and action, modified for the larger 9x39 subsonic ammunition favored by various Spetsnaz troops for it's very good penetration factor and terminal ballistics. In the grenade-launching configuration, a single trigger controls both the 40mm launcher and the rifle itself, with a separate barrel selector. Today, some of these rifles are used by Ukrainian special forces sent to The Zone, as their compact size makes them fit for airborne troops, and good terminal performance makes them effective in close combat. Just like AKS-74u, this weapon is prone to overheating and it's specific gas system means it is quickly getting dirty, requiring care and constant cleaning. It's finish quality leaves much to desire, which can possibly mean it's durability is not on par with other AK types. It's handling is very good and it's very effective in close quarters, but it's short line of sight and awkward, heavy trigger makes it very poor weapon for longer ranges. They can also be found on black market and in hands of Mercenary groups. A number of these rifles were also seen in hands of Duty force recon groups, which started suspicions that Duty is being secretly supported by Military or Mercenaries, who supply them with weapons and ammunition.

%c[0,170,170,170]Browning Hi-Power is a semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x19mm Parabellum, developed by John Browning and FN Herstal factory in years 1914-1935. It was one of the most successful semi-automatic pistols of it's times and was the first of "wonder nine" pistols, starting a new era in world handgun development. Hi-Power was designed by famous genius firearms inventor John Browning (also creator of M1911 pistol). It was a recoil operated, locked breech pistol using linkless cam locking system (a change from M1911 system). The construction is all steel with wooden or polymer grips; the trigger is single action only. The most important feature of HP is it's high capacity, which was achieved by use of a staggered column magazine for 13 rounds - typical pistols of 1920s held no more than 8 rounds, often even less. Browning HP had a huge advantage over these pistols, especially since it's not any bigger than typical pistol of that time. For a very long time the Browning HP was considered one of the best pistols in the world, outclassing the competition with it's reliability and firepower. It was adopted by more than 50 countries, among them UK, Canada, Australia, Germany, France, Argentina and many more. After 82 years of continuous production, the Hi-Power was finally discontinued in 2017, but these pistols still remain in use by many armies. Overally, the Browning HP is a reliable and durable pistol with high capacity magazine. It was definitely the best pistol of it's time and still remains a viable weapon. It's disadvantages however are relatively heavy weight with big dimensions (like all steel pistols of these times) and a heavy trigger, especially for a single action pistol. A lot of these pistols reached the black market after being withdrawn and are one of the most common handguns in the Europe. They are very popular in The Zone as they are available for cheaper than modern 9x19mm handguns. Many stalkers prefer Brownings over most common pistols, the Makarovs or TT-33s, for it's higher capacity and more effective cartridge.

%c[0,170,170,170]L85A1 is a British 5.56x45mm bullpup assault rifle designed and developed by Royal Small Arms Factory (Enfield). It was made to replace L1A1 SLR (FN FAL variant) as a service rifle of British military as NATO switched to 5.56x45mm cartridge. FN FAL was a very good weapon, but it was heavy and used full-power rifle cartridge (7.62x51mm) which produced high recoil and made follow-up shots harder; apart from that, soldiers could carry much more 5.56x45mm ammunition. Mechanically, L85A1 is a gas operated weapon using short-stroke gas piston system. Receiver is made of stamped sheet steel, reinforced with welded and riveted machined steel inserts; furniture is made of polymer. Every L85 has an optic rail mounted by default and all of British infantrymen's L85 rifles are outfitted with SUSAT scopes; those used by other branches of the British armed forces are configured with fixed iron sights. L85A1 was a weapon plagued with design flaws. The rifle jammed very often even when only slightly dirty, the magazines fell out and dented easily, the parts worn out very quickly, were brittle and broken easily and the weapon often required serious repairs that could not be performed in the field. In Gulf War the weapon jammed so notoriously that it was deemed one of the worst assault rifles in the entire world. The LANDSET report identified in excess of 50 faults, and British MoD contracted German company Heckler and Koch - manufacturer of MP5, USP and G3, among others - to fix and upgrade the rifle. The HK version, the L85A2, is almost a whole new rifle. It performs relatively well, no worse by other service rifles, but it's terrible reputation remained. Almost every L85A1 was upgraded to A2 standard, but some apparently were stolen or lost and resurfaced on black market in The Zone. It is disdained by stalkers for it's lack of reliability, especially in harsh conditions of anomalous zones, but is used by some due to it's exceptional accuracy, integrated optics and uncommonly low price for a 5.56x45mm rifle.

%c[0,170,170,170]L85A1 is a British 5.56x45mm bullpup assault rifle designed and developed by Royal Small Arms Factory (Enfield). It was made to replace L1A1 SLR (FN FAL variant) as a service rifle of British military as NATO switched to 5.56x45mm cartridge. FN FAL was a very good weapon, but it was heavy and used full-power rifle cartridge (7.62x51mm) which produced high recoil and made follow-up shots harder; apart from that, soldiers could carry much more 5.56x45mm ammunition. Mechanically, L85A1 is a gas operated weapon using short-stroke gas piston system. Receiver is made of stamped sheet steel, reinforced with welded and riveted machined steel inserts; furniture is made of polymer. Every L85 has an optic rail mounted by default and all of British infantrymen's L85 rifles are outfitted with SUSAT scopes; those used by other branches of the British armed forces are configured with fixed iron sights. L85A1 was a weapon plagued with design flaws. The rifle jammed very often even when only slightly dirty, the magazines fell out and dented easily, the parts worn out very quickly, were brittle and broken easily and the weapon often required serious repairs that could not be performed in the field. In Gulf War the weapon jammed so notoriously that it was deemed one of the worst assault rifles in the entire world. The LANDSET report identified in excess of 50 faults, and British MoD contracted German company Heckler and Koch - manufacturer of MP5, USP and G3, among others - to fix and upgrade the rifle. The HK version, the L85A2, is almost a whole new rifle. It performs relatively well, no worse by other service rifles, but it's terrible reputation remained. Almost every L85A1 was upgraded to A2 standard, but some apparently were stolen or lost and resurfaced on black market in The Zone. It is disdained by stalkers for it's lack of reliability, especially in harsh conditions of anomalous zones, but is used by some due to it's exceptional accuracy, integrated optics and uncommonly low price for a 5.56x45mm rifle.

%c[0,170,170,170]L85A2 is a British 5.56x45mm bullpup assault rifle designed and developed by Royal Small Arms Factory (Enfield). It was made to replace the ill-fated L85A1, which itself was made to replace L1A1 SLR (FN FAL variant) as a service rifle of British military. L85A1 was a faulty design and an extremely unreliable weapon. Mechanically, L85A1 is a gas operated weapon using short-stroke gas piston system. Receiver is made of stamped sheet steel, reinforced with welded and riveted machined steel inserts; furniture is made of polymer. The rifle jammed very often even when only slightly dirty, the magazines fell out and dented easily, the parts worn out very quickly, were brittle and broken easily and the weapon often required serious repairs that could not be performed in the field. In Gulf War the weapon jammed so notoriously that it was deemed one of the worst assault rifles in the entire world. The LANDSET report identified in excess of 50 faults, and British MoD contracted German company Heckler and Koch - manufacturer of MP5, USP and G3, among others - to fix and upgrade the rifle. The HK version, the L85A2, is almost a whole new rifle. Among A2 changes were a redesigned cocking handle, modified bolt, extractor and a redesigned hammer assembly that produces a slight delay in the hammer's operation in fully-automatic fire, improving reliability and stability. The A2 also has rails that allow to attach more equipment, it also accepts new optics and ACOG and ELCAN SpecterOS scopes are usually used. L85A2 performs relatively well, no worse by other service rifles, but it's terrible reputation remained. L85A2 is still a heavy and not an exceptionally durable rifle, but it is extremely accurate and has very low recoil. Almost every L85A1 was upgraded to A2 standard, but some apparently were stolen or lost and resurfaced on black market in The Zone. L85A2 is used only by British military, but some of PMC teams, including those in The Zone, were found to be rarely using them.

%c[0,170,170,170]LR-300 is an American 5.56x45mm assault rifle designed by Allan Zitta and manufactured by Z-M Weapons. It is based on AR-15 rifle and was designed as upgrade for it. The AR-15 is an American 5.56x45mm assault rifle developed by Eugene Stoner in 1960s. It was designed as a lightweight automatic rifle using a modern, light, small-bore ammunition which allowed the soldier to carry more ammunition. AR-15 is a gas operated firearm that uses direct gas impingement system with a rotating bolt. The rifle has a straight-line recoil design, which reduces the muzzle rise to minimum. It is however less reliable than comparable designs when dirty, and the receiver extension, which is a long buffer tube, an integral part of the cycling system, doesn't allow the folding stock to be mounted (the AR-15 stock is actually mounted "around" this tube). LR-300 design changes it by using an adapted version of the standard direct impingement gas system which removes the need for a receiver extension. The gas key, which contains the return spring, is extended beyond its normal length to form an operation rod, like in M14 or AKM, extending into the top of the forward handguard, the bolt carrier is also only half as long; in result, there's no need for the recoil buffer tube, which is normally protruding backwards into the stock. In the end the LR-300 is more compact while being even slightly more reliable than the typical AR-15 type rifle like M4 or M16. Apart from that, LR-300 is basically the same as every other AR-15. It has same lower receiver, trigger and barrel. On top of the receiver there is RIS rail that allows for mounting optics and other attachments. LR-300 was only bought in limited numbers for few police departments in the USA and some were bought by PMC groups. These rifles received media attention when they were spotted in The Zone, where one of the mercenary teams (probably part of one of PMC companies mentioned before) fielded these weapons. Some were also sold on black market and, just like other AR-15s, received relatively high popularity among stalkers, who praise it for it's light weight and exceptional ergonomics, especially when compared to heavier and less comfortable AK rifles.

%c[0,170,170,170]MP5 is a 9x19mm submachine gun designed and manufactured by Heckler and Koch in former West Germany in the late 1960s. It was based on G3 rifle, scaled down and rechambered to 9x19mm pistol cartridge. It is one of the most widely known weapons in the world and became somewhat of a symbol of special forces and counter-terrorist groups. To this day the MP5 is considered a gold standard of the submachine guns. More than 100 variants of MP5 were made, all to perfectly fit needs of their operators. Most important are A2 (fixed stock), A3 (telescopic stock), SD (integrated suppressor) and MP5K (shortened PDW). A2 and A3 with burst mode are called A4 and A5. Mechanically, MP5 is a submachine gun of all-steel construction using a roller-delayed blowback action, firing from closed bolt. Whole receiver is made of stamped sheet metal, which makes MP5 easy and cheap to manufacture. The furniture is made of strong synthetic polymer. Iron sights are the same diopter sights like on G3, but adjusted to 9x19mm round. The hammer-forged barrel is free floating, which gives MP5 unmatched accuracy, limited only by 9x19mm rounds' ballistics. One of the biggest advantages of MP5 is extremely low recoil which is very easy to control, even when shooting long bursts. The MP5 is a reliable and durable weapon, however, there were reports of it jamming when not maintained properly, so it should be cleaned often. MP5 was adopted by more than 40 countries, mostly by special forces, law enforcement and counter-terrorist groups. Multiple mercenary groups also use MP5s with great success. A number of MP5 submachine guns reached the black market and are available in The Zone, where they are well liked for their great handling, low weight and compact size, making it very good weapon for scavengers and artifact hunters who don't need a fighting weapon and just want something light to carry on them for personal defense from mutants and bandits at close range. Very cheap 9x19mm ammunition means lower upkeep cost of submachine guns, including MP5.

%c[0,170,170,170]MP5K is a personal defense weapon based on the MP5 submachine gun. It was developed for use by police units, bodyguards and all those who needed an easily concealable weapon with higher firepower than typical pistol, similarly to Mini-Uzi. The main differences between MP5K and MP5 are shorter barrel and lack of stock (or different, shorter stock in MP5-PDW variant). MP5K also has a small, fixed front grip for improved handling (since the same round recoils more violently in smaller and lighter weapon). MP5K accepts the same magazines and accessories (like laser sights or silencers) as MP5. Apart from that, MP5K is exactly the same as MP5. Mechanically, MP5 is a submachine gun of all-steel construction using a roller-delayed blowback action, firing from closed bolt. Whole receiver is made of stamped sheet metal, which makes MP5 easy and cheap to manufacture. The furniture is made of strong synthetic polymer. Iron sights are the same diopter sights like on G3, but adjusted to 9x19mm round. The hammer-forged barrel is free floating, which gives MP5 unmatched accuracy, limited only by 9x19mm rounds' ballistics. One of the biggest advantages of MP5 is extremely low recoil which is very easy to control, even when shooting long bursts. The MP5 is a reliable and durable weapon, however, there were reports of it jamming when not maintained properly, so it should be cleaned often. A number of MP5K submachine guns reached the black market and are available in The Zone, where they are well liked for their great handling, low weight and compact size. It is often used as a sidearm by those who use sniper rifles or machine guns as their primary weapons, which are rather hard to use in close range. Very cheap 9x19mm ammunition means lower upkeep cost of submachine guns, including MP5.

%c[0,170,170,170]MP5SD is an integrally suppressed variant of MP5 submachine gun, designed and manufactured by Heckler and Koch in former West Germany in the late 1960s. While all MP5s can be fitted with silencers, this version is equipped with a non-detachable integral sound suppressor and vented barrel to reduce bullet muzzle velocity down to below the speed of sound, allowing for use of standard 9x19mm ammunition instead of special subsonic rounds. This silencer is much more effective than screw-on silencers and offers unmatched sound reduction. Apart from integral suppressor, the MP5SD is exactly the same as MP5. Mechanically, MP5 is a submachine gun of all-steel construction using a roller-delayed blowback action, firing from closed bolt. Whole receiver is made of stamped sheet metal, which makes MP5 easy and cheap to manufacture. The furniture is made of strong synthetic polymer. Iron sights are the same diopter sights like on G3, but adjusted to 9x19mm round. The hammer-forged barrel is free floating, which gives MP5 unmatched accuracy, limited only by 9x19mm rounds' ballistics. One of the biggest advantages of MP5 is extremely low recoil which is very easy to control, even when shooting long bursts. The MP5 is a reliable and durable weapon, however, there were reports of it jamming when not maintained properly, so it should be cleaned often. MP5SD was adopted by many countries' special forces for use in stealth missions. Very small number of MP5SD submachine guns reached The Zone, mostly by mercenary groups who use them for assassinations and stealth actions. MP5SD are rare and expensive and very sought after.

%c[0,170,170,170]MP7 is a German personal defense weapon chambered in 4.6x30mm HK, designed and manufactured by Heckler and Koch as a direct competitor to FN P90. It was designed from ground up as a compact, light, fully-automatic machine pistol shooting a small round of high velocity that defeats even heavier types of body armor. 4.6x30mm round can defeat level III armor using FMJ rounds and level IV using AP ammunition. It also has high rate of fire with almost non-existant recoil, which makes it very easy to put multiple rounds in one place, further adding to it's armor-piercing capability. The action of the MP7 is somewhat unusual for weapon of such small size, since it is gas operated, rotating bolt design, which strongly resembles the action of the HK G36 assault rifle, respectively scaled down. The receiver of the MP7, along with integral pistol grip, is made from the polymer with steel reinforcements. Top side of the receiver has a Picatinny rail allowing to mount sights. The sights are simple and foldable, the MP7 is usually outfitted with optical sights. Telescopic buttstock can be extended to give additional stability. MP7 is relatively successful design and was adopted by militaries and law enforcement agencies of more than 15 countries. MP7's advantages are very low recoil, high accuracy and high rate of fire with rounds that reliably penetrate heavy armor. However, the MP7 received critique for it's insufficient lethality, as the small 4.6mm bullets have disappointing terminal ballistics and deal relatively low damage. Because of this, special forces groups started using hollow point bullets when fighting against enemies who don't use body armor. PMC groups operating in The Zone sometimes use MP7s as PDWs for those who carry a lot of equipment or heavy long range weapons, like heavy sniper rifles, yet need something with more firepower for defense at close range.

%c[0,170,170,170]MP9 is a compact machine pistol designed and manufactured by Brugger and Thomet Co. of Switzerland. In itself it is a further development of Steyr TMP project, which was sold by Steyr in 2001. Differences from the TMP include a stock that folds to the right side of the weapon, an integrated Picatinny rail, and a new trigger safety. Mechanically, it is a blowback operated weapon with a locked breech design, with - interestingly - rotating barrel. After the shot, the bolt with barrel locked to it will move backwards, then, the barrel rotates and this movement is used to unlock the bolt. The whole receiver is made of polymer, which reduces the weight. The MP9 shoots with high rate of fire of 900 rounds per minute, but is relatively easy to control and comfortable to shoot. It is effective as PDW or for concealed carry for security and bodyguards. It is currently used by multiple police and security forces, among them ones from France, Switzerland and Thailand. Russian Alpha Group of FSB also uses these compact weapons. In The Zone they are sometimes used by Mercenaries as personal defense weapons, as they bring good firepower while being very compact and light.

%c[0,170,170,170]MP40 is a German WWII 9x19mm submachine gun developed in 1938 by Erma Werke in Third Reich. It was often nicknamed Schmeisser, as allies believed Hugo Schmeisser to be designer of this weapon (he was designer of MP18 and MP28), but it's not true - MP40's designer was Heinrich Vollmer. The MP40 is considered to be one of the best submachine guns of the World War II and long after. Mechanically, the MP40 is a blowback operated weapon that fires from an open bolt. It was fully-automatic only, but a relatively slow rate of fire permitted single shots with short trigger pulls. The proprietary bolt system with telescoped return spring guide served as a pneumatic recoil buffer, helping to decrease the rate of fire to a very manageable level. The folding shoulder stock made the MP40 very compact when folded. MP40 was made entirely out of stamped steel, which made it cheap and quick to manufacture. It was accurate, had extremely low recoil (thanks to it's low rate of fire and specific construction) and was made with very high quality. It's reliability was above average, lower than Soviet weapons like PPSh but better than other SMGs of that time. The MP40 was the standard SMG of German military. After WWII MP40s were sent to other countries as military aid, most notably Israel, Syria, Libya, China, Vietnam and Korea. In Vietnam, US special forces used MP40s instead of American weapons. A lot of MP40s reached the black market and resurfaced in various places in the world, including The Zone, where, just like all other old submachine guns, are used as weapons for personal defense by those who don't need heavy and long rifles. Such SMGs, with their compact size, are well liked by scavengers and artifact hunters who need as much mobility as possible. They are used as cheap alternative to more modern submachine guns, but due to excessive weight they usually aren't very well liked and are used only by those who can't afford more modern weapons.

%c[0,170,170,170]SIG MPX is a modular submachine gun designed and manufactured since 2015 by SIG Sauer, primarily made for military and law enforcement. Since its introduction it's considered a serious competitor to MP5 and UMP. Its operating system is pretty unique for a submachine gun, as it's a gas-operated firearm, featuring a closed, rotating bolt. The construction is based on AR-15 layout, and the MPX keeps its ergonomics and controls style. It has an aluminium alloy receiver, which reduces weight. Receiver has accessory rails which allow user to add necessary accessories and optical sights. Unlike most other submachine guns, the SIG MPX is a gas operated weapon, utilizing short-stroke gas piston and rotary bolt locking. MPX shoots from closed bolt for increased accuracy and safety. It is a completely modular weapon, user can configure it to use different calibers - so far in offer are 9x19mm, .40SW and .357 SIG. Barrels can be quickly replaced without need for any tools. Overally, SIG MPX is a true modern submachine gun, light, compact, modular and reliable. In The Zone, MPX submachine guns are rarely available on black market and are well liked for their great handling, low weight and compact size, making it very good weapon for scavengers and artifact hunters who don't need a heavy fighting weapon and just want something light to carry on them for personal defense from mutants and bandits at close range. Very cheap 9x19mm ammunition means lower upkeep cost of submachine guns, including MPX.

%c[0,170,170,170]The Spectre M4 is a 9x19mm submachine gun developed in 1980s by Italian manufacturer SITES for use by counter-terrorist and police units. It has a compact design and high rate of fire. Very short barrel and compact size place it close to weapons such as MP5K or Kiparis. Spectre is a striker-fired, recoil-operated submachine gun firing from a closed bolt. The receiver of the Spectre is made from thin stamped steel. The bolt is so designed that it acts as an air pump to push air through barrel shroud and provide additional cooling for the barrel and action, which is very useful when firing long bursts. A simplistic stock is available, but sometimes this weapon was also used without any stock. High-capacity magazines hold 50 rounds of 9x19mm rounds, which allows for prolonged shooting, even though the weapon shoots very rapidly at 850 rounds per minute. Overally, the Spectre is a very compact submachine gun/machine pistol hybrid, but it's capacity and firepower is pretty high. It is currently used by Swiss and Italian counter-terrorists and military special forces. In The Zone, Spectre submachine guns are sometimes available on black market and are well liked for their great handling, low weight and compact size, making it very good weapon for scavengers and artifact hunters who don't need a fighting weapon and just want something light to carry on them for personal defense from mutants and bandits at close range. Very cheap 9x19mm ammunition means lower upkeep cost of submachine guns, including the Spectre.

%c[0,170,170,170]The Agram 2000 is a Croatian 9x19mm submachine gun based on the Beretta M12, however with increased rate of fire. It is a recoil-operated firearm, firing from an open bolt. Agram has steel receiver, but the trigger group and magazines are made mostly of polymer, which reduces the weight. The front grip has unconventional loop-like shape, which was intended to make it easier to control in longer bursts. The sights can be set on 75m and 150m - pretty optimistic considering the weapon has no buttstock to stabilize it. The quality of production leaves a lot to be desired, and the weapon has opinion of having poor reliability. The Agram was used by Croatian special forces. After the civil war in Yugoslavia, a lot of these SMGs found their way to black market, where they fell into hands of various criminals - because of that, the weapon became somewhat infamous in the Europe, similar to how MAC-11 and TEC-9 became stereotypical "gangster weapons" in USA. These guns reached The Zone from the black market, where some are used by stalkers who need a compact automatic weapon for personal defense, but don't have sum needed to buy more refined submachine gun or PDW.

%c[0,170,170,170]PKM is a modernized variant of PK ("Pulemyot Kalashnikova", Kalashnikov's Machine Gun), a Soviet general-purpose machine gun chambered in 7.62x54mmR cartridge, which was introduced in 1961 to replace RP-46 and SG-43 machine guns in military service. The PK is a gas operated, belt fed, air cooled machine gun firing from open bolt. The gas system consists of a gas chamber with a manual gas regulator and a long stroke gas piston located below the barrel. Unlike the AK and RPK, the PK machine gun is an open bolt design, which reduces overheating during automatic fire due to the airflow allowed into the chamber and the barrel. The belt is mounted from the right side. PK utilizes a two-stage belt feed from steel non-disintegrating belts. Receiver is made from 1.5mm thick stamped sheet steel. For additional rigidity and strength the PK receiver features double walls made from 1.5 mm steel plates. The heavy barrel is quick-changeable and is chromed for rust protection. Muzzle threading allows for mounting various muzzle devices. Skeletonized stock is made from birch plywood laminates. PKM is slightly lighter than PK, weighting 7.5kg, which makes it lightest GPMG in service. It's light weight, very high reliability and durability coupled with high firepower gave the PKM legendary fame, it is considered by many to be the best GPMGs in the world. It is used by more than 80 countries, among them Russia, Ukraine, West Germany, Yugoslavia, China, Finland and Poland. Poland and Yugoslavia made their own versions in 7.62x51mm NATO, which have even higher reliability due to use of non-rimmed cartridge. In The Zone, the PKM is commonly used by Ukrainian military as service weapon, and by stalkers as a weapon for support, defense or mutant hunting. Loners usually don't like LMGs for their excessive weight and they are usually only used as defensive weapons at camps, however, mutant hunters (especially from Duty) often employ at least one light machine gun in squad to increase their firepower to maximum when hunting dangerous mutants.

%c[0,170,170,170]PB ("Pistolet Besshumnyj", Silent Pistol), also known as 6P9, is an integrally silenced PM variant. Just like PM, it is a semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x18mm round. Straight blowback pistols, like Walther PP or Makarov PM, do not suppress well since the increased rearward pressure speeds up the slide and dumps a bunch of gas out the chamber end of the barrel, so a specially modified PB pistol was made for quiet shooting. PM is a compact, straight-blowback-action, all-steel construction, frame-fixed barrel handgun. It uses 9x18mm round which is at the limit of what a blowback design can withstand. The PB's firing mechanism and design is based on that of the Makarov pistol. Because the front part of the barrel is covered by the suppressor, the slide is very short, such that it does not allow placing a return spring into it. For that reason, the spring is in the grip, and acts on the slide by means of a long lever. Just like PM, the PB is very reliable, durable, relatively easy to use and maintain and works flawlessly. It is small and easy to conceal. SA/DA trigger allows for safe carrying with a round in the chamber. In The Zone, PB pistols are sometimes employed by military, special forces and mercenaries for stealth action. Stalkers sometimes use these pistols to kill stray dogs without making much noise.

%c[0,170,170,170]PM ("Pistolet Makarova", lit. Makarov's Pistol) is a Soviet semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x18mm Makarov round. It was designed and developed for Soviet military in 1947 to replace old TT-33 pistol, which had insufficient reliability and it's 7.62mm round had quite a high recoil. The Soviet military requested a new pistol with a list of requirements, among them reliability, low recoil and compact dimensions on par with Walther PP pistol. Nikolay Makarov designed a new pistol based on PP design and in 1949 his PM pistol was accepted into service with military. PM is a compact, straight-blowback-action, all-steel construction, frame-fixed barrel handgun. It uses 9x18mm round which is at the limit of what a blowback design can withstand. Overally, it is a very successful design. It is very reliable, durable, relatively easy to use and maintain and works flawlessly. It is small and easy to conceal. SA/DA trigger allows for safe carrying with a round in the chamber. The 9x18mm round is however rather underpowered for a military pistol; later the PM was replaced by 9x19mm pistols, most notably MP-443 in Russian army. PM is used by more than 40 countries, mostly ex-USSR. High amount of these pistols reached the black market. In The Zone, the PM is most common pistol in existence. Large amounts were stolen from the military warehouses or bought off from corrupt military officers. Makarovs are well liked and respected by stalkers, but modern pistols with higher capacity, chambered in more powerful 9x19mm rounds are usually preferred. Nonetheless, the reliable PM pistols are cheap, plentiful and dependable, and are definitely one of the best choices for those who don't have lots of money to spend for more expensive handguns.

%c[0,170,170,170]PM ("Pistolet Makarova", lit. Makarov's Pistol) is a Soviet semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9x18mm Makarov round. It was designed and developed for Soviet military in 1947 to replace old TT-33 pistol, which had insufficient reliability and it's 7.62mm round had quite a high recoil. The Soviet military requested a new pistol with a list of requirements, among them reliability, low recoil and compact dimensions on par with Walther PP pistol. Nikolay Makarov designed a new pistol based on PP design and in 1949 his PM pistol was accepted into service with military. PM is a compact, straight-blowback-action, all-steel construction, frame-fixed barrel handgun. It uses 9x18mm round which is at the limit of what a blowback design can withstand. Overally, it is a very successful design. It is very reliable, durable, relatively easy to use and maintain and works flawlessly. It is small and easy to conceal. SA/DA trigger allows for safe carrying with a round in the chamber. The 9x18mm round is however rather underpowered for a military pistol; later the PM was replaced by 9x19mm pistols, most notably MP-443 in Russian army. PM is used by more than 40 countries, mostly ex-USSR. High amount of these pistols reached the black market. In The Zone, the PM is most common pistol in existence. Large amounts were stolen from the military warehouses or bought off from corrupt military officers. Makarovs are well liked and respected by stalkers, but modern pistols with higher capacity, chambered in more powerful 9x19mm rounds are usually preferred. Nonetheless, the reliable PM pistols are cheap, plentiful and dependable, and are definitely one of the best choices for those who don't have lots of money to spend for more expensive handguns.

Nikolay Makarov designed a new pistol based on PP design and in 1949 his PM pistol was accepted into service with military. SA/DA trigger allows for safe carrying with a round in the chamber. The 9x18mm round is however rather underpowered for a military pistol; later the PM was replaced by 9x19mm pistols, most notably MP-443 in Russian army. PM is used by more than 40 countries, mostly ex-USSR. High amount of these pistols reached the black market. In The Zone, the PM is most common pistol in existence. Large amounts were stolen from the military warehouses or bought off from corrupt military officers. Makarovs are well liked and respected by stalkers, but modern pistols with higher capacity, chambered in more powerful 9x19mm rounds are usually preferred. Nonetheless, the reliable PM pistols are cheap, plentiful and dependable, and are definitely one of the best choices for those who don't have lots of money to spend for more expensive handguns.

%c[0,170,170,170]Armsel Protecta, also known as Striker or Bulldog, is a 12 gauge semi-automatic shotgun with revolving cylinder, designed in Rhodesia by H. Walker during 1980s for riot control and combat use. Striker was introduced in 1981, and after it came improved version, called Protecta. The key advantages of the Striker shotgun were its large magazine capacity, which is double the traditional shotguns magazine capacity of that time, and rapid-fire capability. On the other hand, the rotary cylinder-type magazine was bulky, very slow to reload, and the basic action was not without certain flaws. The weapon's action is similar to that of a revolver, using a rotating cylinder. Since the Striker uses a conventional double action only trigger and a very large and heavy cylinder (compared to handguns), Walker added a pre-wound clock-work spring to revolve the magazine which proved to make loading the weapon slow, in exchange for a shorter and lighter trigger pull. The design was changed into having a cocking lever on the right side of the barrel. The Protecta is a controversial weapon. On one hand, it has high capacity and provides high firepower. On the contrary, it has sub-par reliability, the magazine loading process is long and frustrating and the quality leaves a lot to be desired. Some of these shotguns came into The Zone, where they are sold on black market. They are sometimes used by mutant hunters for it's high firepower, but due to it's low reliability in harsh conditions of anomalous areas stalkers usually prefer other semi-automatic shotgun designs.

%c[0,170,170,170]The uniquely designed Armsel Protecta is a rotating cylinder fed 12-gauge shotgun developed for riot control and combat. Antiquated now by the Russian Saiga-12 and the American AA-12, the Protecta was a revolutionary weapon created by the Apartheid government in the 1980s. This smoothbore combat revolver-type shotgun was intended to provide extreme firepower for militarized units. The weapon benefits from a large magazine and a high effective rate of fire, but its bulkiness and considerable weight, combined with a long reload time, are the price to be paid for these advantages. Rare in the Zone and used primarily to clear confined spaces of mutants. This particular model of the Armsel Protecta is using the common m81 woodland camouflage. The m81 woodland pattern has been one of the most duplicated and modified camouflage patterns ever designed, seeing service with military forces around the world and continuing to be worn even today.
 
%c[0,140,140,140]ATTACHMENTS:
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] SUSAT series scopes

\n \n%c[0,170,170,170]The RG-6 was used as a means to increase the firepower of the infantry during urban combat, seen in small-scale conflicts, such as the Chechen wars. This revolver-type grenade launcher uses six rifled front-loading barrels, identical to underbarrel launcher attachments. The drum is also front-loaded. Widely used for rapid suppression of enemy firing positions and, when in the open, attacking defended fixed targets or fighting particularly tough mutants.

%c[0,170,170,170]PKM is a modernized variant of PK ("Pulemyot Kalashnikova", Kalashnikov's Machine Gun), a Soviet general-purpose machine gun chambered in 7.62x54mmR cartridge, which was introduced in 1961 to replace RP-46 and SG-43 machine guns in military service. The PK is a gas operated, belt fed, air cooled machine gun firing from open bolt. The gas system consists of a gas chamber with a manual gas regulator and a long stroke gas piston located below the barrel. Unlike the AK and RPK, the PK machine gun is an open bolt design, which reduces overheating during automatic fire due to the airflow allowed into the chamber and the barrel. The belt is mounted from the right side. PK utilizes a two-stage belt feed from steel non-disintegrating belts. Receiver is made from 1.5mm thick stamped sheet steel. For additional rigidity and strength the PK receiver features double walls made from 1.5 mm steel plates. The heavy barrel is quick-changeable and is chromed for rust protection. Muzzle threading allows for mounting various muzzle devices. Skeletonized stock is made from birch plywood laminates. PKM is slightly lighter than PK, weighting 7.5kg, which makes it lightest GPMG in service. It's light weight, very high reliability and durability coupled with high firepower gave the PKM legendary fame, it is considered by many to be the best GPMGs in the world. It is used by more than 80 countries, among them Russia, Ukraine, West Germany, Yugoslavia, China, Finland and Poland. Poland and Yugoslavia made their own versions in 7.62x51mm NATO, which have even higher reliability due to use of non-rimmed cartridge. In The Zone, the PKM is commonly used by Ukrainian military as service weapon, and by stalkers as a weapon for support, defense or mutant hunting. Loners usually don't like LMGs for their excessive weight and they are usually only used as defensive weapons at camps, however, mutant hunters (especially from Duty) often employ at least one light machine gun in squad to increase their firepower to maximum when hunting dangerous mutants.

%c[0,170,170,170]PKP Pecheneg is a Russian general-purpose machine gun chambered in 7.62x54mmR cartridge, based on older PK light machine gun. The idea for new construction came from Soviet experiences in Afghanistan and local conflicts, which shown a neccessity for a weapon better suited for prolonged firefights. It was named after the ancient nomadic, warlike tribe from Central Asia, who lived in what would later be known as steppes of Southern Russia. The PKP, just like PK, is a gas operated, belt fed, air cooled machine gun firing from open bolt. The gas system consists of a gas chamber with a manual gas regulator and a long stroke gas piston located below the barrel. The belt is mounted from the right side. PKP utilizes a two-stage belt feed from steel non-disintegrating belts. The receiver is made from thick stamped sheet steel. The main feature of PKP is the barrel, which, curiously is not meant to be changeable in the field, but is heavier than PK's, has cooling ribs and is enclosed in a steel jacket (which features a distinctive looking carrying handle), which runs up to the muzzle to provide forced air cooling, similarly to the famous vintage Lewis LMG of the first world war. Cooling air enters the jacket through oval windows at the rear of the jacket, and exits at the muzzle. Another change from the parent design is the location of the integral, non-removable folding bipod which is placed near the muzzle. This feature is said to improve stability and long-range accuracy when firing from the bipod, however it also limits the arc of fire and makes it harder to shoot from the hip. It weights 8.7kg, which is noticeably heavier than PKM (1.2kg more), but still much less than western designs like M240 (12.5kg). Overally, PKP is more durable than PKM, but also heavier and less maneuverable. It's barrel overheats slower, but also is impossible to quick-change when needed. Whether those advantages are worth those drawbacks depends on the situation. PKP is currently used only by few countries, most notably Russia and Syria.

%c[0,170,170,170]P220 is a semi-automatic pistol developed in 1975 by SIG Arms from Switzerland to replace older P210 in military service. P220 is a short-recoil operated, Browning-type locked-breech pistol. The slide is made from sheet steel by stamping and forming processes, with the separate breech block pinned into the rear of the slide. The standard trigger is a DA/SA type, with an automatic firing pin block safety and a frame-mounted de-cocking lever. Decocker allows the pistol to be carried with a round in the chamber, which is very important for a concealed carry weapon. As with all SIG firearms, the P220 is made with highest quality and was designed to work reliably even in harshest environments. Construction is very durable and can take more beating than typical steel-framed pistol. Weight is relatively low for all-steel construction, at 0.8kg. Drawback of P220 is single stack magazines which hold only 7 rounds of .45ACP, so later the P226 was developed, which can hold up to 18 rounds. P220 was accepted by militaries and police forces of few countries, among them Switzerland, France, Denmark, Japan and Vatican (used by Swiss Guard). Some of these pistols reached The Zone, mainly in hands of mercenaries and from black market, where they are liked as few modern pistols which work well with .45ACP caliber, and it's high reliability make it perform very well in harsh reality of anomalous zones.

%c[0,170,170,170]SG 550 SR is a sniper variant of Sturmgewehr 550, a 5.56x45mm assault rifle developed by Swiss Arms AG in Switzerland in the late 1970s. Differences from SG550 are heavy, hammer-forged, accurized barrel, refined, two-stage trigger (only 1/3 of standard pull weight), ergonomic, regulated pistol grip and special stock with cheek rest. The rifle comes with a bipod and Zeiss 10x scope by default. The rifle is extremely accurate for a semi-automatic design and is said to achieve sub-MoA accuracy with right ammunition. Rest is basically same as in SG550. It was based on AK action, but in extremely modernized package. SG550 is a gas operated, select fire rifle with gas piston and long stroke action. It has adjustable gas valve to improve it's performance in harsh environment. Furniture is from strengthened polymer, and the receiver is made from stamped steel and has two major parts, upper and lower. The heavy, cold hammer-forged barrel is screwed into the upper receiver and is equipped with a slotted "bird cage" type flash suppressor that is also used to launch rifle grenades or attach a bayonet. The gas system's components are made of stainless steel, the barrel, bolt and other parts are all made with steel that has been gas nitrided, hardened and tempered to provide highest possible protection from rust and damage - in effect the SG550 is incredibly reliable and durable rifle. SG550SR didn't gain wider popularity and is no longer produced. It is used by few counter-terrorist groups and law enforcement agencies. In The Zone some of them came in hands of mercenaries, but are very rarely seen. SG550SR is a very accurate rifle, but due to it's weaker 5.56x45mm ammunition it is considered less universal than full-size scoped rifles, nonetheless, despite it's niche usefulness, the SG550SR is one of the most refined sniper rifles available and reach very high prices on the black market.

%c[0,170,170,170]Sturmgewehr 550 is a 5.56x45mm assault rifle developed by Swiss Arms AG in Switzerland in the late 1970s. It was intended as modular weapon with several variants of different length. The new rifle was based on AK action, but in extremely modernized package. SG550 is a gas operated, select fire rifle with gas piston and long stroke action. It has adjustable gas valve to improve it's performance in harsh environment. Furniture is from strengthened polymer, and the receiver is made from stamped steel and has two major parts, upper and lower. The heavy, cold hammer-forged barrel is screwed into the upper receiver and is equipped with a slotted "bird cage" type flash suppressor that is also used to launch rifle grenades or attach a bayonet. The gas system's components are made of stainless steel, the barrel, bolt and other parts are all made with steel that has been gas nitrided, hardened and tempered to provide highest possible protection from rust and damage - in effect the SG550 is incredibly reliable and durable rifle. SG550 are made to have extraordinary accuracy, with about 95% hit probability on 300 meters demanded from every rifle - if rifle doesn't hold this standard, it's not accepted into service. Overally, the SG550 is a very accurate, reliable and effective weapon. Despite using AK type of action, the rearrangement allowed it to be very accurate, unlike typical AK variants. Long barrel allows 5.56mm bullet to reach high velocities, which improve it's terminal performance, as it relies on velocity to yaw and fragment in the tissue. SG550 is a service rifle of Swiss Army and it's variants are adopted by Canada, Finland, France, Germany, UK, USA and many more. In The Zone, the SG550 are used by multiple mercenary groups, some of them were stolen in widely reported incident in 2011 and ended up on Ukrainian black market, where they are very sought after and highly valued by stalkers for their high accuracy, long range and high reliability, even in harsh anomalous areas. Good terminal performance of 5.56mm bullet from long barrel also make SG550 an effective weapon for mutant hunting, especially with expanding ammunition.

%c[0,170,170,170]SG552 is a commando-length carbine variant of Sturmgewehr 550, a 5.56x45mm assault rifle developed by Swiss Arms AG in Switzerland in the late 1970s. It was intended as modular weapon with several variants of different length. The new rifle was based on AK action, but in extremely modernized package. SG550 is a gas operated, select fire rifle with gas piston and long stroke action. It has adjustable gas valve to improve it's performance in harsh environment. Furniture is from strengthened polymer, and the receiver is made from stamped steel and has two major parts, upper and lower. The heavy, cold hammer-forged barrel is screwed into the upper receiver and is equipped with a slotted "bird cage" type flash suppressor that is also used to launch rifle grenades or attach a bayonet. The gas system's components are made of stainless steel, the barrel, bolt and other parts are all made with steel that has been gas nitrided, hardened and tempered to provide highest possible protection from rust and damage - in effect the SG550 is incredibly reliable and durable rifle. SG550 are made to have extraordinary accuracy, with about 95% hit probability on 300 meters demanded from every rifle - if rifle doesn't hold this standard, it's not accepted into service. Overally, the SG550 is a very accurate, reliable and effective weapon. Despite using AK type of action, the rearrangement allowed it to be very accurate, unlike typical AK variants. Short barrel reduces velocity of 5.56mm bullet and it's terminal performance, as it relies on velocity to yaw and fragment in the tissue. SG552 and it's variants are adopted by Canada, Finland, France, Germany, UK, USA and many more. In The Zone, the SG552 are used by multiple mercenary groups and are very valued by stalkers for their compact size and light weight, which makes it very easy to carry on long expeditions, where one must carry a lot of loot.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]Semi-automatic shotgun. High damage output. Best on short range. %c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]SPAS-12 is is a combat shotgun manufactured by Italian firearms company Franchi from 1979 to 2000. The SPAS-12 is a dual-mode shotgun, adjustable for semi-automatic or pump-action operation. The SPAS-12 was sold primarily to military and police users worldwide. The appearance and intended purpose of the SPAS-12 initially led to its "military" designation as a combat shotgun. The SPAS-12 was designed from the ground up as a rugged military shotgun, and it was named the Special Purpose Automatic Shotgun. SPAS-12 utilizes, somewhat traditional for shotguns, gas system with annular gas piston located around the underbarrel magazine tube. The receiver is made of stamped sheet metal. It could be outfitted with metal buttstock that folds to the top of the receiver when not in use and with a pistol grip made of plastic, there were also versions with fixed polymer stock. Barrel has threading for screw-on muzzle devices like muzzle brakes and/or chokes. SPAS-12 gained worldwide fame after it appeared in many action movies and video games due to it's iconic, "combat" look. Nonetheless, it is an effective and reliable weapon and one of the first successful semi-automatic combat shotguns. Today SPAS-12 shotguns are rather rare. A batch of these shotguns reached the black market in The Zone, where these weapons, just like other semi-automatic shotguns, are very valued as close-combat weapons especially useful against wild animals and mutants. Mutant hunter squads often make use of semi-automatic shotguns for their immense firepower in close range and the SPAS-12 is not an exception to this. The only disadvantage to this shotgun is it's heavy weight, relatively complicated maintenance and quite a high price.

%c[0,170,170,170]SVD ("Snayperskaya Vintovka Dragunova", Dragunov's Sniper Rifle) is a semi-automatic sniper/designated marksman rifle chambered in 7.62x54mmR cartridge, developed by Y. Dragunov in Soviet Union in early 1960s. It is one of the most famous marksman rifles, known for it's unique aesthetics and ruggedness. SVD is a semi-automatic, gas-operated rifle with a short-stroke gas-piston system. The rifle's receiver is machined to provide additional accuracy and torsional strength. The barrel profile is relatively thin to save weight and is ended with a permanently fixed, slotted flash suppressor. The barrel’s bore is chrome-lined for increased corrosion resistance. The Dragunov's receiver bears a number of similarities to the AK rifle, but these similarities are primarily cosmetic in nature. These cosmetic similarities can lead to mis-categorization of the Dragunov as an AK variant. The rifle is issued with a quick-detachable PSO-1 optical sight, which was pretty advanced back then: it featured bullet drop compensation adjustment, an illuminated reticle with range finder grid as well as an infrared charging screen. However, by now, this scope is rather obsolete, as a lot of new sights with high power variable magnification are available. SVD's accuracy is at ~3.5 MoA, enough for typical DMR use at ranges of below 600m. In The Zone, the SVD is very common, as it is service weapon of Ukrainian military. A lot of them were stolen from warehouses or bought from corrupt military officials. Stalkers like SVDs for their reliability, ruggedness and high rate of fire compared to bolt-action sniper rifles, however, due to it's low-power sight, those who want to shoot on longer ranges usually prefer more modern rifles with high-magnification scopes. Nonetheless, SVD is still one of the most common and well-liked rifles of stalkers of all factions and professions.

Stalkers like SVDs for their reliability, ruggedness and high rate of fire compared to bolt-action sniper rifles, however, due to it's low-power sight, those who want to shoot on longer ranges usually prefer more modern rifles with high-magnification scopes. Nonetheless, SVD is still one of the most common and well-liked rifles of stalkers of all factions and professions.

%c[0,170,170,170]SVD ("Snayperskaya Vintovka Dragunova", Dragunov's Sniper Rifle) is a semi-automatic sniper/designated marksman rifle chambered in 7.62x54mmR cartridge, developed by Y. Dragunov in Soviet Union in early 1960s. It is one of the most famous marksman rifles, known for it's unique aesthetics and ruggedness. SVD is a semi-automatic, gas-operated rifle with a short-stroke gas-piston system. The rifle's receiver is machined to provide additional accuracy and torsional strength. The barrel profile is relatively thin to save weight and is ended with a permanently fixed, slotted flash suppressor. The barrel’s bore is chrome-lined for increased corrosion resistance. The Dragunov's receiver bears a number of similarities to the AK rifle, but these similarities are primarily cosmetic in nature. These cosmetic similarities can lead to mis-categorization of the Dragunov as an AK variant. The rifle is issued with a quick-detachable PSO-1 optical sight, which was pretty advanced back then: it featured bullet drop compensation adjustment, an illuminated reticle with range finder grid as well as an infrared charging screen. However, by now, this scope is rather obsolete, as a lot of new sights with high power variable magnification are available. SVD's accuracy is at ~3.5 MoA, enough for typical DMR use at ranges of below 600m. In The Zone, the SVD is very common, as it is service weapon of Ukrainian military. A lot of them were stolen from warehouses or bought from corrupt military officials. Stalkers like SVDs for their reliability, ruggedness and high rate of fire compared to bolt-action sniper rifles, however, due to it's low-power sight, those who want to shoot on longer ranges usually prefer more modern rifles with high-magnification scopes. Nonetheless, SVD is still one of the most common and well-liked rifles of stalkers of all factions and professions.

%c[0,170,170,170]"Lynx" is a custom-made rifle based on SVD ("Snayperskaya Vintovka Dragunova", Dragunov's Sniper Rifle) - a semi-automatic sniper/designated marksman rifle developed by Y. Dragunov in Soviet Union in early 1960s. "Lynx" rifles were modified and assembled by Clear Sky technician known as "Grey", as his faction didn't have enough real bolt-action sniper rifles for guarding their territory in open area of Pripyat marshes. After the faction grew in strenght, these rifles were sold and now are going from hands to hands. This rifle uses modern Russian POSP scope with 3-9x variable magnification which gives it high advantage over standard SVD. Differences from standard SVD are match trigger, improved gas system and new furniture. The rear part of the barrel is enclosed into tubular steel jacket, which in turn is located within polymer handguards. This relieves the barrel from the stress imposed by handguards and bipod, making it "half-free-floating", which improves accuracy. The rest is same as in SVD rifle. SVD is a semi-automatic, gas-operated rifle with a short-stroke gas-piston system. The rifle's receiver is machined to provide additional accuracy and torsional strength. The barrel profile is relatively thin to save weight and is ended with a permanently fixed, slotted flash suppressor. The barrel’s bore is chrome-lined for increased corrosion resistance. The Dragunov's receiver bears a number of similarities to the AK action, but those are primarily cosmetic in nature. SVD's accuracy is at ~3.5 MoA, enough for typical DMR use at ranges of below 600m; features of "Lynx" improve practical accuracy to about 2 MoA, on par with more advanced western rifles. In The Zone, the SVD is very common, as it is service weapon of Ukrainian military. A lot of them were stolen from warehouses or bought from corrupt military officials. Customized SVDs with improved optics, like Lynx, are considered very effective and are highly sought after by stalkers.

%c[0,170,170,170]SVU ("Snayperskaya Vintovka Ukorocennaya", Shortened Sniper Rifle) is a Russian semi-automatic sniper/designated marksman rifle based on the SVD rifle, built in bullpup configuration and chambered in 7.62x54mmR cartridge. The SVU was developed in early 1990s to meet the needs of the security forces of the Russian Ministry of Internal Affairs, such as OMON - they needed a more compact rifle than the long Dragunov. The basic action of the SVU-AS rifle is inherited from Dragunov SVD sniper rifle - it is a semi-automatic, gas-operated rifle with a short-stroke gas-piston system. Receiver is steel and furniture is made of polymer. Because of bullpup layout, the buttplate is attached directly to the receiver, and pistol grip and scope mount are moved forward. Barrel is shortened and equipped with multi-purpose muzzle device acting as a flash hider, sound dampener and a muzzle brake. It is said to reduce sound signature by 20% and reduce recoil by 40%. Standard sighting equipment includes open sights installed on folding bases, with rear being of diopter type and adjustable for range between 100 and 1300 meters. There's also a standard side mounting rail, which will accept a variety of telescopic or night-vision sights, the 4x PSO-1 being most typical. SVU uses standard SVD magazines. SVU rifles are currently used only by Russian law enforcement agencies, few are used by Ukrainian military. These rifles are rare in The Zone, being very rarely used by Ukrainian spetsnaz units operating in deeper parts of The Zone, some are also used by mercenaries. SVU are liked for their compact dimensions and better handling, but their high price and low numbers make them a rare sight.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Ergonomics: %c[0,170,170,170]high %c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] ATTACHMENTS: PSO-1 4x fixed magnification scope (permanent), SVU-AS muzzle device (permanent)

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[0,140,140,140] Main characteristic and advantages: %c[0,170,170,170]Greatly increased shot spread. Lowered weight and good handling. Very high damage. %c[0,140,140,140] 
 
%c[0,170,170,170]Homemade sawn-off variant of TOZ-34. Short barrel and removal of stock makes it lighter and more compact. It also increases shot spread greatly, improving the chance of hitting, however, because of spread and lower muzzle velocity the range is significantly lowered, making it uneffective beyond 40-50 meters. TOZ-34 is an over and under (O/U) double barrel shotgun manufactured by Tulsky Oruzheiny Zavod (Russian: Tula Arms Factory) in Soviet Union. It was designed in 1964 and it is still produced. Like all other Soviet hunting weapons, it is a simple design, without decorations or any revolutionary solutions, but is a solid piece of work and does it's job as intended, all that for unmatched price. It has a "monoblock" construction, the breech area, including the locking lugs, are machined from one piece. These shotguns were popular among hunters and civilian shooting enthusiasts and were brought to The Zone by stalkers who owned them or bought them on black market. Two barrels hold one shell each and can be fired both in the same time. One disadvantage of SxS setup is that barrels of a double-barreled shotgun are not parallel, but slightly angled, so that shots from the barrels converge, usually at about 40 meters out. For the O/U configuration with a parallel rib, both barrels' discharges will keep to the dead center, but the discharge from the "under" barrel will shoot higher than the discharge from the "over" barrel after 40 yards. Thus, double-barreled shotguns are accurate only at practical shotgun ranges, though the range of their ammunition easily exceeds four to six times that distance. Very long barrel provides tight spread and higher muzzle velocity than typical short combat shotguns and it basically guarantees a kill on up to 75m when aimed well. However, the tight spread and it's length mean it's rather unwieldy and less effective in close quarters - some users are sawing off the barrels to make it a light and compact weapon with wider spread, nonetheless the longer barrel is definitely more effective when it comes to big game hunting.

%c[0,170,170,170]The Beretta 682 is a high-end competition grade over-under shotgun. It is manufactured, marketed, and distributed by Fabbrica d'Armi Pietro Beretta. Beretta 682 comes in variants for sporting clays, trap and skeet shooting. It is extremely well made and beautifully crafted, with excellent quality and outstandingly aesthetic design. Apart from it's obvious high quality manufacture, it is perfectly balanced for easy and highly accurate shooting. It is very popular among professional sportsmen and hunters. Guns of this type are usually used by professionals or rich enthusiasts who can afford it and almost never seen in The Zone, since guns providing higher firepower are preferred. This one however somehow reached this place, and is now in your hands. When compared to more common cheap double barrel shotguns you will surely notice it's great handling and high accuracy, which make it a real pleasure to shoot.
